tweet.tweet_content: Hello Boston! Great to be working w/the FableVision team at the Children's Museum. Inspiring place! !
Good Morning! I found the last 45 sec of this short lightning video fascinating - beautiful to see & educational:
I'm intrigued by the pixellated surreality of whatever we're doing in this dry lakebed.
July morning, swim after a run, idyllic time and place to be a dog.
Congratulations to students Alexandria Milton & Harkarn Gamal! Good young Canadians, fine examples of our future
A friend just sent me this photo I took of a river and farmland in Brazil. The delicacy mesmerizes me.
Good Morning! Sunny by the forest and water. Days like this were remembered and made me smile to myself while orbiting Earth.
Had much fun inventing an image for the book cover, in-between whimsy & serious, as am I. Would you have chosen this?
Remind people that it's fun to be curious & they'll discover new things. Here's our Twitter effect on .
Playing music w/ & choir tomorrow 10AM, practice today. " 40 Pearl Hall kids rehearse music on stage at 1:45".
I'm just finishing the part about the live snake. For Canadians, here's where to find it: ,
Finishing writing a book this week. It's exciting for me to see it getting near! Like launch ,
I can fly! A huge human-powered helicopter wins the 33-year-old competition. I really like the video:
Good morning, after a long walk with 3 dogs. A refreshing way to be reminded of the available simplicity of life.
showed us how he cut his hair in space: . Now see how washes hers!
Several people asked about bone loss and adaptation to spaceflight - here's how they change over a few months.
Growing up on a farm I found this an oddly interesting 2 minutes: - corn growth comment is a Hadfield family trait:)
You can read about 's first few days back on Earth from his Flight Surgeon:
Good Morning! After 2 months back on Earth, went for my 1st run yesterday. Felt clumsy & awkward & winded - & great! Building bone back.
Good morning! Spacewalk day on Space Station, as Karen suits up Chris and Luca for a full day's work outside.
Good morning! Spacewalk day on Space Station, as Karen suits up Chris and Luca for a full day's work outside.
Good Morning! Odd how wearing my Stetson was so natural in Calgary, but seems less suitable here in Toronto. The geography of hats.
Yes, thanks for capturing the parade moment!
Blue Alberta sky, fine place to live,
This makes me think about chance and how we choose to treat each other:
Good Morning! Headed to the Suncor Energy Family Day Breakfast, free for the first 20,000 guests. That's a lot of pancakes!
Just watched the grandstand show . It was superb! Congratulations and thanks to all the talented performers & choreographers
Mark makes very cool cigar box guitars, was happy to sign one he's donating to flood relief.
Good morning! Hope to see you at the 17th Annual Ismaili Muslim Community Stampede Breakfast, supporting the Boys & Girls Clubs of Calgary.
It's inside 's wagon... what a great way to kick-off !
Logan - that was a ride to remember! The power of your 4-horse team was awesome to see up close. Thanks!
Last chance to win two tickets to speaking at tomorrow. Enter here. Our contest ends at noon.
Man and horse, after the parade, happy to have met so many people and helped open the Stampede together. Thanks, Jag.
One horsepower - Jag and I are ready to ride!
welcome to Calgary! Bad portrait time!! +you will rule the parade!
Good Morning! Time to ride a big white horse as parade marshal to help open the 101st Calgary Stampede. Clear and cool, good waving weather!
If you were suddenly singing on the Stampede stage, what song would you choose? I went with Long Black Veil.
Thanks everyone for all the nice words and best wishes. After 35 years, retirement feels very new and odd. Walking on a new path.
Thanks everyone for all the nice words and best wishes. After 35 years, retirement feels very new and odd. Walking on a new path.
Good morning, from the 1st day of my retirement. Headed to Calgary for the Stampede, booted, looking forward to seeing everyone there!
Stampede 101 - get boots to be Marshal for the parade. I love how these turned out! They have that new boot smell.
@WGAdams95 Will, the hardest parts of being an astronaut are fatalistic patience & remembering vast fine detail over decades.
As soon as I get to Calgary tomorrow, I'm buying one of these.
Canada Day was SO much fun! This photo by David Johnson helps captures the joy & rarity it all
Tattoo is on my guitar-playing Canadarm :)
Punctuation optional, prideful bemusement pervasive. ": Oh,Canada! Oh!! Canada? Oh CANADA! Oh? Canada… etc "
I play in the Noon & evening shows on the Hill, and play Oddity at 3:30 with in Major's Hill Park. Fun day!
The nice waitress just gave me a tattoo to put on. Where should I wear it?
Bonne fête, Canada! Le spectacle à Ottawa commence à midi.
Thank you. Good luck with your presentation!
Happy Canada Day! The sun is shining on Ottawa. A fine place to be on Earth today.
Only band in the world to cover Space Oddity with a fiddle, a banjo & an astronaut
An artist by profession, she was touching up the stage paint black.
Blue sky, Green room, Parliament.
Good morning Ottawa! A day of music practice: ISS song with choirs, Space Oddity with , then dinner with Chicken Farmers.
Like many lucky people, I love the people and the land that are my country:
Thanks Bailey, that's a really nice thing to say.

tweet.tweet_content: A great space day - 1st-hand account video of Space Station ammonia leak, how it looked, and what we did to fix it.
Disaster Cam - we installed a telescope on ISS that's helping see extent of Alberta flooding:
Bonjour, Montreal! Thanks everyone for the good wishes about the award. An honour to meet with our Governor General.
NASA's next spaceship is called 'Orion'. & Ricky Arnold doing a pressure suit test in the main capsule.
On Monday crewmate & I will be in Ottawa answering any questions you have. Here's how to submit them
Istanbul waters - the sunglint shows how the Black Sea water flows through the Bosphorus.
Now that's a help desk - thanks! ": APC_index_mismatch is the error. Disable APC in the bios."
A new elementary school bearing my name is a high honour and responsibility! What will they name their sports teams?
Not what I wanted to see 3 minutes before Skyping with this morning!
Thanks everyone for the bone marrow donor matching information at onematch.ca. I'm a bit over the age limit, but you might save a life.
Today my daughter got added to the bone marrow registry in Ireland, where she lives. I'd like to follow her example. How do I in Canada?
Sun glint turns a thousand miles of rivers into a single veined leaf.
A Calgary exclusive! This year's Stampede Parade Marshal, , will be on BT today.
I wonder how many other report cards & Ed from will be on? Yay, Cordelia!
. the structure of Station stays parallel to Earth for comm/science, while solar arrays & radiators rotate to track the Sun.
. Spacewalking is more like rock climbing, so it's mostly fingers, forearms and shoulders that ache.
2 friends just did a 6.5-hour spacewalk, readying Station for the new Russian laboratory. Good work Fyodor & Sasha!
Good morning! I love how some people have fun with the mundane - and create a personal expression of art!
Six degrees from Khan. I'm guessing we're both related to Kevin Bacon:
Six degrees from Khan. I'm guessing we're both related to Kevin Bacon:
It took about the same time to drive from Houston to Canada as it did from Kazakhstan to the Space Station. Different fast food enroute.
After 26 years serving in other places around the world, tonight I am back on Canadian soil, to stay. It feels so very good to be home.
Swan Song. On last night before leaving Houston, our band played a couple tunes. Song choice? Moondance :)
Floods are an unbridled misery. My heartfelt thoughts and wishes for a swift recovery to those battling the Alberta high waters.
My last morning with NASA. They said "1 last thing before you go" Good to the last drop! Headed home to Canada today.
Green man lake. I can't help but see human faces in the natural shapes and colours.
A perfect likeness, in crochet! I love the fine attention to detail.
For those wondering, this is the 'head bolt'. Affectionate name for an ESA Circadian rhythms experiment.
Good Morning! A strange week of lasts. Today is my last physical rehab session, last psychomotor test & head bolt off. I'm ready for normal.
Two Commanders. A delight to be with 4 1/2-year old Daniel-James in his astronaut suit and happy smile.
A rare sight at the Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center, last week in Star City, Russia. Does my heart proud.
Hawaiian lava, like Japanese ink.
How cool is this - performing hit song, Astronaut, from space!
A school in Corner Brook NL won the national photo contest for my spaceflight. Had fun Skyping with them yesterday!
It was beautiful in Star City, Russia last week. In winter hardy locals swim through a hole in the ice in that pond.
Chris Hadfield speaks via video conference with students at JJ Curling Elementary in Corner Brook.
NASA has announced their new astronauts! A hugely impressive group. Worth taking a moment to look at their skills.
Good Morning! Today's our crew debrief to the NASA Astronaut Office, all lessons-learned & recommendations. What to tell the as-yet unflown?
. After a 21-year mission I'm making room for The Next Generation. And maybe an alien or two :)
. After a 21-year mission I'm making room for The Next Generation. And maybe an alien or two :)
It somehow felt like this lake was looking at me.
Happy Fathers' Day, Dad! A guiding example & voice in my head all my life. You're not on Twitter, so I'll call you :)
Good morning, & happy 50th anniversary of spaceflight to friend Valentina Tereshkova, first woman to orbit our Earth:
It surprised me to see that Corsica still had snow in May. And a spider's egg cloud.
. thanks Mayor Sorensen, I'm looking forward to my next Banff visit! I used to downhill race & teach; your town's a beautiful hub
My daughter made this fine felt likeness of me years ago, has adorned my office nametag since. Note Tin Tin's rocket.
Office pack-up - before picture. This Moon poster was above my bed growing up. Reminds and inspires me.
G made a paper mustache and said "I'm !!"
Good morning! Boxing up my office at NASA today after 21 years here. An atypical collection of things and emotions. It's so long been home.
I love this picture - the real 3D jumble of being people in a spaceship.
From FB: "My 4 yr-old thinks you should retire & study snails. I believe that you should remain a public promoter of science more generally"
The ultrasound technologist told me I have very nice bladder inlet ducts. I felt strangely complimented and said 'thank-you'. So proud.
Good Morning! Got to give a commencement address yesterday to Nova Scotia Community Colleges - love that technology!
After 1 month on Earth, the doctors are testing to see how my body is changing & adapting. Felt normal until this!
Good Morning! A photo with Yuri Gagarin. Tom, Roman and I at Friday's welcome home ceremonies in Star City, Russia.
At the NASA Johnson Space Center, you need to watch your step. Easy to tell I'm back in southeast Texas!
Good Morning, Toronto! On my way through today, but looking forward to being back soon.
Reading the so many notes of support and thanks. A lovely and thoughtful end to a big day for me. I thank each of you for taking the time.
To say goodbye to these good people today was much harder than I expected.
To say goodbye to these good people today was much harder than I expected.
Driving to Montreal to the Cdn Space Agency. : MEDIA - Canada Welcomes Home Astronaut .
Good Morning! On my way to breakfast with the Prime Minister and his wife. A high honour for this Canadian.
The Earth gleams against the black and blue.
Good Morning, Canada! Recognize where I woke up? Gorgeous morning for a walk, out to get a little June sun on my face
Back in Canada! On the ground at Montreal airport. Been welcomed home by so many people already, warms my heart, like reuniting with family.
Vancouver, with the Fraser River flowing full, roiling Spring run-off from the Rockies.
. Yes, germs can live on the Space Station, so we're very careful to sterilize upcoming vehicles.
She could only read 3 words, now can read 20 "wants to go to space, needs to be a good reader to be smart so she can"
. A large black coffee & a maple-dip doughnut would be great right now! I'll be in Canada at the CSA on Monday, hopefully then :)
Sleep-shifting around the world always leads to a few nights of insomnia. Unavoidable part of travel. I'll nap later!
Good Morning! Pomp and ceremony day in Star City as this small, proud spacefaring community officially welcomes our crew back to Earth.
New Brunswick and the Bay of Fundy in the mid-April sun.
. I haven't seen ISS fly overhead since I got back on Earth. I'm looking forward to it and curious how it will make me feel.
If you're interested, you could try a similar experiment: stand on your head and see if you can burp. If you can't, why?
I'd like to sing with you and your choir on Canada Day - today's the deadline to apply!
Five minutes after spaceflight - Tom & I did a beanbag chair chat with & belovedly unique
Good Morning! I salute & thank each of you, now over a million of us, together sharing the experience of exploration, art & learning. Wow!
sure does - info here:
I think my father owns that airplane, flies it on his farm in Ontario. Why do you ask?
I think my father owns that airplane, flies it on his farm in Ontario. Why do you ask?
It was really nice of Ryan Holmes to write this article. Computers, pizza and paintball:
I am smiling and laughing, enjoying the variety of faces people from around the world are drawing in there!
Just south of the Galapagos, this cloud is waiting for you to draw a face.
. The Great Wall of China is not visible from orbit with the naked eye. It's too narrow, + follows the natural contours & colours.
Albert Einstein launches in 10 hours, headed to the Space Station. I'll be watching:
. When I cut myself shaving in space, I think it clotted a little better as the weightless blood stayed put on the cut.
. I got to know the builders when they were here, rang the church bells when first installed, ate and played music together
Good Morning! This Russian church is just outside my quarters in Star City - it's also my screensaver.
How Cassidy made his new, bald Italian astronaut crewmate Luca feel at home on Space Station:
Montreal Trudeau Airport, Dorval, plus the south end of the city on a February winter's day.
Star City has been the cosmonaut training centre since Gagarin. You can see it on at 55.878922,38.117273. Try satellite view.
Hello from Star City! Air is warm, swans on the pond, flowers in bloom, everything green with the start of Russian summer. Photos to follow.
Orange-peel sands of Saudi Arabia.
. Thanks Ben - I'm seeing many of these videos for the 1st time too. A great voyage chronicle to have.
Good Morning! Flying to Star City, Russia today for debriefs. 3 weeks ago we could cross the Atlantic in the time it took to make tea ...
. Thanks Steven! Together with I think we made 146 videos in 146 days, to help see & understand life & science on ISS.
Gibraltar has a busy harbour.
Bandella at the end of the reunion concert, circa 1 AM. Beloved friends and musicians all.
Complex waters off the Mexican southwest coast.
Complex waters off the Mexican southwest coast.
The early crowd gathered for our music gig last night. Good to spend an evening with friends, after half a year away.
This Cuban coral reef redefines the colour blue.
Recovery takes months, especially bone density. But today my symptoms are sore feet & back from standing/playing, & raspy throat.
Played a reunion gig in a local pub with music group Bandella last night. Friendly crowd, warm harmonies - smiling wide this good morning.
One straight human line drawn onto incredibly rough terrain.
Sudbury, Ontario, rich in nickel and copper, the ore put there by an asteroid impact 2 billion years ago.
Astana, capital of Kazakhstan since 1997, modern downtown surrounded by the steppe turning Spring green.
Good morning, Saturday! Saw the last night. It made me really think & feel about where I've been; need to reconcile it all.
Hard brown ship of rock, adrift on a sea of salt.
Inside this tilting, turning simulator is an astronaut trying to remember which way is up.
Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, with a few traces of snow still visible from Space in early May.
Red River overflowing - Spring floods making a sorry mess between Grand Forks and Winnipeg.
Amazing to work in a place where you see this as you walk between buildings.
Good Morning! May has been a bustling month, rife with amazing events, fast changes and new memories. Onward to the languorous heat of June.
Delicate fan of farms sharing the water as it flows from the hills, China.
Lisbon, Portugal, clear and bright on a Spring day.
Thanks to Lord Mayor Naoise Ó Muirí for bestowing such an honour, and all in Ireland who have supported throughout.
My daughter having fun at the Dublin Lord Mayor's Awards on my behalf. The mace is from 1718, the sword from 1410.
My daughter having fun at the Dublin Lord Mayor's Awards on my behalf. The mace is from 1718, the sword from 1410.
. that's the thin upper edge of our atmosphere, lit-up by the power of the Northern Lights. So beautiful to see.
Matamoros and Brownsville, where the Rio Grande finally meets the Gulf, at the US/Mexico border.
. I love it! From my ears to the white space socks, you got it perfect :)
Good morning! Got together with friends last night to play music. The guitar felt so heavy, but stable; the harmonies lighter than air. Fun!
Winnipeg, with winter passed, fields turning green, river and spillway look full.
Lord Mayor of Dublin Award - a singular honour! Many thanks to my daughter Kristin for attending on my behalf.
vient d'annoncer que fera partie des festivités de la . Soyez-y!
Have a choir? Want to sing with this ? Here's how:
to celebrate Canada Day in Ottawa is a family favourite - I'm looking forward to being a part of it!
The starkly beautiful Labrador coast, stage-lit in the setting sun.
Good Morning! Spaceship dockings are happy events, especially when hairstyles match.
I am home preparing for tomorrow's meetings, but very distracted by the Soyuz docking:
Not sure, but I think that's a field of sand dunes covered in snow.
. A revelationary experiment on ISS:
. That guitar is a beloved resident on ISS:
. We ran ~130 experiments in the labs, from human health to fluid physics to Earth's atmosphere to collecting Dark Matter,
. Yes, many times & places across Canada's north, including a round of golf at . An unforgiving course.
My Mom & Dad are very proud to see the cover of magazine: . Shel Silverstein cover of :)
My Mom & Dad are very proud to see the cover of magazine: . Shel Silverstein cover of :)
. I've been to all larger cities in Canada, many times, & most of the country in-between. Driven Trans-Canada in a 62 Bug
. Thanks Diane, that's really nice to hear. I have seen Australia so intimately from above, but have yet to be there in person.
. Just came from a mtg with our photo/video experts at NASA JSC - SO many images to share. World wonders.
. it's steepest at first, but physical rehab takes about 4 months. Should be back to normal by late summer.
Been on Earth 2 weeks, a day of blood draws, medical science tests, starting technical debriefs, plus 2 hrs rehab.
. Launch is 20:31 GMT, 15:31 Houston time, 02:31 AM for them (local Kazakh time)
. A new Soyuz hull is needed for each launch, but much of the internal equipment is reused for multiple flights. Saves money.
You can watch the & launch on NASA TV later today: . They were our backup crew 6 months ago.
. Station has had 3 aboard since we undocked two weeks ago. They'll be cleaning up for company today!
Today Karen, Feodor & Luca leave Earth, flying their Soyuz spaceship up to the International Space Station. Godspeed!
Lake Baikal, Siberia, immensely deep, ancient waters, locked under late winter ice.
Dip your brush, paint something from this Chinese mining town's palette.
Happy 10th birthday
. I feel a great contentment, an inner smile, and a delight in working to be a part of what links the two in human experience.
Bahamas Blues Festival
Sun, sea and toes in the sand. Two weeks back on Earth. Marvelous.
. Thanks Martha - the ability to share in wonder and learning, half a world away, is great. Hi to all the students!
The last Monday in May, Memorial Day here in the United States. I honour all those who lost their lives in service of their country. Salute.
. Those were filmed from a Space Shuttle through the overhead windows, during post-undocking flyaround. Amazing sight.
. Those were filmed from a Space Shuttle through the overhead windows, during post-undocking flyaround. Amazing sight.
Signs of Spring - the melt beginning on the eastern edge of Hudson Bay.
Looking at my spine - Kat is a world-class ultrasound specialist, learning about osteoporosis through her hands.
This German machine uses X-rays to create a detailed image of the old and new bone structure in my leg. Key info.
Tortured rock where India crashed into Asia and pushed up the Himalayas.
Good Morning! Time to get some sun on my face, after 5 months in an aluminum cave. But first - 2 hours of physical rehab. Getting there.
Sunlight on the water reflects the many bays of Newfoundland, like vertebra of rock.
. Space Station stays parallel to horizon while orbiting every 90 min, so it pitches at 4 deg/min (360/90)
. How spaceflight affects astronaut vision:
. Yes. My Dad's side of the family is from Yorkshire, I've visited several times. Great Granddad settled in Canada in 1908.
. Yes, I was a Cub Scout in Milton, ON. My Mom drove us to the weekly meetings at the Fairgrounds. I worked hard to earn badges.
. I'll be in Ireland as soon as I can. So many people to visit, but first & foremost my daughter in Dublin.
. That's Kevin Ford, ISS Commander back in Dec at docking. The majority of astronauts wear glasses, especially after spaceflight.
. Wow! How did you make that photo mosaic? Cool image.
Spaceflight Photos! Just got a copy of the 25,000 or so images of our 5 months in orbit. Big smiles on docking day.
Pockets of snow on The Rock - St John's in mid-April.
Crewmate Roman Romanenko has been busy since our landing - answers some Mars travel questions:
Very nice article, with a quote that made me smile: " adorably unhip Tom Selleck 'stache "
Nice to chat with you over breakfast, everyone. Now off to rehab, drive the recovering body through physiotherapy. One small step at a time.
. As everyone who's ever belly-flopped will attest, water is hard, too. And you can't drown on land. It's a risk trade-off.
. As everyone who's ever belly-flopped will attest, water is hard, too. And you can't drown on land. It's a risk trade-off.
. I'm a CSA astronaut, been in the NASA astronaut corps 21 years, was NASA's Director of Ops in Russia. ISS is International.
. excellent health, advanced technical degree, proven operational work experience, burning desire.
. I flew on the Shuttle twice. It & Soyuz had different purposes & thus design trade-offs. Both are amazing human inventions.
. Average age to begin as an astronaut is mid-30s; takes that long to gain the skills/qualifications. NASA's hiring a new class.
. Landing in the Soyuz is violent, like a planned car crash. Our fitted seats have shock absorbers. Quite a welcome home.
. the Soyuz lands near the Baikonur launch cosmodrome. Nearest towns are Karaganda & Zhezkazgan, in Kazakhstan's open prairie.
Good Morning! At Earth impact the Soyuz fires optimistically-named 'soft landing rockets'. Here's how ours looked.
Africa blurs my eyes to the endless horizon.
To inspire art in others is a rare reward. Thanks to Lauren Crawford for sharing her talent.
Good article in . I'm very glad we were methodical and legal with David Bowie's creation.
My kids love Space Oddity and just requested it out of the blue. Thanks again, .
Lake like a shadow puppet.
. I took 10s of thousands of photos of our planet while living in orbit. Just starting to get them to look through now
The mouth of the Nile and the Red Sea, Cairo brightly lit.
Good Morning! Had a chance to sit down & talk with Rob Navias of NASA TV - how the experience looks to me now:
Our Earth is just simply beautiful.
Art deco farming.
Quantitative Computed Tomography, taking 3D images of my new hipbone internal structure. Wonder what we'll find out?
This is how I flew, raced and drove a Mars rover 2 hours after I landed back in Houston. I'm less of a hazard now...
This is how I flew, raced and drove a Mars rover 2 hours after I landed back in Houston. I'm less of a hazard now...
Here is the direct link to the Google+ Q&A session, starting at 3p.m. EDT:
An hour of Neurospat and my brain is fried like an egg. Doing my best for ESA science.
's psychomotor vigilance test for is described here:
Questions for Astronauts? Our crew will be on-line today, Tom, Kevin & I, ready to answer anything you want to ask.
Just completed my psychomotor vigilance test, best reaction times ever, then realized it's not actually on my schedule. Rehab irony.
. The most magnificent experience, hanging on to all of humanity with one hand, between Earth's riot and the bottomless universe.
Good Morning! Space Station appears to be back to normal power and cooling today, as a result of our crew's spacewalk. That feels very good.
This South American lake looks like an uncomfortable place to go swimming.
The Isle of Portland looks like an interesting place - the type I'd like to visit now that I'm back on Earth.
Looking bizarrely like 2001 A Space Odyssey, post-flight medical testing blurs my reality with fantasy.
The only thing that delights me more than this picture is imagining her thoughts.
. Even after floating everything for half a year, I haven't dropped anything yet! But I don't throw things reliably.
Good Morning! I've been back a week, and finally feel like I have my legs under and my wits about me. Seems landing on a planet takes time.
Today's photo is a river doing impersonations: Look, I'm a Stag Beetle!
Working with Adam and Jamie was fun! Mutual moustache appreciation:
I love MRIs. Vital science, imaging my eroded spine, learning about the body, all with a few bonus minutes to nap.
. yes, I did make another, and even convinced a crewmate to make one. They were delicious! A nice, simple space recipe.
SPICY SPACE BURRITOS! Need I say more? Watch create a new space dish for on board the ISS.
Heart and lungs, on the cardio machine to see exactly how bodies readapt. I have empathy for the cries of newborns.
Heart and lungs, on the cardio machine to see exactly how bodies readapt. I have empathy for the cries of newborns.
. When we vacuum the filters weekly on Space Station, most of the debris is shed skin flakes. Sort of gross, you get used to it.
Still so stoked this happened!! Thank you !!
. my backbone stretched in weightlessness, but scrunched back down to normal again in gravity. Was hard to put my spacesuit on!
Good morning! After my 1st spaceflights as I awoke I felt like I was floating above the bed for a few days, but not this time. I wonder why?
Today's photo shows light snow and low sun turning the American Midwest into a strange bas-relief.
After several months, that's a joyous amount of laundry.
My Leafs shirt and Russian long underwear, still soaked with sweat from the fiery re-entry, ready for the laundry.
Look deep into my eyes. Dr. Gibson uses all the tools to see how I see. It appears my eyes were unchanged. Yay!
Time in weightlessness affects basic 3D perception. Studying how we interpret things using an experiment.
and I made a space game for to play on the ISS! Can you guess what we used to make it?!?
Tell the eye doctor that your trip to space changed my vision...of our beautiful planet! Thank you for that!
Hot smokestack exhaust streams in the harsh wind across a central Asian winter landscape.
. sounds like fun - I played rugby while I was in university at Royal Roads in Victoria, BC. A great game.
Good morning from NASA JSC - today I get eye tests, see if weightlessness changed my vision, as it has for some. Also med tests & physio.
Today's photo is of Argentina. A tongue of mud lashing in the river's mouth.
After today's medical tests & physio, here's one of the several interviews I did, with Toronto TV. Time for a nap!
. The only way to achieve your dreams is to continue to pursue them. Accept that they and you will change over time. Pursuit.
Apparently this is a good place to drill for water, in Saudi Arabia.
. Very glad to be home with family & friends after the magnificent experience, so much to tell. Hi to your 7th grade students!
. Very glad to be home with family & friends after the magnificent experience, so much to tell. Hi to your 7th grade students!
. to be able to inspire others, especially youth, is the most important and lasting impact of what I do. Best to your daughters
. yes, we use the laboratory of weightlessness to study osteoporosis, both prevention and recovery. I'm a test subject:)
. it will take a few months until I truly feel back to normal, and a year or more for bone density to rebuild. Long rehab road.
Good Morning! Played some guitar last night with friends for the 1st time since landing, don't have full breath yet, but so sweet to hear.
Today's photo is Mallorca. Wow. Please remind me to go there when I'm fully recovered.
Luv this pic! ": 3 men, a moon , & Roman Romanenko were enroute to "
Pegboard task - testing hand-eye coordination as it changes back. Just like a test we did during astronaut selection.
. is pictured with the U of Waterloo team for the BP Reg investigation:
With the research team from U Waterloo. Danielle, Richard and Andrew studying the body's circulatory system controls.
Good Morning! To test my balance readaptation today I drive a motion simulator of a car, T-38 jet & Mars rover. Plus rehab physio & intrvws.
Today's photo is of the rising Moon. How could anyone have ever thought the world was flat?
Spent 75 minutes imaging my innards in this MRI. You'd think I'd at least come out with a tan!
's picture is from the ESA investigation called Neurospat:
This is your brain, on Earth. ESA neurological experiment measuring brainwave changes as I adapted to and from 0G.
You know you're back on Earth when you suddenly have to watch where you put your feet. One small step for man...
AWESOME ALERT on ! and I got to create a dish for on 's ISS!
How I earned my breakfast this morning. Welcome back to Earth.
. Oddity was so much fun to record in orbit. Son Evan's revised lyrics & Emm & Joe's music made it resonate around the world.
Good Morning from the Johnson Space Center! Happy to report that my body and balance feel much better. Today I'm going without the G-suit.
Good Morning from the Johnson Space Center! Happy to report that my body and balance feel much better. Today I'm going without the G-suit.
YESSS! Two of my FAVORITE topics: Space + Food! Watch 's 's Space Food Systems Lab visit video, here:
Today's photo is sunrise, the windows glinting and solar array gilded in the unbelievably harsh morning light.
My left hand, all wired-up to measure how my body is readapting to gravity. Part of a Japanese university study.
. I wonder how the rides at the CNE Midway will compare to my ride back from orbit in the Soyuz?
An update on 's condition, by CSA's Flight Surgeon Raffi Kuyumjian:
Wired head, chest, arms and feet, learning how the body works when it has been weightless for half a year.
Thanks Dave - and happy birthday!
Good Morning from Houston! First chance today to talk with Canadian media, try and describe the wonder of the experience. + physiotherapy.
Today's photo is from the Mongolian highlands. Surreal to see a frozen lake surrounded by sand dunes.
I took a few thousand more photos in space than I was able to post. I'll try to update from here on out with at least one per day.
How does the body control blood pressure? Scarecrow on a tilt table to measure how.
It's cliche, but this is my 1st meal back on Earth. The smell is like an old friend.
Return to Gravity, so many things. It is strange to talk and feel the weight of my lips and tongue! Dizzy too - would fail any sobriety test
Shower door in NASA astronaut quarantine facility. I think I want one at home.
I've just been through my Twitter, Facebook & email welcomes home - am overwhelmed. Thanks to everyone who took the time to write. So nice.
Good Morning, Earth! 1st real morning back on the planet, still dizzy & jet-lagged, full NASA sched of med tests and rehab. So much 2 tell!
Good to back in Houston at Johnson Space Center - sort of: 14 vials of blood, now on to coordination tests. Welcome home :)
Back in North America! Walking around the Bangor, Maine airport, getting my Earth legs back. Fresh, clean air has never been so sweet.
MEDIA ADVISORY - Canadian Space Agency Astronaut First News Conference Since Returning to Earth:
Forgot to mention: first long, hot shower since December. That felt so good! Step 1 of Return to Earth complete.
On the ground in Prestwick , Scotland, to refuel. Blue sky day, Nature smiling on us. Was 1st here in 1977 - who could have predicted this?
Safely home - back on Earth, happily readapting to the heavy pull of gravity. Wonderful to smell and feel Spring.
"It`s a boy!" jokes !
144 days on the , 146 days in space, 2,336 orbits around the planet and clocked almost 62 million miles. What a ride!
Touchdown. We are celebrating!
TOUCHDOWN!!! , Roman , welcome home! !!!
In case it isn't entirely clear, I am retweeting these for my father. He does not have twitter, internet, or free time in Soyuz. :)
Parachutes are open! Descent is being slowed to 7.2metres/second.
Under 15 minutes to touchdown. Roman Romanenko, the Soyuz Commander, could not be doing a better job returning our crew home.
2 minutes to maximum G-force. 4-5 G's on reentry. 4 minutes to parachutes opening (6.7 miles up).
We lose communication with the capsule during re-entry. This is normal. Capsule is about to interface with the atmosphere.Cue the fireworks!
30 minutes till landing!
Now Soyuz splits in 3 pieces.Middle part has our precious cargo.Other 2 pieces burn up,trash section& engine/computer/power section.
Accurate de-orbit burn! Great news!
Soyuz de-orbit burn is underway. No turning back now, they're coming back to earth now! At least somewhere on the planet.
If Soyuz automated entry system fails, then it gets more interesting for crew. Crew will manually fly the capsule or enter in ballistic mode
5 minutes away from deorbit burn:
One hour, nine minutes to touchdown.
Deorbit burn and landing coverage on NASA tv starts now:
Big unknown in Soyuz landing accuracy is not orbital mechanics, it is the wind during the parachute ride(15min).
From the both of us, with the most sincerity and gratitude I can express, thanks to all of you for making Expedition 35 one to remember.
Dad is a bit indisposed, but I'm certain that he would be incredibly grateful - immensely grateful - to know how many of you are watching.
Wonder what it looks like in the Soyuz capsule? I think the term they prefer is "cozy".
Deorbit burn and landing coverage should begin in around one hour's time:
. He doesn't have internet during his time in Soyuz. While he is there, I am just retweeting so people can be updated.
I will try to keep updates as best I can. That said, is giving a very good feed of the landing. He would be hard to top. :)
Now crew waits for de-orbit burn at 9:37pmET. Till then monitor systems, ensure suits ready and strap in tight. Real tight!
To those looking for Dad's schedule, from undocking to landing, it can be found here:
Spaceflight finale: To some this may look like a sunset. But it's a new dawn.
Hamburg, famed port city in northern Germany, on what must have been a lovely day to take a stroll down the Elbe.
Reviewing Soyuz procedures onboard, but I wanted to thank every person at the Cdn Space Agency. Your work takes Canada into orbit. Be proud.
how the vid came to be:
You can see how high we are when you see how close this jet trail is to the ground.
Thank you for helping us bring space and science in Canadian classrooms during this mission!
Our solar arrays, like the Earth's atmosphere, are thin, beautiful and vital for keeping us alive.
Clouds swoop in on Crimea, a white bird on the Black Sea.
The southwest corner of Africa, from space.
Good morning, Earth! We're supposed to be sleeping late to be rested for tonight's Soyuz flight home, but I'm finding it hard to sleep in.
Tonight's Finale: Boston, you're a beautiful harbor city. Hope your Bruins play a memorable game tonight vs the Leafs
Tonight's Finale: Boston, you're a beautiful harbor city. Hope your Bruins play a memorable game tonight vs the Leafs
Watch hand over the role of Commander to friend & crewmate Pavel Vinogradov:
Canada rocks.
's beautiful tribute to Bowie, recorded on the ISS & my tribute to him
I missed it in the last tweet, but those looking for Joe Corcoran (who produced and mixed the song), he can be found at .
Huge thanks in the making of the video to the talented trio of , Joe Corcoran and , plus and all at the CSA.
With deference to the genius of David Bowie, here's Space Oddity, recorded on Station. A last glimpse of the World.
Spaceships glowing blue in the dawn as we leave Florida headed across the Atlantic.
Watch as transfers the command of the to Pavel Vinogradov at 3:40 pm EDT.
Utah ski hills, dry powder and Winter Olympics. Next year I'll get some skiing in.
As he prepares for his return, shares his mission reflections & thanks us for coming along on the ride
Almost time to leave Station. Hard to express all of my emotions, but mostly gratitude. I came here on behalf of so many people - thank you.
Cool shot of cloud streets over England from in space: How they form:
English clouds showing how to properly queue over Hull and the Humber Estuary.
Belfast, at the mouth of the River Lagan. Strangely, not the river the city was named after. Who can tell me why?
It's Mothers' Day today, please don't forget. I ordered flowers for my Mom & am about to give her a call. Don't tell, she's not on Twitter:)
Dr. Seuss-inspired swirls in the Black Sea.
ISS Ham radio - talking today to RCMP detachment & students in Yellowknife, NWT. Many thanks to for all the contacts!
. Thanks! From one former spaceship Engineer to another, we both know how good it is to be part of a great crew.
Good Morning, Earth! Today I proudy hand command of Space Station to Pavel Vladimirovich Vinogradov. Time to rev up the Soyuz, home tomorrow
Good Morning, Earth! Today I proudy hand command of Space Station to Pavel Vladimirovich Vinogradov. Time to rev up the Soyuz, home tomorrow
Tonight's Finale: The Moon rising over a bed of cloud. A constant reminder to us all of what can be achieved.
Chris and Tom, helmet lights doing their best to light the universe on the dark side of the Earth.
Amazing day. EVA went off without a hitch. Great crew, phenomenal ground support and a supportive audience. Who could ask for anything more?
Approaching orbital sunset, the harshest of light, a blackness like endless velvet.
Here's looking at you. Chris and Tom take a minute with visors to look up-sun at my camera in the window.
Climbing out of the airlock, quite the commute to work!
Chris Cassidy, Navy SEAL and lead spacewalker today. The nicest iron man you'll ever meet.
Dr. Tom Marshburn, well-dressed for a day's work outdoors. Friend for life.
No leaks! We're bringing Tom & Chris back inside. In two days Tom, Roman & I return to Earth in our Soyuz. This is an amazing place & time.
Houston just sent the command to start flowing ammonia through the newly-installed pump. Gloved fingers crossed.
The reason they regularly check their gloves is for damage. Even though multi-layer, even a tiny leak requires immediate haste to airlock.
The spacewalking suit has pure oxygen at 4.2 psi - a trade-off between flexibility and crew health and fire risk. It is a workout to wear.
Do you hear how different their voices sound at the suit's low pressure? Turns out in the 4.2 psi oxygen you can't whistle - air's too thin.
Chris and Tom are safely outside ISS, hard at work in the vacuum of space, looking for signs of the ammonia leak. THAT was a busy AM inside.
KU satellites are back in range, and video is now streaming live from EVA helmet cams.
Depressurization complete, EVA underway now. Working in the vacuum of space, traveling at 17,500mph. Watch live here:
Watch and listen as and ground crew make final preparations for the EVA (scheduled for 8:15 ET):
Tom and Chris in the final stages of readying the suits and airlock for their spacewalk. A full day's prep.
Good Morning, Earth! A complex & vital day on Space Station, as Tom and Chris suit up and go outside to help fix the ammonia leak. Busy day!
Good Morning, Earth! A complex & vital day on Space Station, as Tom and Chris suit up and go outside to help fix the ammonia leak. Busy day!
Tonight's Finale: A springtime haze laps on the evening shore of the Alps. -- Big day tomorrow!
. Thank you, Claudia - I am up a bit late studying, just to help make sure that I do my part right. Goodnight soon from ISS.
Sunrise catches clouds in the act, mid-Atlantic.
Super-sensitive feet an advantage for astronauts? Find out in this 5th & final installment of our ‘Senses’ series:
A lone jet draws a straight line across the Tatras.
Tomorrow we send 2 crew out into the thermal vacuum wearing cloth-and-rubber pressure suits to repair ISS. Extra study of procedures tonight
Scotland and the Spring sunshine peeking at each other over the clouds.
What a fun day! This type of event is what the years of training were for. A happy, busy crew, working hard, loving life in space.
Nicosia (Lefkoşa) and the rugged north Cyprus coast.
Video: ammonia leak prompts preparations for possible spacewalk Saturday.
Athens, Greece, with the reflecting sun showing the wind on the water.
Audio: During Fri AM planning conf, says crew ready to serve for possible spacewalk.
Big storm swirling off the Irish coast on the 9th of May.
The whole team is ticking like clockwork, readying for tomorrow. I am so proud to be Commander of this crew. Such great, capable, fun people
Good Morning, Earth! Big change in plans, spacewalk tomorrow, Chris Cassidy and Tom Marshburn are getting suits and airlock ready. Cool!
The crew are awake and have begun preps for a potential EVA (spacewalk) to fix the ammonia leak. See more:
Tonight's Finale: A view to put the mind at ease.
On a lighter note: Science teachers were key to becoming an astronaut. Congrats to on their 50th anniversary! Go !
Audio: reports sighting evidence of ammonia leak to MCC Houston ~10:30am CT.
. At the analyzed rate, one of the Station's cooling loops could shut down within 48 hours. Read more here:
.Tomorrow we will know more clearly. At present, the crew is not at risk.
It is a serious situation, but between crew and experts on the ground, it appears to have been stabilized. Tomorrow we find out for certain.
Station's power relies on ammonia coolant. A few hours ago, we determined that the ammonia was leaking out of the Station and into space.
Chesapeake to Cape Cod to Lake Huron - in a glance, so much history, geology and geography.
Burnt steak and gunpowder in the airlock? describes how the sense of smell is hampered in :
Enroute to to speak with this evening. Teachers play such a critical role in society's future.
. I would be THRILLED to be the Stampede Parade Marshall! A great reason to come back to Earth!
San Francisco and California wine country - a favourite place on Earth.
oops, typo, thanks - I'll fix it. The days blend with 16 sunrises per :)

. Space suit, white hat, cowboy boots – I’ll be ready to ride anything that stays below 8km a second.
Moscow on 8 May 2013 - best wishes to all my friends on Victory Day! С праздником!
Cape Town, South Africa and the South Atlantic calling to forever.
Good Morning, Earth! Today on orbit we honour the Russian holiday of Victory Day. Gives time to think, catch-up, clean, and pack for travel.
Tonight's Finale: A long lens view of thunderstorms over the Amazon.
Strange how the slow flow of glacial ice becomes more visible from here, so far away.
Same land, different politics. The US - Mexican border, seen from space.
750,000 people are seeing the world from this perspective of the Space Station, via Twitter. It amazes me. Thanks to everyone.
Little farmers, big farmers and nature, in Turkey.
Little farmers, big farmers and nature, in Turkey.
In our latest 'Senses in ' video, shows us what he's been eating to stir his sense of :
Here I am singing with students from Lansdowne School in Sarnia City Hall. Sorry if I was a little flat.
. Calgary in July sounds lovely! Anything worth coming to see that time of year?
Budapest, river capital of Hungary, the surrounding hills newly alive with the green of Spring.
Did you add your voice to the million-strong chorus on ? Watch & students perform I.S.S.:
Mining town in northern China - the open pits gleam with blue from space.
Manila in the evening, her formidable port clearly visible from orbit.
. Yes, volcanoes are fascinating to see from above. I'll be looking for Popocatepetl when we pass over later today.
Yesterday was so cool: as we tested our Soyuz thrusters we could hear and feel them firing, and how they shook and flexed the whole Station.
. Spacewalk suits come in 3 sizes & have snap-in arm and leg length adjustments. It takes days to go outside, complex operation.
Good morning, Earth! Today will run a full cleaning cycle on the spacewalking suits' cooling plumbing. Several spacewalks planned for July.
Tonight's Finale: Moonset, one of 16 per day on ISS, all marvelous to see.
There's some great playoff hockey going on between these two Canadian cities. Do they take the train back and forth?
A small southern hemisphere cyclone spinning off the African coast.
Mississippi delta - heartland topsoil flowing relentlessly into the Gulf of Mexico.
. Spaceflight is that rare experience that outstrips even the highest of expectations. It's art, science and magic, all the time.
. My favourite thing to do in space is to fly! I can soar and float and tumble, Spiderman for real, like a super power :)
Looking north from our orbit to the forbidding rock and ice of Greenland.
Recruiting the next generation of space explorers for in Ingersoll, .
Good to know that after 5 months, my Sokhol pressure suit still fits. It's what we wear in the Soyuz. High fashion.
It's not easy putting on the Sokhol pressure suit - a tight squeeze. Like being born in reverse.
Good Morning, Earth! Roman and I are about to test the thrusters and motion control system of our Soyuz. Wake it up after 5 months.
Tonight's Finale: Our Sun is immensely, unfathomably powerful.
Even on the Space Station we have refrigerator art. Thanks Jordan!
Big and Little Ambergris Cay, on the blue edge of the abyss.
Bermuda is beautiful, both above and below the sea.
Santo Domingo, Dominican Rep., founded in 1496. Now 3 million of us live here - the largest city in the Caribbean.
Taipei, Taiwan - modern bustling city nestled on the Tamsui River between quiet volcanoes.
That was FUN! Thanks everyone for being a part of Music Monday. Sharing joyousness and art is a vital part of life, great to share frm here.
Every day this work week, will share a unique fact about the 5 senses in . Today it’s hearing:
Music Monday concert, coming up soon! Don't miss out:
Fier de voir la relève scientifique comme les BioGENEius Eunice Linh You & David Drouin partager leur savoir avec d'autres jeunes!
Dust blows from what was once the Aral Sea floor. Tragic mismanagement of a natural resource.
Last week to submit your pics to our Chris Hadfield World Tour Photo Challenge! It ends when lands!
Maputo, capital of Mozambique, home to 2 million of us living in this African port city on the Indian ocean.
. Nice guitar pick! That's the same one I'm using onboard ISS. Very handy mission emblem :)
Good morning, Earth! Today is Soyuz spaceship re-entry practice, Sokhol suit pressure checks, spinal ultrasound, and Music Monday. Full day!
Tonight's Finale: Huron, Erie and Ontario - Great Lakes in Spring flow.
There are over 600,000 students all singing together live with me tomorrow - amazing!
There are over 600,000 students all singing together live with me tomorrow - amazing!
The highlands of Cape Breton still wear the winter's snow, sun highlighting the connecting waters.
Watershed Study - how the springtime water flows around Lake Ontario on the Canada-US border.
Gaspe like a giant beast, sloughing off the last of the winter's snow.
I'm always looking to see a whale, here at Tadoussac where the Saguenay pours into the St Lawrence. None yet.
A view over central Mexico - just in time for Cinco de Mayo.
. that's a worldwide connection that is really delightful to hear. Thanks for letting me know!
Tartus and Latakia, on the Syrian coast. Why do the cities seem to use different light bulbs, I wonder?
. the medical tests start minutes after landing & last for months. Also technical debriefs, physical rehab & public events. Busy!
. there are 10s of thousands of photos I haven't yet sorted/posted, plus the process of becoming Earthling again. Much 2 see.
New crew coming: once we're safely back on Earth, & will launch for ISS. Much to Tweet about from both places!
. Yes, I stayed up very late and watched the game. Great to see them play so well! All alone & weightless, I cheered and smiled :)
Good Sunday morning, Earth - happy Cinco de Mayo! Gearing up for our last work week in space, all aboard the orbital research vessel ISS.
Tonight's Finale: Toronto. Go Leafs Go!
. I've been wearing the blue and white all day. NASA is streaming the game up to me in orbit now. Go Leafs!
Minneapolis and Saint Paul, MN. Home of the classic American radio show, A Prairie Home Companion.
Plymouth, England. Ancient human settlement - who'd have thought it would become the brand name for an automobile?
The southern UK, as-seen from the ISS.
There is no try - only do. May the 4th be with you.
And the answer is... Leeds, Bradford and the surrounding towns of West Yorkshire. Congrats to those who got it right!
And the answer is... Leeds, Bradford and the surrounding towns of West Yorkshire. Congrats to those who got it right!
North central England in April. A web of roads, railways and light. Do you recognize the cities?
I've recorded and uploaded a half-dozen or so new sounds from everyday Station life. Noisy place!
Makkah (مكة), spiritual home to over a billion of us.
@thamer_alsubaie Thank you, Thamer. We will do our best.

If you've ever walked across a cow pasture, you'll recognize these. Except they're rock outcroppings in Africa.
The Earth bubbled and spat like boiling porridge, long ago in Saudi Arabia.
Thanks for all the questions and the artwork, ! My favorite planet is Earth. Let's sing together on Monday!
Just had a very fun conversation with students at Diamond Jenness in Hay River Canada via ham radio. Good questions, nice on a Friday night!
Syria, from a different perspective.
Music Monday soon - I'll be practicing this weekend. Fill the skies w/music!

this is Oleshky sands near Kherson , Ukraine -

has fun at work with the O2 mask used in emergencies. Spoiler: he sings!
Astronaut G-Suit - squeezes blood out of my legs and abdomen up into my head, where I need it. Fashionable, too!

. Thanks! Good perspective. We're the fastest humans alive, but light blows past us like we're standing still :)

Shadow play of cloud and mountain at sunset.
. we can manually fly the Soyuz through the atmosphere to repatedly land it within a 5 km circle. Part of our qual for spaceflight

to Sing With Students Live From Space in a Coast-to-Coast Concert for Music Monday:
Good morning, Earth! G-suit fit checks today, another step to be ready to return to Earth. See how skinny my calves are after 5 month float.
Tonight's Finale: Overhead of Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic, floating above our glowing blue sphere.
. Pam - there's a ukulele onboard ISS. I need to play it some before I return home. And - thanks for the letters.
While the Newfoundland ice formed a heraldic dragon, these Pacific clouds look more like Woodstock, of Peanuts fame.
While the Newfoundland ice formed a heraldic dragon, these Pacific clouds look more like Woodstock, of Peanuts fame.
A heraldic Spring dragon of ice roars rampant off the coast of Newfoundland.
Philadelphia in exquisite detail. Counting the bridges from space.
Last week my daughter talked to the kids at Sacred Heart in Roscrea, Ireland. Fine batch of young astronauts!
It turns out that onions DO make you cry in space, too. Just here, tears don't fall.
How do you control the , a ship the size of 5 hockey rinks? explains in this vid:
Tricorder? Our sound level meter has a very Space Age look.
Space Onion - came up on the Progress resupply spaceship. We sliced it up and had it with everything - nice flavor!
Good Morning, Earth! We undock for our fiery fall back to Earth on 13 May. So many things left to do! And enjoying each one of them.
Tonight's Finale: The Moon ushering in the dawn over the Southeastern United States.
I've been wearing my Leafs shirt here on the Space Station all day - good luck and play well in the game tonight. Go !
A sea turtle and I swam along this Maui beach together one evening for 20 minutes - special to see it from here.
. Astronauts, the Canadian Space Agency and the Bank of Canada plan ahead :)
Over 330,000 participants already registered for Music Monday! Join in the celebration May 6th
Hamburg, Germany - with positive wishes to Stefanie Bierholz on her mid-Spring birthday.
I think Brianna will be a fine astronaut. The Right Stuff, in miniature.
It's Hamburg, taken from NNE, looking SSW.
The photo was taken above (Northern) Central Europe, but I can't recognize the city. Can anyone identify it for me?
The humanoid form of Robonaut is a little spooky onboard, at times.
The humanoid form of Robonaut is a little spooky onboard, at times.
. I have noticed that time sure flies at 8 km/sec! Just hanging on to the spaceship's tail by the skin of my teeth, & loving it.
Thanks for all the questions this morning! Here are answers, put together by my co-workers at the Cdn Space Agency:
Good morning, Earth! Yesterday was surreal - a spacewalker on the new $5 & a little guitar w/Neil Young. Time to focus & get back to work!
Tonight's Finale: Dubai, the Palm Island like a trilobite in the night.
An astronaut's perspective on the Canadian Maritimes.
Talked with Neil Young tonight, he in his hybrid 1959 Lincoln, my in a spaceship. Discussed Earth ecology & writing music. A heart of gold.
The yin and yang of ice and land at Lake of the Woods.
Do you see what I see?
Have you seen what's on Canada’s new $5 bank note? Just announced it today with from orbit.
The Greek islands, like delicate shattered eggshell pieces.
Is THAT what that is? I was thinking asteroid impact :)
It seems apropos that the COLBERT treadmill (named after ) sounds a little funny:
The flag of Cyprus shining in the sun on what must have been an absolutely beautiful day.
The Sea of Marmara, Turkey. Macro scale water flow visualization.
A very happy and healthy Queen's Day to all the Dutch on the last celebration before her abdication.
My astronaut classmate musician Cady Coleman wrote a nice article on ISS life and music:
Good morning, Earth! Big health science research day - Microflow cytometer tests & spinal ultrasounds. But first, morning blood draws. Ouch.
Tonight's Finale: The Galapagos - just far enough apart to give Darwin something to think about.
Tonight's Finale: The Galapagos - just far enough apart to give Darwin something to think about.
Nova Scotia and her surrounding waters, the land showing the first green of Spring.
Orbit highlights modern terraforming. Visible here is the cutting down of forest for farmland in the upper Amazon.
Melanoma pit mine on the farms and forest.

Bullet hole - a small stone from the universe went through our solar array. Glad it missed the hull.

Enormous grassland fires in Siberia/Mongolia this morning.
Good morning, Earth! One week until Music Monday - looking forward to it!

Progress robot resupply spaceship, coming up to dock with Station on Friday.
Lines on the Earth, natural and human-made, in south-central Africa.
. Thanks Rachel! I'm glad you like the videos and pictures. I hope they help you to better understand the World & our place in it
Ancient Saharan stone, burnished by eternal sand and wind.
Good Morning, World. Sunday off the planet, Mission Control gave us a long list of Honey-Do's. Many hands make weightless work.

From Haifa to Alexandria, a huge curve of history in one glance.
The Holy Land of Jerusalem clearly visible between Tel Aviv and Amman.

Sorry for the slow Tweeting today, we've had computer server troubles, but the fine folks at NASA JSC Houston just got it fixed!
Beijing just after sunset. I'm still trying to spot the Great Wall, but it's hard as it's narrow and dun-colored.
Port Moresby, capital of Papua New Guinea. I need to learn more about this part of our world.

I don't know what the people are doing here, but I sure like how it looks from space.
Southern UK and (after much discussion) Pas de Calais. The lights act like a census.
lifts the cover on the Water Recovery System to show us how a vital resource is preserved on the :

This river's about to take a short cut.
. My favourite hockey player of all time is Wayne Gretzky. His talent, passion and commitment set a new standard for the game.

Tonight's Finale: A Dali watch on an alligator wristband - Mexico.
The beautiful and violent ugliness inside a naked volcano. Chad, Africa.
The Nature of Things is highly respected: Please let me know what you think of the show - I won't see it until later.
. You're welcome! I was living in Maracaibo while it was being built. Doubly amazing to see it from orbit now.
Maracaibo, Venezuela - the 50-year-old bridge clearly visible from space.
Cape Town, South Africa, the glinting sun highlighting the water.
Lake Balaton, Hungary. A lovely vacation destination on the water with spring's new growth visible all around.
If you fly in space, this a great group to be with, surrounded by talent: Pavel, Tom, Chris, Roman & Alexander.
Space Plumber - replacing a low-temp cooling valve in the Columbus Lab. Note my hi-tech tools.
. We're all trained as Med Techs, worked in Emer in a hospital. If it were really serious, 3 would come home in via Soyuz.
I just shaved sinkless and took a weightless sponge bath - I am really looking forward to my first hot shower in 5 months!
Good Morning, Earth! Looking forward to a ham radio discussion with high school students in Rankin Inlet, Nunavut (on Hudson Bay) this aft.

The effortless natural art of the southern Sahara.

There may never be a clearer picture of the Isle of Wight from space.
Stonehenge is in this picture if you know where to look. The bend in the river at Amesbury helped me find it.
Plymouth, England, port at the mouths of two rivers, on the edge of Dartmoor National Park.
Swansea, Wales. A natural place for people to settle and live, from pre-history to the Vikings to today.
The mouth of the Thames - you can see where much of England's topsoil eventually goes.
. To get back to sleep I floated and reviewed ISS systems in my head, all possible causes & effects, until I was sure we were OK.
Just saw this article, and immediately tried to remember where I parked my car before I left Earth. .
Good Morning, Earth! An alarm rang in the night, ventilation failure in Service Module, an unexplained transient. Glad to sleep in a bit.
Tonight's Finale: Canadarm2 blushing with the dawn.
Cuba, the Bahamas, Florida, the Universe.
Cuba, the Bahamas, Florida, the Universe.
The Florida Keys look especially vulnerable from orbit.
South Florida from Earth orbit. Can you recognize the cities?
Texas coast - can you see where the shrimp boat has been?
. Donal, I will do my best to describe this experience with all the senses.
. la Lune semble plus petit du fait de l'objectif de la caméra que j'ai utilisé.
. There is solar wind, a steady flow of tiny particles and energy from the Sun, but you'd need an enormous sail to catch it.
While looking for the approaching Soyuz, I caught a glimpse of another orbiting body in the distance.
. the docking mechanism has big internal springs and shock absorbers to dampen the impact. Station uses massive reaction wheels.
. Launch-to-docking profiles are a tradeoff of risk & complexity & reserve for contingencies. We're still learning what's best.
Good Morning, Canmore. How's the Spring skiing?
. Space Station smells clean and controlled, like living in a laboratory. In fact it IS living in a laboratory :)
We dock at 0.1 m/s, +/- .05, and with tight offset and angular tolerances.
. Yes, at the moment of docking Tom & I had our hands on the docking port. Could feel the massive thud, like 2 train cars linking.
Space Sounds - This is what it sounds like when Soyuz docks with the Station:
Inside the Cupola, just at orbital sunset, Earth already dark. From here we photograph the world.
Good morning, Earth! We've been up all night, getting the Soyuz safed and crew settled in. A long, great day. Six of us now here, together.
They're docked! I was right at the hatch, heard/felt the metal sliding, heavy thump, then Soyuz pulling to check latched. So very cool.
Tonight's Finale: Soyuz Rocket Launch - the moment of ignition, as-seen from their target, the Space Station.
The Nazca lines seem to show that the less we understand about history, the greater our propensity towards mythology.
The Nazca lines seem to show that the less we understand about history, the greater our propensity towards mythology.
Space Exercise Video - how to avoid bone & muscle loss when weightless. And maybe dance a little:
This Bolivian lake looks to me like a dinosaur's jaws. What do you see?
Just watched the Soyuz launch! The rocket's red glare, powering up away from the Earth, turning towards us in hot pursuit. Incredible to see
Resistencia and Corrientes, on opposing banks of the Parana River, Argentina.
A Brazilian river, perpetually kissing the Atlantic.
Ships waiting their turn at the Panama Canal's western mouth. One amazing feat of engineering viewed from another.

tweet.tweet_content: . All water, even from your tap, is recycled urine. Dinosaurs were big, and here for a long time. Just need a good purifier.
Glamorous job - next task is to replace the urine receptacle hose & funnel. Gloves and mask on. But our new crewmates will appreciate it :)
Guanaja: An island shaped like a conch shell. Perfect!
Good Morning, Earth! A long & big day ahead as 3 friends launch in their Soyuz rocket from Baikonur to dock with us ~03:00. Godspeed!
Tonight's Finale: The Moon rose on the horizon just before we released Dragon to fall to Earth.
Like the sand came crashing over the shore of rock.
Does anyone know what this is in the Egyptian desert?
Fuzhou, China, major port city on the Min River - over 4 million of us live in the city proper.
I sang with these kids on Earth and now will from orbit w/ . Watch live at 3:30 ET:
Delhi, India. So many people, their lights shining in the night up into space.
Lahore, Pakistan it is! Good eye to all those who found it. A region where I'm still rusty on my geography. Orbit makes for good practice!
On the Rajasthan border of India and Pakistan - a city with a very distinctive circle. Does anyone recognize it?
On the Rajasthan border of India and Pakistan - a city with a very distinctive circle. Does anyone recognize it?
A shoreline mimicking cresting waves near Stokes National Park in Western Australia.
Geelong, Australia, and the beautifully-named Stingaree Bay.
Good Morning, Earth! A Wednesday of computer install/reload, exercise eqpt maint, plus a concert with school choirs:
Tonight's Finale: Cubist farming in Brazil.
I saw a angel :)
I'm not sure what it is, but I think it enjoys wallowing in this lake.
This Young Man is pushing the snow ball over the edge..
How's this? (hint) you don't want to land here if you're a Jedi walking the plank
I'm sorry Chris, I'm afraid I can't do that.
If you look closely you can see...
I used the free GNU Image Manipulation Program (GIMP) for mine.
I put a commander style moustache on it
how's this?
This Mexican lake is an empty canvas for anyone with PhotoShop skills. Give it a face and I'll retweet my favourites!
Those are some absurdly geometric Brazilian farms.
Hello to Ms Walsh’s Gr 7 class at Chris Hadfield Public School. Thanks for making science and Tomatosphere part of what you're learning!
Tom, Roman and I in the mouth of the Dragon spaceship. These are two superb men to be off the Earth with.
600000 seeds = an infinite number of future scientists & engineers. Congrats Tomatosphere on ’s Science Award!
Just now got word that the Dragon we released from Station this morning is safely home and on the ship off of California. Congrats SpaceX!
Just now got word that the Dragon we released from Station this morning is safely home and on the ship off of California. Congrats SpaceX!
A squiggly little river feeds the mighty Amazon.
An island like splatter, South America.
. We had to get up 3 hrs early to get everything done to release Dragon on-time, so it lands in the right place, near the boats.
Perth on the Swan to the sea, Western Australia.
. For a short while after we release the Dragon spaceship it just falls, but then it is actively controlled right through landing
Good Morning, Earth! Fly little Dragon, fly, safely home again ro a soft landing in the Pacific. We release it from Canadarm in 6 hours.
Tonight's Finale: The Richat Structure. A giant gazing eye upon the Earth.
Mt Etna, pouring heat and steam and smoke up through the snowcap. Earth never ceases to amaze.
An angry thunderstorm stands out against infinity.
Oil drilling draws a circuit board on the ochre landscape.
Cloud over western Europe, rippled like water over a stone.
Best wishes to those of you celebrating the beginning of Passover, from the unique position of seeing all peoples of the world, every day.
Pacific clouds doing a Matrix impersonation.
Sydney, Australia, glowing green and lovely in the night.
. During launch the rocket gets Dragon above the air, and then accelerates it. During Re-entry the air decelerates it, causing heat.
Adelaide, capital of South Australia, from space. The square of downtown parks really stands out.
In case there's confusion - this is the Dragon robot cargo spaceship we're sending home tomorrow: . It's nearly full!
Good Morning, Earth! Up early, sleep-shifting for final packing in Dragon, early morning release tomorrow. Fiery splashdown into the Pacific
Good Morning, Earth! Up early, sleep-shifting for final packing in Dragon, early morning release tomorrow. Fiery splashdown into the Pacific
Mexico City, one of the largest metropolitan areas on Earth - housing roughly the same population as Australia.
Pacific cloud snuggling up to Mexican rock.
Sunglint catches the irrigation canals of these Mexican farmers.
Bugs in Space! Here's how I tested the Space Station for microbes and mushrooms and mould:
Monterrey, Mexico by night. The heights of the Cerro de la Silla give the city a breathtaking backdrop.
From orbit you see water in a whole new light. Pacific swirl off a Mexican promontory.
Guadalajara, Mexico. A densely populated collection of humanity, packed with culture and historic architecture.
Mexicali and Calexico, with the Mexico/US border very distinct.
Time to wash up: small bag of hot water, bit of soap, washcloth, waterless shampoo, dab shaving cream, razor, towel, swallow the toothpaste.
. One of my best friends, Russ, was a fireman in Ann Arbor, and gave me that shirt. I gave him an astronaut shirt in return :)
. The best part has been getting to know our World better.
. You're welcome, Mia. I didn't even know they were filming that day! It was just my answer to the most common astronaut question.
Being in orbit makes me feel the same way, Patty :)
