tweet.tweet_content: Rugged, wicked badlands of central Mexico.
. I opened a can of soda pop when I lived on the ocean floor. Here's what happened:
Auckland. Holding a third of New Zealand's population, it radiates like a beacon between the harbours.
. Playing guitar in space: . It sounds the same, just hard to fret bar chords on a floating guitar.
What are you curious about? The Cdn Space Agency took your most frequent Twitter questions & answered them here:
. The best thing about being weightless is the ability to magically, effortlessly fly. It's like having a superpower.
. The best thing about being weightless is the ability to magically, effortlessly fly. It's like having a superpower.
.@an0n_egg This is how we get rid of waste on the Space Station:
. The gentle earthlights twinkle, the bright ones are clear. We see whatever is pointed upwards plus the reflected glow of the rest.
.@PeteLaberge Food on Space Station is mostly instant, thermostabilized or irradiated. My coffee is Kona, black, in a bag through a straw.
Good Morning, Earth! Big week ahead: Dragon spaceship release, Soyuz w/3 new cremembers arrival. A Sunday to get the place ready. Coffee 1st
Tonight's Finale: Dawn sneaking in under the Northern Lights. When we turn our lights down, nature lights up the sky.
Christchurch, NZ, taken just after Earth Hour ended. The perfect grid system of the downtown core is clearly visible.
Baltimore, Maryland, bright and clear. The major landmarks of the city all shining up through the night.
San Francisco and the whole Bay Area. Taken at an angle, it is easy to see the entire layout of the bay by night.
Las Vegas, with the Strip distinctly standing out from the rest of the city, even from orbit.
Detroit and Windsor, where Michigan meets Ontario. Spiderwebs of light expanding out from the dark river border.
Chicago, a bright spot on the tip of Lake Michigan, glowing through the clouds.
New York City, lit up like a bulb. The Statue of Liberty is clearly visible in the night from above.
Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, with the lights of the city piercing through the clouds.
Boston, Massachusetts. Everyone down there prepared to shine a little less brightly for an hour?
Feet hooked into toe loops hold our bodies steady for delicate work. It can be tough to stay still when floating.
. Yes, we'll turn the ISS lights off tonight. Like a cloaking device :)
As it turns out, orbital mechanics don't support seeing lights out efforts. But a richness of "before" night photos coming for inspiration.
Good Morning, Earth! I'll try and photograph people's efforts during Eartrh Hour today. It's our planet, let's each help a bit.
Tonight's Finale: A gyre frozen into the ice, Newfoundland, Canada.
Tonight's Finale: A gyre frozen into the ice, Newfoundland, Canada.
Charlottetown locked in the cold of winter, Confederation Bridge just barely visible from orbit.
Richmond, capital of the Commonwealth of Virginia. A vital crossroads for so much American history.
The world-record tides of the Bay of Fundy sure do churn up the Annapolis Valley mud.
Washington, DC, waiting for the green of Spring. Andrews Air Force Base visible at lower left.
Halifax, a wonderful natural harbour and a great place for music.
Finger Lakes, New York. Glaciers clawed them into the earth as they retreated during the last Ice Age.
Cape Breton. Every Canadian should walk the Cabot Trail. Rugged, beautiful bedrock of our country.
. 0 G affects convection & we need forced air & water for atmosphere, which all make noise. Need to establish good spaceship design
As I'm reading your Tweets I'm doing my hearing test, beeps with inner and outer headphones. I can still hear OK, and multi-task too :)
- And here's a photo of the phenomenon:
. In weightlessness we use our socked feet like apes do, to hold and stabilize. We only wear shoes for exercise - 2 hrs/day.
Astronaut wardrobe malfunction. Perhaps I'm taking the "wear your clothes until they wear out" thing a little too far
. Birthday candles don't burn well here, where heat doesn't rise. Uses up local oxygen & the flame looks like a small blue ball.
. Seeing our Earth from here makes me feel incredibly lucky, & obliged to do what I can to reflect it back to everyone.
Good Morning, Earth! It's birthday week for the Hadfield family: Happy Birthday to my baby sister & brother Pat & Flip, and also to my Dad!
Tonight's Finale: Germany, the Rhine from Bonn to Koln, spanning from the Cathedral to the European Astronaut Centre.
Düsseldorf, Germany, where the Düssel flows into the winding Rhine.
Koblenz, Germany, where the Mosel flows in to the Rhine. A key location, settled for over 2000 years.
If you are looking for a quick way to search through my past posts, you can find them all collected here:
If you are looking for a quick way to search through my past posts, you can find them all collected here:
done
A thought - maybe some of these pictures would be useful on Wikipedia to show how places really look. Please add to Wiki pages if they help.
Looking to the north to Hannover, Germany, a major hub of road and rail. Famous for its old town and zoo.
Remember that photo of Cork on St. Patrick's Day? Well I've added labels:
. No staplers allowed on Space Station. Small, sharp floating pieces of metal are bad for eyes, lungs and electricity.
Berlin. A great city, undivided. I went through Checkpoint Charlie in 1977, a very strong and serious memory.
. That cartoon you drew made me laugh here in orbit, Patrick. Your wife was right, everybody knows Flin Flon.
Bonn, capital of pre-unification West Germany, neatly clear in the March snow along the dark waters of the Rhine.
Köln (Cologne), Germany. The old city street patterns fanning from the Rhine, visible from space.
. things burn up in the atmosphere because of friction w/the air. We're going 8 km/sec. Imagine sticking your hand out the window.
. Ich spreche ein wenig - ich studierte Deutsch in der Schule. Aber alles vergessen.
Liebes Deutschland! Die Fotos sind heute für Sie. Wiesbaden & Mainz, straddling the dark Rhine white snow and cloud.
. We put all our trash into the unmanned resupply vehicles, like Progress, & they burn up into dust on re-entry. Shooting stars.
. there are no bugs or even insects on ISS, so we never catch a cold or flu. It's the ultimate quarantine.
. on Station we wear our clothes until they're worn out or filthy, & then throw them away. Clothes washers use too much water.
Houston, we have a PJoblem.
Space Pajamas: Russian-made and stylish, 2-tone blue with white socks. What all the astronauts are wearing this year.
. They're Russian pajamas. I think it's time to break out a new pair.They come pre-packaged with thick white socks. Very chic.
. Duct tape - excellent suggestion! Either that or check the Inventory Management System for needle & thread onboard.
. Duct tape - excellent suggestion! Either that or check the Inventory Management System for needle & thread onboard.
Good Morning Earth! The waist elastic in my PJ bottoms broke! Fortunately, in weightlessness they don't fall down. A spaceflight advantage.
Tonight's Finale: The Nile and the Sinai, to Israel and beyond. One sweeping glance of human history.
Some of the things we build for ourselves are puzzlingly visible from space. Such as the islands of Dubai.
Latakia (and Tartus), where Syria meets the Mediterranean. Serving as an important port city for thousands of years.
Shiraz, Iran - A city of culture and technology. The colourful roof choices complement the landscape well.
Tripoli, Lebanon. An important coastal city for thousands of years. Not to be confused with the Libyan capital.
I was a Cub Scout in Milton, Ontario. We met at the fairgrounds. I worked hard to earn badges :)
In-between my run and resistance exercise, short break, been watching a replay of the Leafs playing the Jets. Don't tell me who won!
I took a stroll on the old long walk of a day eye ay eye ay! I've sung that song many, many times :)
On today's episode of Cooking in Space, we're showing you why you should always water your vegetables:
Baghdad, Iraq. Gigantic capital along the Tigris. Once the largest city on Earth, millions of us call this city home.
Just had a fast lunch & then spoke w/ students at Ann Richards School in Austin TX. Excellent, thoughtful questions, good young women.
Homs, Syria. Currently enveloped in fighting - an uncertain future layered upon a storied past.
Happy Nowruz (New Year) to Persians all over the globe. Here's a view of Qods and the outskirts of Tehran from orbit.
Just spent 10 minutes via Ham radio with excited, confident, well-prepared students in S Australia. Great to hear the young voices!
. Happy Equinox! Today the sun beats down exactly on the equator, shifting northward. Watching the seasons change from space.
Good Morning, Earth! Today: install the Amine Swingbed - a new CO2 removal system. First, talk with Adelaide S Aus students via ham radio.
Tonight's Finale: Storm clouds standing tall in the atmosphere over Africa.
Tonight's Finale: Storm clouds standing tall in the atmosphere over Africa.
Airport, beach, coral, sunshine. A little bit of Cayman paradise.
Paris sous le soleil. Les ombres de l'Arc de Triomphe et la Tour Eiffel sont a peine visible.
To my Saudi followers: If I were to visit somewhere in the kingdom, where would you suggest? I'd be interested to see it from the ground.
Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. 3 million people on the Red Sea. You can see the road that leads to Mecca.
I hope these two Saudi farmers are good neighbours.
Venice, Italy - the red roofs and white docks of the famed island city are visible from orbit.
The Province of Syracuse at the very Southern tip of Sicily. A lovely view of Italy on the Festa del Papà.
. Thanks for letting me know that. I recorded Danny Boy because I love it. My great-grandad used to sing it.
Taking pictures of the Outback from space is like unearthing ancient cave paintings.
. Hide-and-Seek would be great on ISS! Without gravity you can get into very unusual places. Just don't suffocate (said the CDR).
. Inside we hold +23 C for comfort and equipment cooling. Outside it's +120 in the sun, -150 or colder in the shade. Wicked.
. Mark, I just checked, pressure inside Station is 734 mmHg/14.2 psi, just a bit below sea level pressure. We hold it there.
Good Morning, Earth! Weather this morning on Space Station - 23 deg (73 F), low humidity, calm, clear skies. And weightless.
Tonight's Finale: Our Moon, forever to be graced by the footprints of twelve brave men.
It is a volcanic lake, not much about it online! Google Maps: It is very beautiful!
What is this little perfect round hole in Africa? Likely in Ethiopia near 7.99N, 37.19E.
Pretoria, South Africa, visibly between the Highveld and the Bushveld.
This cave painting is, in fact, raw geology in central South Africa.
The Earth's fault lines are especially visible from orbit, like this one in South Africa.
The Earth's fault lines are especially visible from orbit, like this one in South Africa.
Intensive agriculture in a forbidding place, southern Africa. Like terraforming.
Setting up the camera & mic onboard for a live news conference, my 1st as Station Commander. Webcast here in 30 min:
Robonaut flexing. It will be even more interesting when his legs are installed.
. much of the Soyuz internal equipment is re-used for multiple flights, but the hull itself is not. The heat is too intense.
Inside a Spaceship. Through that far silver hatch you can just see into the Soyuz, our ride home.
. Hello Evan & Ryan & hi to all in Bracebridge. Thanks for getting up early. We're busy doing experiments today, but I waved:)
. I am a fundamental believer in the fact that we need both science & art to survive & thrive as a species. It is our nature.
. Where does Station water come from? We collect humidity and urine, purify it, heat it, dispense into instant tea bag - tea time!
. Today's Astronaut Breakfast: powdered orange juice, Cheerios w/powdered milk, Saskatchewan jerky, instant black Kona coffee
Good Morning, Earth! Monday on Space Station w/ a full week planned, the start of Expedition 35. Many experiments running & a Dragon to pack
St. Patrick's Day Finale: Dublin, with her port standing out clearly to photographers in Earth orbit.
Belfast, Northern Ireland, with visibly green countryside signaling the onset of spring.
Drogheda, Ireland, with surrounding counties Louth and Meath obscured by cloud.
Cork, Ireland, just visible at the edge of cloud on the coast.
Galway, Ireland, in the afternoon sun.
Donegal, one of the many famous places I've only seen from space.
Derry, Northern Ireland, and the rugged coast facing the North Atlantic.
Danny Boy strikes home with me, now more than ever. I've recorded a version for today in orbit. Hope you like it!
Tralee, Ireland, nestled in the first green we see after soaring across the Atlantic.
Tralee, Ireland, nestled in the first green we see after soaring across the Atlantic.
Wearing the green - Happy St. Patrick's Day from the International Space Station!
. to know when to look up and watch the Station fly over: or
You can see Station pass just south of Ireland in 10 minutes - might be worth stepping outside for a quick early morning look.
. On the Space Station we live on Dublin time :) aka Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). Perfect for St Paddy's Day.
Maidin mhaith from the International Space Station! Happy Saint Patrick's Day to the Irish all around the globe. Good morning!
Tonight's Finale: Mexican volcano with airliner contrail for artistic emphasis.
Volcanoes iced with snow - just Southeast of the Black Sea (in Armenia or the surrounding area).
The Mexican Colima volcano having a quiet smoke. Quiet is good.
Cardiff, capital of Wales, home to Millennium Stadium (where I hear an intense rugby match has been played today).
The ash from Mount Vesuvius makes this fine farmland, until next time.
When Mt St Helens exploded I was living in Victoria, BC, Canada, and heard it from there.
Peekaboo volcano.
Soyuz departing - Oleg, Kev & Evgeni passing underneath Space Station on their way home after 5 months.
Tasks for the weekend: melt tin and lead for crystallization research, computer shell swap, prepare rooms for the crew that arrives 29 Mar.
Normally they're round. A square volcano in Turkey.
Good Morning, Earth! Best wishes from a weekend on the orbital research vessel ISS. Slept in, time for breakfast.First - a bag of coffee.
Just saw video of our 3 crewmates getting out of their Soyuz, safely back on Earth. A long, good day. Good night, World - sleep in tomorrow!
Tonight's Finale: From Ontario to Superior, the Great Lakes in mid-March, as-seen from Earth orbit.
Calgary in the snows of early March. Time for a warm wind from the Rockies?
Calgary in the snows of early March. Time for a warm wind from the Rockies?
We're turning Station like a huge pinwheelto be pointed the right way for Oleg, Kev & Evgeni's Soyuz to pop off the right direction in 1 hr.
Edmonton, like all of the North, awaits the arrival of Spring.
Just closed the hatch on the departing crew. The echo rang through the Station in many ways; we are now 3 onboard this huge ship. So cool.
Avec et après un échange avec . Excellentes questions des élèves!
From Forest to The Pinery on the icy sweep of the Huron shore.
All the Ottawa-area kids who attended today's event.
Milton, Ontario, where I grew up. Looking closely I can see my parents' farm - and Chris Hadfield Public School!
. The Space Station doesn't corner all that well, but it's really good on the straightaway :)
Erie on the left, Ontario on the right, Niagara Falls in the middle. I love this perspective shot.
Spaceship command. A huge personal and professional moment for me, nicely captured in a photograph.
My Dad took me to the Canada Aviation & Space Museum when I was a kid. Amazing that today he will be there as I link-in from Earth orbit.
Cold Lake, Alberta, deep and aptly named. Son Evan was born at the RCAF CF-18 training base visible at lower left.
. I am looking forward to St. Patrick's Day, and can see the whole diaspora from here - have some space surprises planned.
I am honoured to speak with my nation's Prime Minister and his wife today. My parents and friends will be there too.
Thanks Hannah, that's really nice to read up here. My best from ISS
Good Morning to Southern Ontario - we're about to fly over! Can you see us?
Inside the Cupola in the shadow of the Earth, our nighttime. Very cool photo by Kevin Ford.
. Bonjoiur, petit Ugo. I am doing my best to add a rung or 2 to that ladder for him, and for all that follow.
. Space Station is designed for a crew of 6 and to power 4 big laboratories. Limits are power, air/water purification, resupply.
. Space Station is designed for a crew of 6 and to power 4 big laboratories. Limits are power, air/water purification, resupply.
It is fascinating to be in orbit in mid-March, as we watch the world's seasons change. Winter/Summer swapping ends of the Earth.
. Bill, you are the best Soyuz photographer ever! Hopefully the day's delay will give you better conditions for landing photos
They were within about 20 minutes of getting into their Soyuz and closing the hatch when the Ground Rescue Forces decided. Try, try again.
Good Morning, Earth! We had house guests last night - departing crew was delayed for terrible weather in Kazakhstan. Retry undock tonight.
Tonight's Finale: Happy Pi Day! The iconic Manicouagan meteor crater has a diameter of 300 km. What's its area?
Crazed patchwork of farms in Central Asia, a monochromatic 3D hallucination in the snow.
Soyuz with Expedition 34 crew delays landing until tomorrow due to bad weather at landing site in Kazakhstan. Now Friday night 10:06 CDT
Warsaw, capital of Poland, split by the Vistula River as it flows to the Baltic.
This Chilean rock looks like it's still wet.
People often ask for photos of the big storm over them. I don't normally, because this is how they look from space :)
. I've tried to take a good video of sunrise in orbit, but the light change is so huge and rapid that the image gets blown out.
The dry folded skin of the Sahara desert, looking like the crust of a pie. Perfect for Pi Day!
. Oui, quand vous fermez les yeux dans l'espace, parfois vous pouvez voir des éclairs de lumière du rayonnement cosmique.
. In case of a solar flare we hide in the heaviest-shielded sections of ISS. We measure radiation many ways
. The windows on the Space Station have protective coatings, or we'd be burned by the Sun's radiation in seconds.
Sunrise in the Cupola. With no atmosphere to filter and diffuse the light, our star is incredibly harsh.
The International Space Station streaked over your head at 17,250 MPH this morning. Wave to and crew!
. Thanks James - an amazing time when you can look up, watch a man-made star fly over, & then chat with the people inside. I like it.
The key is to make every day a personal success:
The key is to make every day a personal success:
Time for breakfast - instant oj, Cheerios w/powdered milk, dried fruit, instant coffee - black.
. The big difference of being in command is that now all final decisions are solely mine - right, wrong, life, death.
. Our sleep berths on Station are just slightly bigger than the cryogenic sleep pods imagined in most science fiction movies.
. Waking up as a Space Station commander, I feel both daunted and ready. I like the combination, keeps me keenly aware.
. Without gravity pushing down on tongue, throat and sinuses we don't snore in space. Then again, we sleep in soundproof berths.
.@helenpforrest The sound of rain - I have a recording to be able to hear that in orbit. On ISS it is always 23 deg with clear skies :)
Here are some answers to your most frequently-asked questions, compiled by the Cdn Space Agency:
Thanks everyone on Twitter! I've received a world of congratulations on newly commanding this spaceship. Very big moment in my life.
. Space sunrises are FAST. We race around into the light, horizon glows light blue, then rainbow, & bursts with the red-orange Sun.
Good Morning, Earth! We're shift workers, trying to sleep late to be rested for the outgoing crew's undock at midnight tonight. I'm awake.
Tonight's Finale: Be proud of our achievements, but don't stop there. We're heading towards the future, not the past.
Some thoughts from Space Station on how to mould yourself into the individual you wish to become:
The Isle of Wight looks like a jigsaw piece that needs to be moved up and in.
Statement by , first Canadian Commander of the International Space Station:
Today's transfer of command ceremony can be viewed live online here:
Rome, the Vatican, and the surrounding hills. I'm not certain you can make out the new pope from here, though.
Time to start waving, Vivere :) Best from ISS.

tweet.tweet_content: Folkestone and Dover. Both the White Cliffs and the ferryboat tracks are visible from space.
Thank you, Stephen! From a middling busy day on Space Station. Very much appreciated.
Thank you, Stephen! From a middling busy day on Space Station. Very much appreciated.
. Thank you, Your Excellency. Since we first met at U Waterloo, you have been a role model to me of a life well-lived.
Hull and the Humber Estuary, Yorkshire, England, on a picture-perfect beautiful day.
Je vous remercie, monsieur le premier ministre. Je suis un Canadien, fier de servir, and honoured to represent our country.
Thank you, Dara. I looked for you while you were in Africa, but missed photographing your adventure, sorry. Raincheck?
. If anything can make one's jaw drop in weightlessness, it is to be honoured by the Queen herself. I am amazed & humbled.
Read the message from The Queen to :
Southampton, UK, easy to see what a good natural port it is from orbit.
Newcastle-upon-Tyne to Berwick-upon-Tweed, seen via Nikon-upon-orbit.
Nice graphic of where and how we live and work on the International Space Station:
Good Morning, Earth! A Wednesday in space, time for 16 sunrises, a day of research work, and tonight Kevin hands me the spaceship's keys.
Tonight's finale: Canadarm2, poised on the edge of night. Big day tomorrow!
Victoria, B.C. High-tech hub (not just tea and flowers - ), as clear as I've ever seen it.
I went to space today!!! (Well... Sort of.) Watch: cc:
Kids learn at our Science Centres, and this week is a science showdown across Canada on with . Worth watching.
Vancouver basking in the sunshine, from North Van to Tsawwassen, with the Fraser river discharging sediment.
Enormous eddy off the Italian coast.
Havana has a beautifully protected harbour, as well as some of the Caribbean's most stunning architecture.
This central Asian mining town looks best from orbit, I suspect. The stark winter colours are almost pretty.
. Thanks Chloe! Imagine it from my side of the camera. A real delight to talk with young Canadians, hear your ideas, off the Earth.
. Thanks Chloe! Imagine it from my side of the camera. A real delight to talk with young Canadians, hear your ideas, off the Earth.
Such an endearing little lake. In the upper Amazon, Brazil.
I love that he remembered to pack the sofa.

tweet.tweet_content: . Thanks Brooke! From the sublime to ... manual changeout of the urine treat tank. Such is life on a hard-working Space Station.
. Greetings, Mia, a delight to hear from you. You would LOVE seeing the World this way. Such a beautiful balance that is our home.
. Good morning California! Worked all morning, on a quick lunch break, about to talk with Brooke Baldwin at CNN. Fun space day.
.@iqbal1892 Hello Indonesia! Space internet is very slow, linked through a high orbiting relay satellite to Houston. Our food is rehydrated.
. From space we can see Earth's hidden folds & secret places, inaccessible valleys & deepest jungles. I love seeing them.
Space Music Video - playing from orbit with legendary Paddy Moloney & Chieftains, + Bandella, Jones Hall, Houston
Beautiful blood orange, freshly-delivered from California. It was delicious - thanks !
. We bathe, shave, wash hair and brush teeth, all with less than 1/4 litre of water. I need to make a video showing how ...
Morning on Space Station. Time to shave, shampoo and sponge bath.Water is short. A hot lingering shower is one thing I really miss!
Good Morning, Earth! While I slept we went over half a million people following on Twitter! The interest and support amazes me. Thank you!
Tonight's Finale: When I look at thunderstorms from above, I see faces. What do you see in the clouds?
The previous post, I should note, is also a mosaic of numerous photos pieced together through the talented work of Andrew Yee.
The Pearl River delta is home to 65-120 *million* of us, depending on seasonal work. The logistics overwhelm.
A composite of Hong Kong, Macau, and the Pearl River Delta with thanks to friend Andrew Yee.
A lot of people ask about food in space. Do tastes change? What variety of things do you eat? Here's my answer:
One of my two apples delivered on Dragon. I stuck Velcro on the bottom so I could set it down between bites.
Saskatoon on the South Saskatchewan River, Canada. Ham radio pass with Martensville students very soon!
Saskatoon on the South Saskatchewan River, Canada. Ham radio pass with Martensville students very soon!
Wondering if a photo was already taken? and students have made an interactive map for you to use. Cool!
Tried for Comet Pan-STARRS out Roman's sleep pod window, but our angle with Earth was bad. I did see this, however.
Mt Fuji really stands out dressed in winter white. I stood inside the top in September, looking up.
Do you read me, Martensville? set to talk to Sask students from orbit today! We'll be there.
Later today I have a videocon with students in Airdrie, AB, to discuss radiation in space and on Earth, and Cdn tech.
. Yes, after 5 months of freedom in weightlessness, the relentless crush of gravity seems an unfair burden.
My daughter tells me it's snowing and hailing in Dublin! Sounds like perfect weather for indoor pursuits. Sláinte!
. Perhaps the greatest gift of spaceflight is that you get to see and know the whole world, as one good place, like your home town.
An eruption of green life where water slows enough for it to take hold, in Africa.
Weightlessness is a constant delight - we're able to fly. Makes me smile.
. If you were assuming command of a spaceship in flight, what would be your first order of business?
. The next crew, Pavel, Chris & Sascha rocket up here at end-March, & my Soyuz crew w/ Roman and Tom fall home in mid-May.
Good Morning, Earth! This week Oleg, Kevin and Evgeni fly their Soyuz home, so I become Space Station Commander on Wed. Exciting for me.
Tonight's Finale: The very first glimpse of Moonrise.
Tarout Bay, Saudi Arabia, looks powerfully unnatural and purposeful from orbit.
Valentines is over, but I'm still in love with what the Earth shows me each day. Happy Mother's Day to Ireland/UK.
when you get back, you should visit all the places you've shown from space.
I'm loving reading everyone's ideas and offers of hospitality! Imagine what that is like for me, from here. Warm voices from the globe.
I'm loving reading everyone's ideas and offers of hospitality! Imagine what that is like for me, from here. Warm voices from the globe.
visit your daughter in the wonderful Ireland!!
wherever your heart leads you. To enjoy the feeling of wind in your hair and the messiness of life
When I return to Earth in mid-May, where do you recommend I should visit? Can you tell me why in just 140 characters? Best places on Earth.
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba, oxbow on the Trans-Canada. Can see where the Air Force teaches primary flying skills.
The Canadian Museum of Civilization's IMAX theatre is showing Space Station. The huge screen is the next best thing.
Smoke plume streaming from a cloudy and rumbling Mt Etna, Sicily.
Success! For months we tried to get a clear photo of Minsk, Belarus, hometown of happy crewmate Oleg Novitsky.
Riga, Latvia's capital city, with the outflowing Daugava River holding the Gulf ice at bay.
From the 6 men in orbit, a very happy Mother's Day to women in the UK and Ireland. We trust our Earthbound brethren to celebrate you rightly
. 8 Wonders of Earth: sunrise, Outback, S NZ, Sahara, Kamchatka, Grand Canyon, Great Lakes and where the oceans touch the land.
The Space Station runs on Universal Coordinated Time, aka Greenwich. With 16 sunrises per day, we didn't switch to Daylight Savings :)
One way to hold yourself still while you take pictures out the Cupola windows.
. It is so cool to watch the end of summer in Australia & spring arriving in the north. From orbit you can see the global changes.
. Thanks, I heard this documentary came out well. They were nice people to film with.
. le petit-déjeuner ce matin: Cheerios, jus d'orange, salade de fruits, café.
Good Morning, Earth! Running an experiment today to improve the metal in turbine blades, dental fillings & aluminum alloys. Big week coming.
Tonight's Finale: Canadarm2 and the Dragon she captured, as the shadow of night falls across the Earth.
To those still looking, the emphatic island can be found off the coast of Kalkan, Turkey.
To those asking "what is this" from the last photo:
If at first you don't succeed, try six more times.
Anticosti Island doing an excellent imitation of a Parrot Fish.
. Looking forward to talking with the students! Just flew over Airdrie, still snowy :)
. Thanks! But I like mine black, with a maple dip donut :) That would be good right now!
Wicked geology laid bare in Northeast Africa.
Johannesburg, South Africa, distinctively multi-coloured on the Witwatersrand range.
This is a great way to get the news that really matters. Thanks for all the updates!
We keep receiving unusual signals called tweets from some kind of orbiting platform. We've sent up a Dragon to investigate.
So what's going on down there on Earth these days? Could anyone fill me in on the top 3 things? We've been busy working, I'm behind on news.
Finished transfer, time to exercise and wish Yuri Gagarin a Happy Birthday. A brave man, he led the way, and would have turned 79 today.
I love seeing the wake spinning off the curly little islands at the top.
Working on Spacesuits - doing a flush of their cooling system, in our airlock. Ready to go for a walk, just in case.
Just took 10 minutes to speak with students at Lycee Polyvalent Anatole in France. Merci a tous pour les bonnes questions! Back to work :)
. Dragon is an American spaceship, built by SpaceX, will splashdown in the ocean just off the California coast in 2 weeks.
As I fill each cupboard and enclosure inside Dragon, it's somehow comforting that each item will be similarly unpacked by someone on Earth.
Good Morning, Earth! A full working Saturday in space, rebuilding the CO2 scrubber, running experiments and packing Dragon for return home.
Tonight's Finale: A beautifully clear February day over Newfoundland, with St. Pierre et Miquelon too.
African saltwater marsh - an incredibly complex ecosystem like nothing I've ever seen.
African saltwater marsh - an incredibly complex ecosystem like nothing I've ever seen.
Cosmonaut Barbershop - how to get your hair cut when it doesn't fall to the floor.
Saint Pierre et Miquelon - French Islands just off the Newfoundland coast of Canada. Fishing past, tourism present.
A fan of sand in Oman. From space you can see which way the Omani wind blows.
People ask if I see aliens. If sci-fi has taught me anything, this St. Lawrence ice is what they'd look like if I did
The border at El Paso, Texas and Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. A river runs through it.
Texas land use patterns - snakes and ladders speckled with oil drilling plots.
Newly delivered Canadian experiment called MicroFlow - there's an entire blood analyzer in this little bag.
. focus on the objectives, what you expected to see, what you actually saw, what you learned from it, & specific conclusions.
Good Morning, Earth - Happy International Women's Day!
Tonight's Finale: A large rock fell from the sky and blasted this hole in our Earth. When will the next one be?
Dallas, Texas - From orbit you can see just how big DFW airport is (it even has its own ZIP code).
From orbit you can see why they called it Grand Rapids - Michigan USA.
Cocoa Beach, Florida. Rockets on the right, cruise ships in the middle, fun on the left.
Be astronaut fit! – good work 385 students who are climbing their way to the in the name of wellness.
Chicago on a clear winter's day, ice on the shore, busy O'Hare airport visible from orbit.
A real tricorder? Learn more about how this experiment in space will help us live better on Earth.
Many people worked very hard to get this blood analyzer-in-a-box experiment onboard. First test - go, go Microflow!
Myrtle Beach, South Carolina - one of the legendary name resort destinations in the US. Looks inviting!
. I'm really looking forward to talking with the Stonepark students via Ham radio today - from PEI to space, and back!
. I'm really looking forward to talking with the Stonepark students via Ham radio today - from PEI to space, and back!
Tswaing Meteorite Crater, just north of Pretoria, South Africa. I once gave a lecture standing on its salty floor.
. Very sorry to hear Stompin' Tom Connors died. I'll play Sudbury Sat Night/To It n At It up here today, sing with him on his way.
Good Morning, World! Time to set up Robonaut & bring him to life for extended testing. His human-like presence is always slightly unnerving.
Tonight's Finale: Scandinavia on the horizon, far to the north of the Space Station's orbit.
Bornholm island, Denmark, a rocky rectangle in the Baltic Sea.
We ask 2 or 3 people to have a videocon with us during our 5 months in space. Just had a fun show 'n tell w/ - interesting lady!
Stockholm, Sweden. An iconic Northern city pulsing outward from the charming central island of Stadsholmen.
Spilling something in space can be a real mess. Here's how to clean up spills and avoid serious problems:
Helsinki, Finland at top and Talinn, Estonia below, looking on the oblique.
Oslo, Norway, lovely northern city, rarely seen from the International Space Station.
Lake Vättern, Sweden, boasting an island that resembles a fish.
Copenhagen, Denmark and the bridge to Malmö, visible from space. Alas, couldn't see the mermaid.
How the floating camera and teleprompter looked to me while filming the bit for the Rick Mercer Report.
It is a set of braided rolls of clouds over the Balkans.

tweet.tweet_content: Cute skit from last night's show with :
Good Morning, Earth! A packed day in the Lab today, including the first-ever cytometer in space, MicroFlow. Great potential, I'm excited!
Tonight's Finale: At long last - Manila, capital of the Philippines, delicately shining in the night.
Brand new RMR tonight on CBC @ 8:00 pm. Busting ice on the Red River plus special guest from space.
From space, a mighty mountain ridge turns into a tadpole.
From space, a mighty mountain ridge turns into a tadpole.
Can you guess what this is? Looks like soft feather down, but it's bigger.
Istanbul, Turkey. The pre-historic museum at Topkapi Palace is a fascinating place to reflect on human civilization.
. C'est la region de l'ASC - St-Hubert, et Mont St-Bruno au centre.
Ancient mountain roots stand out roundly amongst the patchwork fields in this Quebec winter landscape.
. without gravity we get a form of osteoporosis that we're learning how to beat. Spinal ultrasound measures it here.
Kolkata (Calcutta), India. 14 million of us living closely together on the Hooghly River in a huge developed wetland.
I've not seen the Great Wall of China from space, and neither did the Chinese astronauts. With a big enough camera lens & clear air, maybe.
This could very well be the answer (thanks to many for providing): Interesting!
What can this be? A line in the water out in the Pacific, visible from space.
Find out more about the Canadian Microflow blood analysis experiment mentioned by :
Ahh! What's this thing on my head!!! Oh, a sensor to calculate body core temp and circadian rhythm. Phew.
. a mix: some experiments are automatic, some (like spinal ultrasound) completely manual. Station is a big, busy laboaratory.
Good Morning, Earth! Cool new experiments today - MicroFlow blood analyzer in a box, liquid lead/tin solidification, spinal ultrasound. Fun!
Tonight's Finale: The Moon, newly risen, perfect over a flowing blanket of cloud.
Belfast, Northern Ireland. The distinctive, historic harbor stands out clearly from orbit.
I think you fried my website :) this link should work
Morecambe at the seaside, England, home and namesake to the much beloved comedian and entertainer.
What a cute surpise! Thanks to for turning a thought I had into something so nice.
From Edinburgh to Stirling and all the way to Loch Lomond. A rare view of Scotland from space.
From Edinburgh to Stirling and all the way to Loch Lomond. A rare view of Scotland from space.
. When you move houses, often the packing takes longer than unpacking. That's true here too. Dragon is already fully unpacked!
Brianna w/ at Air & Space museum in Ottawa. Maybe at the space station one day!!
The Isle of Man. Home of Spuds and Herrin, and the distinctive Manx triskelion.
Dragon has an empty belly! We completely unpacked the visiting spaceship today. Many new experiments for Space Station, plus some goodies :)
Inverness, the capital of the Highlands. Nearly as far North as my lens can see.
The English coast at Workington and Whitehaven, with the Lake District proving picturesque from any altitude.
Scottish winter snow highlighting the wild extent of Cairngorms National Park.
. Canadarm2 is the huge, 2-handed 7-joint robot on Space Station. Canadarm was its great predecessor on the Space Shuttle.
Good Morning, Earth! Today: unload Dragon, fitness test, sample waste water, set up new Coarsening in Solid-Liquid Mixtures experiment.
Tonight's Finale: A Dragon, snared and tamed by Canadarm2. Saint George ringing in a new era in the silence of space.
. We work with a team on the ground, item by item, to control Dragon's weight and balance. It hugely affects how it flies home.
. My favourite thing on Dragon was a personally signed note from the Canadians that work at SpaceX, a fun surprise photo collage
Success! Canadarm2 holds Dragon by the nose, to drag it up and hook it on to a Station hatch.
. good question! Yes, having Dragon's mass added to Station's nose affects how we control and steer the whole spaceship.
we can't see quite that far south, Jose, sorry. Always on the lookout for volcanoes, will post all that I see.
. we'll spend a few days unloading Dragon, then repack it to the brim with experiments and hardware for splashdown in the Pacific
What a day! Reached & grabbed a Dragon, berthed her to Station & opened the hatch to find fresh fruit, notes from friends, and peanut butter
Did you see this from the Toronto Sun today? So great.You are an icon.
Armchair astronauts, think you have the right stuff to fly ? Test your skills with our game!
Happy crewmember - Dragon securely snared by Canadarm2, ready to be lifted around, hooked into place, and opened up.
Like a Praying Mantis, Canadarm2 poised to reach out and grab Dragon.
The Dragon spaceship high over Mount Etna - both spitting fire.
Self-portrait in the Cupola with rising Dragon below, Africa behind.
is proud to have helped bring to the . See explain robotic operations:
A Dragon approaches over sub-Saharan Africa - surreal juxtaposition.
Dragon comes into view - first sight this morning, sneaking up on us from behind the Progress solar array.
A lot of pictures coming from the Dragon approach and capture. Very busy day, but I'll try to post when I can!
Canadarm2, proud builder of the International Space Station, in preparation for the successful grabbing of a Dragon.
poses with last spring
The Dragon is ours! Maneuvering it now on Canadarm2 to a docking port, will open hatches once secure. Look forward to new smells. Great!
Just caught sight of the Dragon spaceship, crisply white against the horizon, sneaking up on us from behind. We're readying to grapple.
Good Morning, Earth! Time to catch a Dragon. We'll grab it with Canadarm2 in about 5 hours, then go into its belly & see what it brought us.
Tonight's Finale: Newfoundland. The Rock on the horizon.
Point Pelee and Pelee Island - the very southernmost tip of Canada decorated with a jigsaw of February ice.
Hey my daughter Sadie saw u at the SkScience Centre today as you tweeted pix of Regina from space!
Rock and water churning it up in Newfoundland - Proving it doesn't take much colour to paint a beautiful scene.
Gaspe, Quebec - avec une bouchee de glace - with a mouthful of ice.
Regina, SK, cleanly etched into the prairie by the February snow.
. Scout: look at my city pictures for airport runways, & go on-line to see how big they are. Your 'HELLO' has to be that big.
. Scout: look at my city pictures for airport runways, & go on-line to see how big they are. Your 'HELLO' has to be that big.
. Jose - do you have a specific volcano you'd like a photo of from space? I'll do my best to find it.
. Thanks Patrick - what skill! I wish you could be up here to see and be inspired by what we can see.
St John's, Newfoundland, on a crystal-clear winter's day. Cape Spear stands out, even from space.
Gaff hook peninsula at Stephenville, Newfoundland, Canada.
we found your space to-do list! Just one item left.
Freeze Frame - pausing for a moment, flying through the Node2-US Lab hatch, with a medical sensor taped to my head.
. If you're on the right part of the Earth you'll be able to see both ISS and Dragon fly over on Sat or Sun.
The Dragon resupply spaceship is 7 km above ISS and 2850 km in front, her problems fixed. Re-planning the rendezvous and grapple schedule.
.@SarahJNicholson Yes, I'm a big believer in a short nap after lunch. No more than 20 minutes, recharges my batteries. Siesta.
Good Morning, Earth! As of today, Tom, Roman & I are half-way through: launched 19 Dec & land ~14 May. Need to check my space To-Do list.
Tonight's Finale: Two spaceships beautifully blocking the view of Canada's East coast at sunset.
Today I managed to skin my knee in weightlessness. Ridiculous, but true. The blood just sort of sits there, and scabs quickly. An advantage.
The ancients in Peru made lines & patterns on the Nazca plain. Imagine if they knew people would see them from here!
. Brian - pleasure to hear from you! I'll send you 2 or 3, and we can figure out the timing that works best. I'll sort it w/NASA.
Orbit raising burn successful. Dragon back on track.
. My key items on Dragon: the MicroFlow experiment, fresh fruit & veg, plus a jar of crunchy peanut butter - I hope!
Barbados. Bridgetown harbor is where I first learned to SCUBA dive. Who knew it would lead to walking in space?
. Dragon is in an elliptical orbit so the height changes. Looks like the experts are solving the problems, fingers X'ed.
Happy St. David's Day! The Sun shines on Holyhead, northern Wales on the first of March.
Happy St. David's Day! The Sun shines on Holyhead, northern Wales on the first of March.
Far behind us in the distance we spotted a Dragon roaring up through the clouds, coming to catch us. Amazing.
Fly a Space Robot - here's what it's like to operate Canadarm2 from inside the Space Station's Cupola:
Flying Canadarm2, keeping proficient at this very particular and exacting skill. Good job for a Canadian!
SpaceX launch at 10:10am EST today. Will deliver cargo to ISS. Watch it live at
Karachi, Pakistan. More than 20 million of us live in this thriving delta city.
Happy Saint David's Day! We have a perfect pass over Cardiff in 2 hours and I will photograph the day, if only the Welsh clouds will clear.
Coast-to-Coast TV from space: will be on Canada AM with Beverly Thomson this morning:
Space Breakfast - granola with dried blueberries, dehydrated vegetable quiche, instant pineapple juice, instant black coffee. Suit you too?
Good Morning, Earth! Our crew wishes full success in launching Dragon today! We're very ready to grab it with Canadarm2 tomorrow.
Tonight's Finale: Huge cyclone swirling clockwise off the coast of Australia, taken from the ISS on February 27th.
Pyongyang, North Korea. A shrouded city of much global concern. In stark contrast with the South, not too far away.
. I'm getting to know our world well up here, but I sure don't know it all yet. Good thing I still have 2 and a half months :)
. My apologies! You are correct, I am wrong, that is Gunsan, not Seoul! Very sorry for the error. I will correct it. Thanks!
Seoul, South Korea - a massive thriving, industrious port city.
Where the rock meets the soil near Capetown, South Africa. Are these the vineyards where the wine comes from?
The sea playing with the sand, in Pakistan.
Down the throat of an active volcano - Mt Etna smoke and shadow, photo by Kevin Ford.
Mt Etna erupting and shooting steam and smoke high above the cloud, seen from space.
. I'd love to again visit Scotland once back on Earth. I've been from Oban to Aberdeen, but there's so much more to see and do.
. I'd love to again visit Scotland once back on Earth. I've been from Oban to Aberdeen, but there's so much more to see and do.
Good Morning, World! The Japanese robot on the outside of our spaceship had its 1st-ever tool use yesterday. It's good to have capable help.
Tonight's Finale: Edinburgh to Dundee, with the big Tay and Forth bridges visible. Save the rest for another day!
Glasgow and the bonnie, bonnie hills of Loch Lomond.
yes, my grandmother's family is from the Borders region. They sent a brave son to Canada in the 1800s, and then followed him.
The Scottish east coast as-seen from space, Montrose to Peterhead, Aberdeen at the centre.
I live on the island bottom left, here's a photo I took of you last week!
The ruggedness of Scotland evident in the snowy hills and lochs north of the Firth of Clyde.
Scotland - from Prestwick to Glasgow, past Loch Lomond to Inveraray.
Canadian know-how is on its way to help see what asteroids are really made of. Announced today:
Isle of Skye, Scotland, with February snow on the peaks. Mist and mountains - a stirring landscape.
The low, late afternoon February sun shines across the skinny waist of Scotland, almost to Edinburgh.
With her currently clear late-February skies, today seems like a good day for pictures of Scotland. Agreed?
An artist on Earth () did this. The visual process seems pure talent and magic, skills that make me marvel!
Further to 's previous tweet, here is how the crew trains to react to fire alarms & emergencies:
Fire on Space Station - the alarms just rang, we reacted as-trained, used sensors to sniff behind suspect panels, false alarm. Good thing.
. Space coffee is instant, in a bag, drunk through a straw with a little on/off valve. Try coffee through a straw, it's ... odd.
Just made myself a second bag of coffee. One of those mornings, even in space :) Mine is Kona black.
Morning briefings with Houston, Huntsville, Munich, Tsukuba & Moscow complete, time to start assembling the ultrasound in the Destiny Lab.
Good Morning, Earth! Waking to a Wednesday of cardiac ultrasounds and Soyuz emergency drills, plus will try to photograph Mt Etna erupting.
Good Morning, Earth! Waking to a Wednesday of cardiac ultrasounds and Soyuz emergency drills, plus will try to photograph Mt Etna erupting.
Tonight's Finale: Lake Baikal, Siberia. Immensely old and deep, it holds one-fifth of all the Earth's fresh water.
Patuxent River. The day I was hired as an astronaut I was a test pilot here. Hard to believe what's happened since.
Kitchener-Waterloo, ON - home to , and the church my wife and I got married in.
Where there's water, there's life. Serpentine river and center pivot irrigation farms in South Africa.
. it's a rare treat to get fresh fruit/veg in space - only when a new ship comes up. Our regular diet is dried & thermostabilized.
Ontario, Canada - Hamilton, Cambridge, Kitchener-Waterloo, Guelph and Brantford, linked in the night.
Freetown. A major west African port city, capital of Sierra Leone.
way awesome RT : How's this awesome photo of over Peggys Cove? Captured by
Glance out the spaceship side window, that's what you see.
Weightless in my new space pajamas - made in Russia, very warm and comfy.
Hello Scandinavia! Had a very rare pass where we could see the northern European cities. So cool to catch such a glimpse, from our orbit.
Oui, je dors très bien ici a la SSI, merci!
. Thanks! Writing and recording music while orbiting Earth is a fascinating pastime for me up here.
. Priority for today is setting up a new experiment, building the test apparatus. It's called Coarsening in Solid-Liquid Mixtures.
43,000 feet! Be careful way down there so close to the ground :) Fly well.
Good Morning Earth! The full Moon has been beautiful, rising 16 times a day above the air. I need to get and post a good picture of it.
Tonight's Finale: The Himalayas to the horizon, gives me such a feeling of wild grandeur.
Canadarm2, the Space Station's main robot, reaches towards the horizon.
Peterborough, ON - and the Trent Severn waterway.
Peterborough, ON - and the Trent Severn waterway.
Good questions, students at Soleado Elementary! Sorry we didn't have time for them all. Thanks for talking with me on the ham radio!
Washington, DC - the Beltway and the Mall both visible from Earth orbit.
. ears pop when air pressure changes and some gets trapped behind your eardrum. Pressure drop would be bad on Space Station!
Milton, ON, where I grew up on a farm and graduated high school. The Niagara Escarpment clearly visible on the left.
. That's a far better reason for me to be in California - I look forward to the ham radio Q&A with the students!
Toledo, OH, at the very western tip of Lake Erie, famous home of Cpl Klinger and honest weight.
Seen from MCC Capcom console: practicing with Canadarm2 for w.e. arrival of SpaceX Dragon!
Science Rack Repair - replacing the yellow drive belt for the ESA Biolab experiment. It spins as a centrifuge.
Congratulations to the Indian Space Research Organisation on their successful launch! Now we can detect asteroids:
Something very comforting about listening to serenely interviewing folks on Q while I workout in orbit. A calm touch of home.
Good Morning, Earth! Today a Canadian asteroid-hunting satellite launches on an Indian rocket, for planetary safety.
Tonight's Finale: Nature inspires awe - cloud, ice and rock in southern South America.
Niagara Falls in the night, and all the surrounding towns from St Catharines ON to Buffalo NY.
Lima, Peru, with clouds pulled to the Pacific. Airport clearly visible from orbit.
Pittsburgh, PA - even from orbit it's easy to see the three rivers.
. Hi Ben - I've been watching your superb play when they beam up replays of the games, no way I could handle your job! Go Leafs!
Split, Croatia, a fine natural harbor on the gorgeously rugged Adriatic coast.
Bonne chance et succes aux champions!
Bonne chance et succes aux champions!
Spacesuit, like a one-person spaceship. Ready to go outside, just needs gloves and a volunteer.
. It's a startling miracle, every time, to look out of my window and see Earth.
We run on Greenwich time, same as London, England, so it's 11:33 here. Have a fine Sunday in the Grand Valley.
. Space Tip: F=ma, so get the most powerful rocket you can afford and stand well clear. And take pictures.
Yes - Yorkshire is my kind of country.
. Good Morning, Lesley! My family is from your area, Sheffield, Wakefield. Great-granddad Austin Hadfield moved to Canada ~1908.
Good Morning, Earth! A Sunday full of projects to get done. But first otameal, eggs, juice, muffin & coffee (all instant/thermostabilized).
Tonight's Finale: Haruna, a large and powerful tropical cyclone, wreaks clockwise destruction across Madagascar.
Some fault lines are visible from space. Tectonic plates make a rift in the Andes.
I painted this oil painting for you. :) ”
London, Ontario - mid-winter in the snow belt.
Hamilton, at the tip of Lake Ontario. Steel town, with the Niagara Escarpment just visible from space.
. The world is stunningly beautiful from space, relentlessly rolling colour & texture. Grtst fear is family illness, me unable 2 help
Boston on a misty February night.
The Nile, a river so important in human history, lit up and flowing, through Cairo to the Med.
104 years ago today, the first airplane flew under its own power in Canada. That's amazing to consider, from here.
This taffy-twisted African rock reminds me of a dolphin, and Alfred Hitchcock.
Eating my fresh green apple, a rare and tasty treat in space. I wonder who picked it, where, and if they know?
Eating my fresh green apple, a rare and tasty treat in space. I wonder who picked it, where, and if they know?
Just a reminder - You can find my recordings (space sounds and some original music) available for download here:
Happy Birthday from orbit to Canada's first astronaut, ! You have led the way, Marc, and I thank you. Hello to your family, too!

tweet.tweet_content: . Space Haiku: Little window shines, kaleidoscope Earth pours by, all thoughts are humbled
Good Morning, Earth! Got up early to photograph S Africa, India and northern China in clear weather. Will post the good ones. Saturday!
Tonight's Finale: Asteroid impact - the Manicouagan Crater in Quebec. On old scar, but a big one at 100 km across.
Cleveland, OH, on the Erie south shore. Home of the Rock n Roll Hall of Fame!
Talked with students this evening in Penticton, BC, via Ham radio. A pleasure to hear the confident young voices.
I don't think that sand came from those rocks.
The incredible lightness of being .. an astronaut:
Hyderabad, India, clear in the night. Home to the world's largest movie studio.
Everything you've always wanted to know about space travel but were afraid to ask:
Tobago - a lovely place to dream of going when my feet are back on Earth, and ready for sand and sea.
Norfolk VA - from Newport News to Virginia Beach. You can count the bridges from space.
. Carrying the Fire is a great book by Apollo astronaut Michael Collins. I re-read it in quarantine before launch.
Invitation - Hang-Out with our crew on Space Station, very soon!

This morning we fired the thrusters on Station to raise our orbit, getting to the right height/speed for the Dragon launching in a week.
A nice shot of Paddy Moloney, the Chieftains, my band Bandella and me, performing Moondance together last Friday.
A nice shot of Paddy Moloney, the Chieftains, my band Bandella and me, performing Moondance together last Friday.
. Thanks, that's a very nice thing to say. Especially as I've been transferring urine brine all morning :)
. You're right, Colin, thanks! I fixed it, and the right link should be there now. Hard to juggle from up here sometimes :)
Morning Math Motoivation - why should I do my homework?
Good Morning, Earth! How did it get to be Friday so soon? Time sure flies at 5 miles per second!
Tonight's finale: Clouds and cosmos over the Indian Ocean.
Read our weekly Mission Blog for a summary of 's activities aboard the , Feb. 16-21.
The UK south coast crystal clear at night, centered on Brighton.
Even as I took this picture I was thinking it will make a nice desktop background. And it does.
Cape Town, South Africa, the glinting sun highlighting the water.
. I wish Virgin Galactic great success in opening space to many more people. And I'll try & photo Necker Isl.
Winnipeg in the night, with the Trans-Canada Highway left-to-right and the Red River south-to-north.
Had a lovely video link with the beautifully talented . We talked of music and education and guitars. Such a good person.
These delicate cappuccino frosting decorations are, in fact, endless hummocks of Saharan sand.
Eye of the Storm - Tropical Cyclone Haruna, today over Madagascar, with Canadarm2 pointing at the eye.
. UTC time zone splits the difference between Moscow and Houston, our 2 main Control Centres. Shares the insomnia equally.
. Space Poetry - my first orbital haiku: Fly so high so fast; Sixteen sunrises each day; Count my lucky stars.
. Good Morning Scotland! Yes, the Space Station and Scotland are in the same time zone - UTC. We eat breakfast together :)
Good Morning, Earth! Tody I take microbial samples of the air and surfaces in all modules of ISS. See what grows on a ship at sea in space.
After several busy, long days, I'm taking my own advice and floating off to sleep early. Maybe play a little guitar first. Goodnight, Earth.
After several busy, long days, I'm taking my own advice and floating off to sleep early. Maybe play a little guitar first. Goodnight, Earth.
Arid fingers of sand-blasted rock look like they're barely holding on against the hot Saharan wind.
This green Aussie lake somehow reminds me of a haggis.
Beijing - Tiananmen Square still bright with echoes of the Chinese New Year celebrations.
. I agree! The team of people at the Cdn Space Agency are hard-working, resourceful, proud and fun. Glad you could visit!
. What do we do? Space Station is the world's laboratory with no gravity. We run ~130 experiments, pilot the ship, & look beyond.
. Thanks for asking Bill, we were fine. Station is a rugged ship, and we hardly missed a beat. Back full force today.
Mixing colloids in a test tube, then watching them form structures. Space science!
"Open the pod bay door Hal" at work today despite the outage w/the ground. Comms were restored @ 12:34pm
. our orbit is mostly stable, and the Earth turns underneath us, so we pass over new lands on every rev. We go from 52 deg N to 52 S.
Good Morning, World! Mechanic day - replacing the big yellow drive belt in the Biolab Experiment rack. Feels good to get my hands dirty.
Tonight's Finale: The truly surreal is when humans imitate nature - Palm Islands and The World, Dubai, at dusk.
. ... and the solar wind be always at my back - thanks friend David! Lights out soon on ISS.
. Yes, I watch the Leafs play while I exercise. Our support team in Montreal sends me replays of the games. Hockey motivates me.
Weightless liquids behave oddly: an air bubble and pepper oil jockey for position in a ball of water.
. yes, Valentina Tereshkova is a friend and a lovely, brave, gracious lady. She came to our farewell breakfast before launch.
. my favourite experiment onboard is MicroFlow, a toaster-sized blood analysis invention we're testing soon. And it's Canadian!
From over the southern tip of S. America, I looked south and saw Antarctica, there in the sea and cloud. Tantalizing.
. The Soyuz is the ship we fly to Station and also fly home, plus it serves as our lifeboat if ever needed.
. we have intermittent, slow internet in orbit, but it allows me to Tweet live, and is faster than the other planets' :)
. we have intermittent, slow internet in orbit, but it allows me to Tweet live, and is faster than the other planets' :)
. I wrote a space lullaby for my daughter. It's my current favourite thing to play and sing while watching the earth and sky go by.
. We're trained in emer medicine & crewmate Tom is a doctor. We have basic meds onboard. But if really ill, we'd fly Soyuz home.
. John, we go around Earth every 92 minutes, so we see 16 sunrises and 16 sunsets each day. They are beautiful, and happen fast.
. Yes, we're fine. The onboard computer upgrade just interrupted some comm for a while. Space Station's a good, tough ship.
Space Station over Toronto, lovely time lapse photo taken by friend Andrew Yee on 13 Feb.
The computers gave us problems today,comms going in and out, but our superb Mission Control team has it all fixed, back, with an upgrade.
The city of Porto and the Portuguese coast, taken with our ESA NightPod tracking mount.
. Here's how we 'go' on the Space Station:
irony: an incongruity between the literal and the implied meaning. The human talking to us in Mission Control's name is Hal.
As I transition the Space Station computers, I notice our Houston CAPCOM's name is ... Hal ! The irony, as life imitates art.
Good Morning, Earth! Today we transition the Space Station's main computers to a new software load. Nothing could possibly go wrong.
Tonight's Finale: The full moon rises over the only planet we have ever called home.
Budapest, Hungary - and a huge hello from space to the Töröks, family of my beloved daughter-in-law.
On today's episode of Cooking in Space, chef Hadfield teaches you how to eat all you want and still remain weightless:
Mars is a very interesting planet, with its rugged, ancient surface. But this is Earth.
Wow, I can feel the warmth of the Irish all the way up here - go raibh maith agaibh! I'll do my best to photo more cities as clouds clear.
Tá Éire fíorálainn! Land of green hills and dark beer. With capital Dublin glowing in the Irish night.
King George's Sound, Australia. Charles Darwin got off the Beagle and hosted a dance here in February, 1836.

. We want to directly search for antimatter. Because of the existence of the Space Station, we can do that:

Grand Rapids, MI, with the lights on, as-seen from 300 miles up.
Astronaut Music - from my 1st guitar to Randy Bachman:
Asteroid Hunter - small but mighty Canadian satellite to help protect planet Earth, launching in a week. Good project
Tool Time - everything you might need to fix a Space Station in flight.
Good Morning Earth! Been up doing blood draws for bone demineralization research. A fine way to start a Monday. The science week begins.
Tonight's Finale: There is an undeniable beauty in human imagination. What do you see in this Saharan cloud?
Those of you wishing to follow along can see questions and answers (or join in!) here:
The first confirmed alien sighting in space: It must mean it's time for my Reddit AMA! Hope for intelligent life!
Dragon skin. A bad place to take a walk, near the Horn of Africa.
The grappling mechanism at the tip of Canadarm2. The cables snare a shaft and pull in, the teeth lock it in place.
Maracaibo, Venezuela. The bridge to Cabimas clearly visible across the Lake. I lived here as an toddler.
Hi Chris. One of my first attempts! A 30 sec shot when you passed over the UK last night.
. It is an honour to meet an Olympian, Dom. I congratulate you on your talent, tenacity, self-discipline and achievements.
. Spacewalking has been the most memorable. It is magic to be between the Earth & the Universe, alone, holding on with one hand.
. I have taken several pictures of your beautiful country, if you look back through my Twitter images. Also all on Facebook.
. On ISS we are doing ~130 experiments, from collecting dark matter to studying osteoporosis. details at
. I wasn't nervous at blast-off because I had studied, trained and practiced for many years. I knew what to do, thus felt ready.
. I was inspired by Neil and Buzz, the day they walked on the Moon. I started turning myself into an astronaut then. I was 9.
. I was inspired by Neil and Buzz, the day they walked on the Moon. I started turning myself into an astronaut then. I was 9.
Hi Atiyah. Please ask your questions on Twitter or Reddit, and I will do my best to answer them for everyone. Time is precious :)
Yes, it is OK to use the photos I am taking here in space. They are for everyone. Please just credit NASA. Thanks!
Good Morning, Earth, from orbiting research ship ISS. Ask Me Anything - I'll be on Reddit tonight to answer your questions, live from space!
Tonight's finale: Brussels gleams like a lace jewel. Amazingly clear, finely veined surrounding roads and towns.
Merci Gilles! Malheureusement, cela est à la fois impossible et interdit ici à la station en apesanteur.
A bulging thunderstorm grows out through the top of the overcast over Malaysia.
Sat night: overwhelmed by your interest and support. An honour to be able to help give you a view into what we're achieving here in space.
A rare mosaic of space photos of the Toronto region, stitched together by friend Andrew Yee.
Montreal and surroundings - a fine mosaic of 8 photos, thanks to friend Andrew Yee.
Malta and Gozo, glowing in the Mediterranean under a halo of cloud on their hills.
Mama Iceberg and her litter of baby ice cubes, slowly melting into the South Atlantic Ocean.
's set up is for InSpace-3: Which may lead to Earthquake resistant construction materials and more.
Experiment hardware for colloidal particle testing, in the Microgravity Science Glovebox, Destiny Lab, ISS.
Good Morning, Earth! Space adaptation - when I wake, I feel like I'm horizontal, until I turn the light on, & then feel instantly vertical.
In Houston tonight, at Jones Hall, & the Chieftains are playing along with a recording I did this week in orbit - cool!
Tonight's finale:You hear all about the man in the moon, but what about the man in Patagonia?
Getting the Band(ella) back together tonight. &

Clear skies at last, from Cardiff to Belfast to Edinburgh to London, to the northern lights, and beyond.
Clear skies at last, from Cardiff to Belfast to Edinburgh to London, to the northern lights, and beyond.
Havana, Cuba, famed island port, glowing in the night on the Straits of Florida.
I set up a camera in our asteroid-facing window & set a time-lapse to try & see it, but no luck. Too small and far away - but that's OK too!
Porto Alegre in southern Brazil, on the excellently named Lagoon of the Ducks.
Grand Cayman at night, you can almost see the undersea cliffs.
You can watch my downlink with live, starting now, here:
A note to all Redditors: I will be doing an AMA from Station this Sunday at 9 p.m. GMT (4 p.m. EST). I look forward to your questions!
Using a tiny magnet to mix colloids in a test tube, then watching them form structures over a week in 0G. Cool!
A team are working on Earth's asteroid problem, under the Quixotic name of . Details in this TED talk:
our Earth gets hit by 100 tons of meteorites every day. Most burn up, but not all. ISS gets peppered too, but has armour.
Thanks Jeffrey! That is such a nice thing to read, first thing in the morning. All my best from Earth orbit.
Last night's Russian meteorite strike is a good reminder that detecting asteroid threats is good for our health.
This evening we will be pointing our hand-held cameras skyward in hopes of seeing the passing asteroid. Life in a cosmic shooting gallery.
Good Morning Earth! Friday working day in orbit, including activating Robonaut. Like having company, sort of.
Tonight's Finale: The clouds are quickly fleeting, but the heart continues beating.
I long to hold you in my Canadarm.
It's so hard to resist your gravitational pull. Europa me in every time.
The world could only make one heart as perfect as yours.
All the grains of sand in all the deserts can't compare to the number of ways I love you.
Hi Adam! I would love to hear your questions, and try and prove them true or false. Just so long as you don't blow up ISS!
Hi Adam! I would love to hear your questions, and try and prove them true or false. Just so long as you don't blow up ISS!
You make me feel light-headed, like I'm floating around the room.
Seven billion hearts, but I can see only one.
Blood cells looks red, hemolymphs blue, I've hooked up my heart to an experiment or two.
Without you in my orbit, there would be no heavenly bodies.
You're the island on the horizon when my heart is out to sea.
Betelgeuse is red. Rigel is blue. Neither of these stars shine as bright as you.
You are the thrusters that keep me in orbit when the world tries to bring me down.
Over the course of the day, I will be popping in to retweet the best I can find. Bring on your cheesiest!
Without you my heart is a lonely iceberg.
"My love for you burns brighter than a solid rocket booster, my Valentine."
"My heart glows like the Northern Lights when I think of you, my Valentine."
Good Morning, Earth! Happy St. Valentine's Day! Today I will send some Space Valentines from orbit for you to send to your beloved.
Tonight's finale: The Sun just over the horizon silhouettes the complexities of our atmosphere.
The busy Saudi port city of Dhahran, and the bridge to Bahrain. An incredible sea of humanity, as-seen from space.
Center-pivot irrigation farms mining an ancient reef of deep water.
Just spoke w/ students at Chief Peguis Jr High in Winnipeg by ham radio. Really nice to hear the voices & try & answer all their questions.
Look to the horizon to see how thin Earth's atmosphere truly is.
Wide angle look at the Southern UK - despite the blur from clouds you can make out many cities and the overall shape.
Lyon, France, glowing under a touch of February cloud.
Lyon, France, glowing under a touch of February cloud.
Air and pepper oil suspended in a water blob. I blew on it to make it wiggle.
The Caribbean and the ISS sharing an evening yesterday – wonderful and peaceful end to the day
For those of you who missed it last week, here is a link to my musical collaboration with the :
This Friday I get to talk with students at University of Waterloo, a great school. Looking forward to the questions!
This is such a phenomenal place to be. I'm an adult busy working, but the little boy in me is screaming and running around and laughing.
the International Space Station goes fast - 5 mi/sec, 8 km/sec, 500 km/min, 28,00 kph, Mach 25 - around the Earth every 92 min!
Good Morning, Earth! Up and at 'em on the orbiting resarch vessel ISS. She is a good ship, ungainly, but fast.
Tonight's (Fat Tuesday) Finale: Even on the Space Station we're ready for Mardi Gras!
Calgary at night, shining in the foothills of the Rockies. Nose Hill Park really stands out.
The Outback is full of scary faces, staring up in forbidding horror.
Over 7,000 students are collecting neutron radiation data alongside for our RaDI-N2 & You project!
Successful Docking! Oleg and Roman celebrate the arrival of Progress 50 spaceship.
Progress spaceship on final approach to dock. You could see the thrusters firing, like small spitting fountains.
Oleg Novitsky working hard, staring at the screen, making sure the Progress docked accurately and safely to our ship.
Look closely - a spaceship is closing in on us! Progress approaching to dock with the Space Station yesterday.
A weightless waffle with Canadian maple syrup floats out of its package on Station for Shrove Tuesday. Very tasty!
Here in orbit on Shrove Tuesday we have thermo-stabilized waffles and a big squeeze tube of Canadian maple syrup. Delicious!
Good Morning, Earth! We slept in a bit after last night's resupply ship docking. Time to open the hatch - see & smell what the World sent us
Tonight's finale: Northern Lights - recent aurora in green and red waves, USA and Canada below, the universe above.
Tonight's finale: Northern Lights - recent aurora in green and red waves, USA and Canada below, the universe above.
Dropped ice cream. Doesn't it look like these African ridges are melting?
Les lumières de Bordeaux, et tout le chemin vers les côtes de France. The lights of Bordeaux to the French coast.
Silt-laden glacier waters billow blue into the sea at the south of New Zealand.
Progress 50 just docked to our Space Station! I was right at the hatch, it made a quick sliding scraping noise & then a solid thud. Success!
As I look at the verdant fjords and inlets of southern NZ, I ask myself can this possibly be real? Yet there it is.
Mysterious Pyongyang, just at the edge of my night camera's field of view.
We huddled in the Cupola window, saw a red fire in the night, & watched our Progress rocket launch & start chasing us to dock tonight. Cool!
At top, the Soyuz that we flew here and will fly home in May. Below, the Progress that undocked and burnt up.
If you find inspiration to create art in the images I'm sending from orbit, please Tweet your artwork. I'd love to see it!
In support of Expedition 34-NASA Johnson Style dancers & singers sport Hadfield mustaches!
We do have chocolate-covered coffee beans onboard for the mornings when you really need a kick-start :)
just hours before launch the Russian ground support team loads a couple small bags of apples, oranges & onions, etc. Good smells.
Glad to hear, Nancy. We're running that radiation experiment on board this week, also. . Let's compare!
Good Morning, Earth! Robot company coming - unmanned Progress resupply ship launches from Baikonur after lunch, docks tonight. Fresh food!
Tonight's finale: From here to the horizon to forever - a quick glance out the window of the Space Station.
Sarnia, Ontario, the town of my birth. So great to see the lights of home in the night.
I definitely won't forget Ireland - I have family in Dublin. The weather is similar, though :)
I notice I have a lot of followers in the UK. Cool! As soon as the clouds clear, I will photo all I can see.
To those asking: The last photo was of a dry lake in the Outback of Australia.
Your perspective often dictates what you see. From here I see a puffball on an oyster half-shell. How about you?
I believe this is Bournemouth, UK, but I am not positive. Can anyone verify for sure?
Glacial water burping into the Atlantic in deep Southern Argentina.
Here is a photo of you passing over Western University's campus Feb 9 at 6:55pm.
Lisbon, Portugal at night - black water, intricate spiderweb of surrounding towns.
If you give wind and sand enough time together, they create art.
Its only fair, a pic of u from lake Ont @ about 7pm Feb9 from
Yes, please re-post these pictures, credit NASA. I am taking them for everyone to see our world as one place, together.
Julian, that is such a wonderful thing to say. I will do my best. Good morning to you, from Earth orbit.

tweet.tweet_content: Good Morning, Earth! We did some very cool & unusual things this past week. Here's a summary:
Tonight's finale: Unification from space. The Korean peninsula, cut through the centre by a line of historic depth.
Just a few hundred kilometers away: Seoul, South Korea, a glowing hive of human activity welcoming in a new year.
Pyongyang, North Korea - a city and people I know so little about.
Shanghai, China. Home to more than 23 million people. Vibrant, cosmopolitan port at the mouth of the Yangtze River.
Shanghai, China. Home to more than 23 million people. Vibrant, cosmopolitan port at the mouth of the Yangtze River.
Night city in northern China. What could be in the orange box at the top? Can anyone figure it out?
Hangzhou, China. As one of the few space-faring nations, I salute China, her astronauts, and their accomplishments.
Morning clouds cast self-important shadows off the coast of China.
We live right next to a star. Today it ejected a huge blob at 500 mi/sec. But not to worry - should be good aurorae :)
An eye on the East today: Dawn's light on the hazy hills of Taiwan make a surreal spectacle.
Happy Chinese New Year! May it be filled with joy and success. To celebrate, we sent a Progress spaceship to burn like fireworks in the sky.
Lisa - most lonely people live in the middle of cities. Loneliness is more mental than locational. Good thing!
Spaceships and Earth - foreground is the Soyuz we'll pilot home in May. Unmanned Progress vehicle in the background.
I saw Sarnia clearly and waved vigorously, but Station was a bit too far south for a good night photo. I'll get one soon.
We just undocked a spaceship from our Space Station. The Progress robot ship is loaded with trash, to burn up like a meteorite in 3.5 hrs.
weekends are the 2 days where the work is unscheduled. Earth gives us a To-Do list. This weekend we also have a spaceship undock
we just had a panicked ham radio pass with students in Japan - solved our radio problem with 30 sec to go, answered every question - nice!
Good Morning, Earth! I stayed up very late last night, and was rewarded by seeing the lights of Sarnia, where I was born. Hi to all there!
it's an airport. Two runways crossing in an 'x' with a ring road around it.
Tonight's finale: Tehran, Iran - shining in the night. Does anyone know what the bright blue oval is?
The Earth has problem skin; one popped, the other didn't.
This dry salt lake in the Australian Outback looks like a good place to drive very fast.
This dry salt lake in the Australian Outback looks like a good place to drive very fast.
It's Friday evening in orbit, playing a little guitar. If you could record a song in space, which 1 would you choose?
Just talked with students at the Hospital for Sick Children in Toronto. Great, fun questions, many laughs. Nice way to spend a Friday night.
A lot of the Australian Outback looks like somebody spilled something on it.
The early dawn light turns these Outback rock folds into petroglyphs, as if there's a message there to decode.
This combines many things I believe in - art, science, exploration, inspiration & self-actualization. And it was fun!
Watch Ed and premiere their collaboration from space!
When an administrator draws a line on a map, sometimes it can later be seen from space. Farmland demarcations in Aus.
Crawled up to a hard-to-access Station window - guess what this Canadian saw? Look close for the crescent Moon, too.
Ade, here is a video that helps explain what happens to our deorbiting Progress resupply spaceship:
For his insightful work on films Apollo 13 and From the Earth to the Moon, & for his personality, I'd love to show the place to .
Just crossed N America in the night, from N of Vancouver to right over Boston. An incredible 9 minutes, aurora shimmering like magic.
Good Morning, Earth, from the space research vessel ISS. A full science day today, undocking a Progress resupply ship tomorrow for re-entry.
Tonight's finale: Floating in a sleeping bag, tethered to a wall in my pod. Note the armholes and the fresh air vent.
Almost time to float into my sleeping bag, tether to the wall, and go to sleep on orbit. Tomorrow I'll tell you who I was thinking.
Auckland New Zealand straddles widely varied geology, in colour and texture.
If you could send a public figure to visit the Space Station, who would you choose? I have a person in mind.
The Taranaki Volcano looks too perfect to be real.
I am Tweeting from inside my sleep pod on ISS. We need to have a Ku-band satellite link, but we get that many times a day.
If you happened to miss the conversation with earlier, you can find it here:
If you happened to miss the conversation with earlier, you can find it here:
Napier on Hawke's Bay, New Zealand. Rugged land, farms, rivers, city and the sea.
. on how collaborating on a song isn't that much different than working with others in space.
Thanks to for the thoughtful, researched and insightful questions today. Looking forward to meeting in-person back on Earth!
I did see a meteorite burn up between ISS and Earth yesterday, though. Sends a shiver down my back.
Hi from orbit, Ziya! We'll be looking, but unlikely to see it, as few of our windows face away from Earth.
Lake Taupo, NZ. Somehow reminds me of our Pug, Albert.
Proud installer of ultrasonic sensors to detect leaks in a space ship. Good to have.
Bubble Detector arrived today! Students Excited! Thanks to
Good Morning, Earth! Today the Space Station hosts a real-life Star Trek episode - looking forward to talking with !
Tonight's finale: Whatever the African farmers are doing here, I appreciate the view.
I see a chameleon that has taken on the colours of sub-Saharan Africa.
The startling verdant green of this swamp in Paraguay caught my eye from my perch a million feet up.
Join , & on Feb 20 at the in DC at
An angry meeting of air and water on the Chilean coast.
My home town is leaving the lights on for me - if the weather is clear, I'll take a picture of all my friends there!
The incredibly green lush wetness of the Amazon basin.
Ed Robertson of is a delight to work with. Our song debuts this Fiday:
Salamanca Park and Barranquilla Industrial District Port, Colombia - river pouring silt into the sea.
Salamanca Park and Barranquilla Industrial District Port, Colombia - river pouring silt into the sea.
. I'd just sit and watch the earth go by - its a perspective I've never had.
