If you had an evening to spend here on the Space Station, how would you spend it?
It's a pleasant touch of home to zip into my sleep pod bewteen events and check email and Twitter. It bridges the worlds.
spoke w/ Apollo astronaut Gene Cernan today. Here's a tribute to Apollo 17 he recorded before his launch
There's an undeserved satisfaction in cycling at 8 km/sec :)
44 Sarnia Air Cadets Support the Stache on C.O's Parade Night
Nikon D2 & D3, with lenses from fisheye all the way out to 800. Normally 180 or 400 for pictures of Earth.
We orbit Earth every 92 minutes - so we see 16 sunrises and sunsets per day, plus really get to know our home planet.
Our eyes can cry in space, yes, but the tears don't fall. Just get a ball of salty water filling your eye socket. Need a hankie.
Yes, we have coffee on the Space Station, but it's instant, pre-mixed with powdered milk/sugear, & drunk through a straw.
As a Canadian I was honour-bound to bring maple syrup - and it's onboard in squeezable tubes. Delicious!
But first - exercise (resistive lifting and cycling) and breakfast (instant oatmeal, juice and coffee).
Good Morning, Earth! We set a record for the most science ever done on ISS last week. Station is really hitting its stride, lots more today.
Asuncion, Paraguay, a city nearly 500 years old. The ancient street patterns are visible from space.
From London on the Thames to the sea to the world, so much of history came from this brightly-lit city.
From London on the Thames to the sea to the world, so much of history came from this brightly-lit city.
This late-arriving volcano in the Andes comes with its own little lake. I bet it makes for a nice photo on Earth, too.
& recording "I.S.S." It debuts on Friday
Looking across Madagascar to Cyclone Felleng on the horizon.
Returning from my short absence with a nice shot of Mexico. Merida, Yucatan, with a straight line to the Gulf of Mexico
Hello World! Very busy day on Space Station, re-wired the data system, so just got back on-line. Lots of science, & talked with Gene Cernan!
Tonight's finale: The Andes mountains blur to the horizon in a cold Pacific fog.
Where the Mississippi enters the Gulf of Mexico. The soil of America's heartland forming a vast, deep delta.
Saludos from Mexico!
I believe this young lad made to Africa a few times...
Oh come on. That's definitely a gorilla.
Challenge accepted.
You might recognize this....
This African lake is begging for me to draw a face on it. Anybody up for a photoshop challenge?
in CBC studios w recording. Tomorrow we add the choir. Song premiers on CBC Feb 8th!!
Clouds, shadows and sand, playing with my imagination.
To the newcomers: You can listen to the sounds of the Station (and original space music) on my account:
It's a bird, it's a plane, it's ... a river in South America.
A two-dimensional fountain, a river spurting and fanning into the sea.
A two-dimensional fountain, a river spurting and fanning into the sea.
This is so cool & fun it's surreal. Thurs William Shatner & I will talk from orbit to Earth. Hailing frequencies open!
Glaciers hiding from the summer sun in the Andes.
Fun stuff this week: Music with , and a CSA Tweet-Up
While the Space Station is quiescent overnight Japanese scientists study Marangoni flow in a suspended 'bridge' of water in 0g.
Good Morning, Earth! A full Monday of science experiments in colloid suspension, Biolab, & overnt fluid physics liquid bridge. 1st, bkfst!
Tonight's finale: The centre of the action: New Orleans - I can see the Superdome! I hope you all enjoy the !
Back on the East Coast, the Chesapeake Bay from orbit. You can even see the causeway.
In the spirit of the day: San Francisco at night - crystal clear, can even see the lights of Alcatraz from space.
I decided to become an astronaut when I was 9, the night Neil and Buzz walked on the Moon. Those explorers inspired my life.
Baltimore, Maryland. Home of the . Good luck in the game! (Thanks to Commander Kevin Ford for the photo)
We are 300,000 together! If ISS can help that many people look up beyond everyday horizons & see our World, then it truly serves us all.
San Francisco, home of the - good luck in the game today!
We're all rooting for the city we're closest to ... and at 5 miles per second, that can change as often as the score.
Tentacles of an Andes river drain the meltwaters.
Countryside like alligator hide in South America.
Countryside like alligator hide in South America.
From to makes a mixtape for a road trip to space:
Good Morning! When I was very young my family lived in Maracaibo, Venezuela. Some of my first small steps were there :)
Thanks Shir! Sorry for the poor connection, but it is a long way from ISS to Israel via Ham relay. Thanks for all the questions
We take lots of ISS interior photos too, we're just not as photogenic as Earth :)
Good Morning, Earth! Sunday on the International Space Station. About to talk with 200 students in Israel via Ham Radio.
Tonight's finale: This morning, over Africa, my breath was taken away.
You know you're a big dam when you a) have your own airport & b) are visible from space
Philadelphia, PA - the well-lit City of Liberty, Rocky, Brotherly Love and Cheese Steak.
be careful Peter, you're awfully close to the ground! Safe travels. Thanks again for the discussion last week.
Further East is Montreal, with Mount Royal very clear at centre.
On the shore of Lake Ontario, Toronto. Canada's most populous city.
Look at that! Next time I'm home I need to come by for a visit and a day's skiing. Best to all from Earth orbit!
Man and Machine - we set up Robonaut, testing robotic use of human-friendly switches and buttons.
If you're looking for specific photos I've posted, you can find all the updates organized in facebook albums here:
Congratulations to @Astro_Kevin7 - they set an record performing 67 hours of this week!
thanks Suzanne - imagine what they do to my day, to be in a position to hold the camera. I'm so glad Twitter lets us all see.
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: Vic, this is too magnicent an experience not to share. I'm using every means I can think of so you can see it through my eyes.
Mike, I'm Tweeting from my laptop aboard the International Space Station. Be sure to look up & wave next time we fly over you!
Mike, I'm Tweeting from my laptop aboard the International Space Station. Be sure to look up & wave next time we fly over you!
The island of Cozumel, Mexico. Even from orbit it looks like a good place to SCUBA dive.
Group photo - the 6 humans currently not on Earth
Thanks Bob! A nice summary of the what and why of one of the experiments we're doing on Space Station
I slept-in this morning, floating weightless in my Velcroed sleeping bag on the wall until 08:15
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: It's a big week for music - on 8 Feb our song premieres:
After landing, some things readapt quickly, but it takes a day on Earth for each day in space (or so) for complete readaptation
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: We wipe all surfaces & handrails with wet wipes & disinfectant wipes, & vacuum all the air intake filters, + general tidy-up.
Good Morning, Earth! A weightless Saturday, many projects to get done this weekend - explanatory videos, music, writing - & clean the labs.
Tonight's finale: The Andes mountains have an unbelievable richness of colour and texture when viewed from Earth orbit.
A latte runs through it
I spilled land in my sea.
"Papua: Snakes on a plain" RT : a view of Papua New Guinea through my lens. How would you caption it?
A challenge: here is a view of Papua New Guinea through my lens. How would you caption it? I'll retweet my favourites!
Kolkata, India - at night, definitely not the 'Black Hole of Calcutta' of legend. After many passes, a clear view.
Southern Suburbs of Cape Town, South Africa, with Table Mountain framing the bay.
Southern Suburbs of Cape Town, South Africa, with Table Mountain framing the bay.
Bogota, Colombia, on the edge of Chingaza National Park.
Maputo, Mozambique. Big, thriving African port city on the Indian Ocean.
My favorite space food right now is Russian pike perch in white sauce. I had it for dinner - delicious!
Aruba and Curacao, famed islands off the Venezuelan coast.
productive morning - installed ultrasonic detectors behind a US Lab rack to monitor leaks & noises. Later - Robonaut & BCAT. Now ... lunch!
Good Morning, World - 10 years ago today I lost 7 good friends on Space Shuttle Columbia. They would have loved this life. I honour them.
Tonight's finale: A screaming ghost haunting the Chatham Islands east of New Zealand.
Earth has a bellybutton! My guess is that this perfect African circle is a meteor impact crater.
most definitely learn to juggle, like, thirty balls in zero gravity
I wouldn't waste my time looking at tweets from me....:-)
I'm sorting photos tonight after a busy working day. Question: if you had a free evening in space, what would you do?
The Amazon, as though it were clearing away the clouds. A hugely impressive river, even from orbit.
- Pablo, you're right, thank you for the correct info on Cancun geography. I am always glad to learn, to better understand.
Cancun on the Yucatan, favorite tourist port on the Gulf of Mexico.
Vitória, Espírito Santo, nestled into the coast of Brazil on a clear summer's day.
The Annobon Nature Preserve, small volcanic island off the coast of Equatorial Guinea, Africa.
Yes, I used to race downhill and was a full-time ski instructor. Have fun skiing today - grt outdoor sport!
I'm fairly certain this is Reno, Nevada. The biggest little city in the world.
. astronaut breakfast today: oatmeal, dehydrated scrambled eggs, instant cider, instant Kona coffee, dried apricots.
. astronaut breakfast today: oatmeal, dehydrated scrambled eggs, instant cider, instant Kona coffee, dried apricots.
Good Morning, Earth! Setting up Robonaut inside today, while the Cdn robots do complex ops outside this week. ISS is a busy research vessel.
Tonight's finale: Full Moon rising. So near, and yet...
The wondrously wildly beautiful surface of our world (near the Etosha Pan in Africa).
demonstrated today how astronauts wash their hands in zero-g: Hygiene in space:
is on a mission possible when he stores samples that could help in the fight against osteoporosis:
From seashells to galaxies to this storm, Nature loves spirals.
Human land use patterns in southern Africa. I try and imagine what this looks like on the surface.
This space picture brought to you by the letter T. Contrails, as-seen from orbit.
For those who missed it, here's a link to the talk with the students in Ottawa:
It was a delight to speak with grade 5/6 students in Ottawa today, fun questions! Exploration pushes back horizons, helps ignite imagination
Cartagena de Indias - Colombia on the Caribbean.
What would happen to a marshmallow in space? That and more kids' questions, + the Governor General, live in an hour:
Sacramento, CA, the State capital - a river runs through it, visible at night from the Space Station.
A clip from a recent interview talking about the value of social media: How do you think it has been going so far?
. if there's a fire onboard we have to put it out, isolate it, or fight through it to escape in our Soyuz spaceships.
Good Morning, Earth! Short night; fire alarm sounded at 2 AM, false again, thankfully. Full day of science, + talk with students and GovGen
Not so fast. We were awakened by a fire alarm. It's a bad place for a fire. Fortunately, a bad sensor. Back to sleep now - goodnight!
Tonight's finale: Venezuelan valley framed by misty clouds - mysterious, beautiful and surreal.
Cauliflower clouds over the Amazon rainforest. A river like lightning.
Cauliflower clouds over the Amazon rainforest. A river like lightning.
Aruba in the Caribbean Sea - when I say it, the Beach Boys play in my head.
New Orleans - from orbit we can see the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway, both airports, and happily - the French Quarter.
Ed Robertson said some really nice things about the song we wrote & how music education was vital, growing up Canadian
. Evan's right; then the air ripples up & down, like water over a rock, gets cold enough to make a cloud each time.
A blue river in Brazilian farmland provides a striking contrast of colour and landscape.
Is this African lake real, or a mirage? Either way, a sere and beautiful natural work of art.
. During my 1st spacewalk I was blinded by contamination in the suit. My eyes teared & flushed for~30 min 'til I could see again.
. in space, noses don't run and tears don't fall. They just ball up and fill your eye socket and sinuses. We use hankies :)
You can see the floodwaters pouring straight through Bundaberg and into the ocean. Keep safe and dry down there!
The flooding and flow into the Coral Sea at Gladstone, Australia - visible from the Space Station.
Flooding in Maryborough, Australia - visible as we flew over Tuesday morning, 29 Jan.
Floodwaters pour into the Coral Sea near Rockhampton, Australia on Tuesday morning.
Hello Australia! Last night I I stayed up late to take a few photos of the flooding in the Northeast, which I'll be posting soon.
Good Morning, Earth! On pace for a record science week. I set up EarthKam, lets students take photos of Earth:
Tonight's finale: The island of Guam is small with big, visible airports. An important location in a beautiful setting.
. There are good pictures of our crew online - I don't Tweet photos of them out of a sense of privacy :
Two spacesuits locked in an eternal staring contest, ready to take us outside if needed.
Spotted through misty cloud in the Amazon rainforest. Conan Doyle's Lost World, perhaps?
Governor General David Johnston is a man I respect very much. An honour to share Q&A with him this Wednesday:
Governor General David Johnston is a man I respect very much. An honour to share Q&A with him this Wednesday:
Question of the day: What made these eight clouds? Is the Earth sending smoke signals?
Boston at night, glowing under a trace of fog.
Port Elizabeth, South Africa, with the wind out of the west.
Strange property ownership patterns on the Brazilian ocean coast.
Taming the Nile - the Aswan Dam's reservoir, Lake Nasser, highlighted in sun glint
While we're working inside Space Station, the Cdn robots are doing this on the outside:
. It is heart-warming to see the shared sense of human wonder across the globe, in languages I can't speak nor read!
. We have a full day of science planned, but I will get to the window and photograph our Earth every chance I get. Too good to miss
A recent article from when I lived on the ocean floor - good preparation for this spaceflight:
Good Morning, Earth! Today: Earth Camera setup, bacterial filter change, medical skills refresher, BCAT colloids expt
Tonight's finale: Riding the edge of darkness, to beyond the horizon.
We're in the lead! Incredible! Thank you all for your continued support. To those yet to vote, you can do so here:
Weightless water. This picture is fun no matter what direction you spin it.
Water has structure. We just aren't normally in a place to see it.
At the Mediterranean's mouth - Gibraltar, Algeciras and Ceuta.
Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, under summer cloud.
Madeira, Portuguese island off the coast of Africa. It parts the clouds.
. without gravity you need neither bed nor pillow. I have a floating sleeping bag, tethered to the wall so I don't drift away.
. my advanced education: Bachelors Mech Eng, post grad research, Masters Aviation Systems, Test Pilot School, Russian language.
. my advanced education: Bachelors Mech Eng, post grad research, Masters Aviation Systems, Test Pilot School, Russian language.
A tonsil of cloud catches the light at sunset.
. Hello Dara - we just now went past South Africa, and I took photos from Capetown to Port Elizabeth. I'll keep a Zambia eye out
. Space Station runs on London time; splits the difference between Mission Control in Moscow and Houston. I use my watch alarm.
. We orbit the world every 92 minutes, so that makes it 8 km/sec, or 500 km/minute - 28,000 km/hr. Or about Mach 25.
. Space breakfast: instant oatmeal w/dried milk, dehydrated orange juice, instant black coffee, pouch of mixed fruit.
. Thanks Cataldo! I watch the games while I'm working out. Good motivation, and I love the feeling of home it gives me.
. Good Morning, Renaud, thank you. I'm hoping to find time to play some guitar and sing while watching Earth roll by today.
Good Sunday Morning, Earth! We're on track to set a record this week: most hours of science experiments ever on ISS. Busy labs and crew!
Tonight's finale: Angry-looking smoke cloud in western Australia. Good night, Earth!
. this is what we do with our waste on Space Station:
. tonight we're doing a delicate fluid physics experiment in the Japanese lab, so we're finger-tipping gently when we move around.
A river of agonized dryness in Australia.
. we launched on 19 Dec, so our end of the world plan was to stay up as long as possible, and then land where we could see lights on
. one of the perks of being an astronaut on Space Station is no dishes, so no dishwashing! Our food comes mostly in pouches.
. the ISS weighs 500 tonnes and is the size of 5 NHL hockey rinks, with living quarters for 6 people. And its solar powered :)
The endless beaches of Australia - that's where I'd go for Australia Day!
. without gravity hearts shrink, bones reduce, blood press reg changes, eye-brain interact too; it's a lab like no other
. we have a huge magnet mounted on top of Space Station to collect and learn about the stuff of the universe :
. today (1st time ever) we used telescience to ultrasound the brain, bladder, appendix & bones of the hand. A great new capability.
. today (1st time ever) we used telescience to ultrasound the brain, bladder, appendix & bones of the hand. A great new capability.
. we have 130 experiments running, from cardiac ultrasound to fluid physics to collecting dark matter to studying the environment.
. our treadmill broke today, but we got it fixed so I had a late run - while watching a replay of the Leafs-Sabres game.
. we fly in an orbit that is basically steady in space, and the Earth turns underneath us, so new sights each rev - 16 per day.
. the aurora are beautiful from above, dancing curtain waves of green and red. I watched them today. Trying for a good photograph.
Adelaideans celebrating Australia Day. The grid of Light's Vision is visible from the Space Station.
"" I lived in SK and flew in the north, so I know of the thousands of lakes there. You're right, I'll look for a good picture!
"" the entire world is a mesmerizing magnet, pulling us to stare in awe. The photos are dictated by orbital track vs dark/light
"" Uluru is on my list, but I haven't spotted it yet. I'm looking!
I took that photo a bit west of Darwin, just as our orbit crossed the coast of Oz
I visited Johannesburg and spoke at schools there. Good people, beautiful country. Please tell your son Hello from orbit!
no gravity = no cups :) Here's what liquids do up here:
we take the pictures through windows, especially in the Cupola, as it bulges into space like a bubble.
Our view of the stars is phenomenal, and if the Earth is in the way, we just wait 45 minutes 'til we're on the other side :)
Australian river mouth - an explosion of colour and texture.
The cloudless heat of the Australian Outback evaporates lakes into many colours.
10 things to know before Ed & premiere on Feb 8th
King Island, Tasmania, Australia - land use and nature preserve visible from Earth orbit.
Thanks Nathan - the essential Canadian music that your dad wrote plays in my head as I soar across our country.
Thanks Nathan - the essential Canadian music that your dad wrote plays in my head as I soar across our country.
The Australian outback often looks like a rock crystal under a microscope.
It's 26 Jan - Australia Day! I took a few photos from orbit, to help honour everyone Down Under.
Lisbon, port city. No wonder so many of the great sailing explorers were Portuguese.
Good Morning, Earth! Saturday is Lab cleaning day on Station, plus several imaging experiments using ultrasound: hand, brain, appendix.
Tonight's finale: The ethereal wisp of cloud over water, white on blue, to the eternal blackness of the universe.
When you open a can of nuts in space, they almost look alive.
If Picasso painted lakes...
In the lee of the rock - protecting an island of humanity in a sea of orange sand.
Ships waiting for a pilot to guide them through the Suez Canal, from the Indian Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea.
Atlanta GA, with the busiest airport in the world, clearly visible from the Space Station.
It's Robert Burns Day! "If ye wish her gratefu' prayer, Gie her a Haggis!", but no space haggis, sadly.
New York City shining by night. Central Park is visible from space, and maybe even the light on the Statue of Liberty.
It's Friday evening on the Space Station! Time for a ride on the exercise bike (14,000 km), reheat dinner, and then photograph the world.
Our weekly Mission Blog is out! Read the highlights of what accomplished last week on :
Replacing cooling lines for the spacewalk suits. Thick black insulation keeps dew from forming and causing corrosion.
Istanbul - geographically and historically vital crossroads of continents, formed and reformed by imperial ambitions.
Here's more on the Radi-N2 radiation experiment mentioned in previous post:
Good (Friday) morning, Earth! Canadian-Russian radiation experiment today using bubble dosimeters. Plus fixing computers and ... plumbing.
Tonight's finale: Australia. Jackson Pollock would have been even further inspired by seeing the Outback from orbit.
Tonight's finale: Australia. Jackson Pollock would have been even further inspired by seeing the Outback from orbit.
A quarter million people, following these Tweets from orbit! I am honoured and humbled. Thanks to each of you for your interest and support!
La Ville de Quebec pendant la nuit - Quebec City at night.
A science experiment we"re doing on Space Station - we made a video to explain it:
Los Angeles, CA. The grey of pavement and dense population is visible from Earth orbit.
The Golden Gate Bridge from space, and if you look closely, its shadow.
The capital of Canada on a cold day.
Mexico City, Ciudad de Mexico - national capital, and the 3rd-largest city in the world.
Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The grey of humanity in an ochre desert.
. are performing ultrasound exams of their eyes today. To understand why:
Good Morning, Earth! Eyeball ultrasounds today, leak check and close-out of my heat exchanger plumbing, and robotic refuelling tests. Fun!
A month in space already! Unbelievable. Please suggest a cool photo idea - I'll do my best. Or take a picture with me!
Tonight's finale: From Perth, Western Australia, to the horizon.
If you blow on the weightless sphere of water it distorts, and creates a floating Fun House mirror.
Salt ponds and the Dead Sea. Such an abruptly apt name.
For comparison, here's Las Vegas late at night. Even my NightPod camera found the lights too bright.
Las Vegas, NV, with The Strip visible from orbit, and Lake Mead at far right.
Some things are harder - today was 6 o-rings, 8 bolts, 8 nuts and 16 washers. Picture that with no gravity. But I didn't lose even 1 !
I had fun plumbing all day - but no leak check 'til tomorrow. How will I sleep?
New England coast at night, from New Haven up to Hartford CT.
New England coast at night, from New Haven up to Hartford CT.
These bizarre waves off the shore of Trinidad were only visible for a moment, when the sun was just right.
The Australian Outback immediately looks like nowhere else.
Deserts appear as brushstrokes of art. Even as I click the shutter it's hard to believe what I see.
Good Morning, World! A full day of cooling water plumbing work on the Airlock heat exchanger. It needs replacing every 8 yrs, and it's time
Tonight's finale: Sun glinting off the Missouri waters, all the way beyond the horizon.
Trying to drop a puck without gravity - thanks to whoever made and posted this!
A snowstorm left a clear divide in the Southwestern US in January. A natural yin and yang on the prairie.
Dry salt lakebeds of Edwards AFB. I landed in many different types of aircraft here, including Space Shuttle Endeavour.
Canada's east coast, so vividly joined to the sea.
Izmir, Turkey, with the ancient city of Ephesus beyond - seeing that and the Temple of Diana at 18 set my mind aflame.
Detroit and Windsor at night on the 18th of January.
Melbourne, Australia, clear as a bell. An amazing harbor!
Canberra, capital of Australia. If you zoom in you can see the circle around Parliament House.
- Good Morning Starshine! Best wishes from high overhead on the International Space Station.
spaceflight seems to be causing vision degradation, so we're studying it in detail. Important to know for travel beyond Earth orbit
it is more difficult to draw blood in weightlessness than in a clinic, since everything floats away and we do it ourselves.
Good Morning, Earth! Just did a blood draw, now on to panoptic eye exam & replacing the spacewalk suit heat exchanger - delicate work.
An honour to drop the puck for the home opener tonight. Great to see Johnny Bower and a nice catch, Felix!
Tonight's finale: Our atmosphere acts as a lens, distorting the sun as it crosses the horizon.
Tonight's finale: Our atmosphere acts as a lens, distorting the sun as it crosses the horizon.
New Orleans on Saturday night, the Big Easy at her best. Her French Quarter shines all the way to orbit.
Like the sand is being sprayed with icing sugar. South coast of Pakistan.
The city of Perth, and the long curve to the very Southwestern tip of Australia.
San Francisco Bay Area. The sun glint really shows the water and cloud flow patterns.
If you lightly dust farmers' fields with snow, they somehow become a papier-mâché artwork.
Thanks for stopping and looking up! I really like seeing the Space Station from your perspective, there on the prairie.
Read more about 's spinal ultrasound experiment for here:
we just did an ultrasound study of my spine - first-time ever in space! A great way to learn more about osteoporosis cause and prevention.
St. Louis, at the joining of mighty rivers. Gateway to the West.
it's a busy week in the labs here on Space Station. Here's a summary of what we did last week:
an astronaut's Day-In-The-Life Tweet-up - special event, live and in-person for you at the Canadian Space Agency:
MT “: Did you hear from space? We did: loud, clear & autotuned! Preview special space song: ”
Good Morning, planet Earth! Monday in space: urinalysis, spinal ultrasound, airlock heat exchanger prep for replacement. eye pressure exam.
Tonight's Finale: Washington D.C. on Saturday night of the Inaugural Weekend. You can even follow the parade route.
A wonderfully clear view of the US West Coast. San Diego, California to Tijuana, Mexico.
'Checkerboarding' in the Rockies, product of railroad land allocations in 1800s
Ghost of a checkerboard through the snow, foothills of the Rockies, USA.
Cotton clouds over snow-dusted farms in the American southwest.
As far I can tell after a month on Space Station, there are absolutely no insects aboard. A little strange, really.
As far I can tell after a month on Space Station, there are absolutely no insects aboard. A little strange, really.
Three snow-capped mountains in the US Northwest - can you name them?
Houston, Texas, home of the Johnson Space Center, where I lived and worked for the past 20 years.
Great Salt Lake and the Bonneville Salt Flats, Salt Lake City just visible. Dry powder downhill skiing, too.
Great Salt Lake is confusing to look at from space.
Phoenix, AZ. Photo taken from orbit on a clear, near-cloudless day.
Good Morning, world! I was up early taking night photos of Mexico and the USA in continental clear skies. A fine Sunday morning activity.
. fans - I won't get to see the Leafs-Habs game on the Space Station until it's sent up to me tomorrow. Can you keep the score a secret?
Tonight's finale: As the season begins, I see the lights of Toronto, home of my favourite team - Go
Montreal, you're shining bright, it must be in Canada!
After a long delay, with this view stretching from Toronto to Montreal, it's great to say it's in Canada!
With a long tradition of hockey on the shore of Lake Ontario, introducing Toronto - Go Leafs Go!
Also welcomed back tonight, onto the 2013 ice, the city of Vancouver and their
Heureux de voir le hockey de retour au Montreal, Canada ce soir! Pour ma famille de l', !
90 breath-taking seconds over Patagonia last night
From the prairie hockey heartland, welcome back to Winnipeg,
At centre ice, our nation's capital Ottawa, home of - playing the today in Winnipeg.
No, but if you look closely, I think you can see Grapes' jacket from space
Niagara River gorge, Welland Canal, and Toronto - it's Saturday -- Welcome back Hockey, from a Canadian in space!
Good Morning, Brian. Please check your Twitter Direct Messages for details on your photos. Best regards from orbit!
Good Morning, Earth! A space Saturday - some science experiments, clean the labs, exercise, and take some time to see the World.
Tonight's finale: A rare space sight. Most borders are invisible from orbit. This one between Egypt and Israel isn't.
Huge swirls in the sea off of Mumbai, India
Rotterdam and the wide flat mouth of the Rhine-Maas delta.
Portsmouth, England, on a fair January day. You can see the Isle of Wight through a bit of cloud.
Bournemouth to Weymouth, towns named for where rivers meet the sea. Ancient folds of rock help define the coast.
The deep waters of the 'Tongue of the Ocean' lick the reefs of Andros Island, the Bahamas.
Cocoa Beach and Cape Canaveral, launch site of my first 2 spaceflights, and where our Dragon will launch from in March.
Good morning to the students of Truman Eddison Memorial! And to all students across Canada, from the Space Station
Four more sounds from space have been posted to the account, floating between modules to hear the changes:
- Nancy - the deadline for teachers to register is 18 Jan, so 1 more day. Thanks!
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: Good Morning, Earth! Lots of aurora last night, our busy Sun. Need students to test radiation w/me: register today!
Tonight's Finale: Buenos Aires, Argentina - the Rio de La Plata visibly filled with silt from upstream.
Spoke with 800 students in hometown Milton ON today. Great questions, thanks and for hosting!
Intricate patchwork fields and a Rolling Stones-esque lake, northern Mexico.
Farming in the river delta, Topolobampo, Mexico. (Unless, of course, it also turns out to be Tucson.)
Apparently it wasn't Mexico at all! The picture was of Tucson, Arizona. Hard to always know where on Earth the lens is aimed.
I took this colourful picture of a city in Mexico, but I don't recognize which one it is. Do you?
I took this colourful picture of a city in Mexico, but I don't recognize which one it is. Do you?
This grade 5 class arrived for 's downlink from Space complete with spacesuit and paper mâché helmet!
Montevideo, Uruguay - the sharp points of land making cowlicks in Rio de La Plata
Complex waters off the Bay of Callao, Peru. Charles Darwin's boat, the Beagle, stopped here for provisions in 1835.
Hola América Latina! Today is unofficially Latin America day! These Peruvian beach scars remind me of a comb-over.
Just arrived at Chris Hadfield Public School where 800 students are gathering to speak with !
Yesterday I had a tumblr set up to continue branching out further with my updates. Anyone interested can find it here:
Looking forward to speaking with the St Rose students via Ham radio today!
I'm delighted that Irish students are using these space photos fo a class project - global awareness is key in education!
Good Morning, Earth! We changed orbit late last night, fired thrusters to increase speed by .47 m/s. Fighting orbital decay, took 4 mins.
Tonight's finale: Undoubtedly one of the coolest space sights on Earth, the Richat Structure of Mauritania.
Re-wiring the Laboratory. With all the racks tilted up for access, it was like cave diving - hence the headlight.
African inland delta - surreal natural Medusan art.
Taking the new telescope out of the box - like weightless Christmas!
An old volcano, river gorge, and fog - where could this be? Hint: I think I see Zigzag...
The telescope that is floating with is called ISERV for :
New Space Station telescope, floating, ready for installation.
Today we re-wired the US Lab, did organic compound analysis, had a fire drill, and I changed out the toilet solids tank. Now to exercise!
I've uploaded four new sounds from the Station to my account. Hear what life sounds like in orbit:
Moving Day is easier in space. Look Ma, one hand!
Moving Day is easier in space. Look Ma, one hand!
The last photo was of Cartagena de Indias, Colombia (thanks go to for the assistance).
The surging flow of the ocean, very visible along the north coast of South America.
- yes, you can watch the event live at . We will have fun together :)
Tomorrow I will talk with 800 students at Chris Hadfield Public School, hosted by . Kids always ask the best questions.
Wednesday on Space Station - starting to rewire the labs for an upgraded communication system. Astronaut Cable Guy. Good Morning!
Tonight's finale: The Earth’s horizon, just before sunrise. Beautiful lines of colour, a rainbow halo for the planet.
The Station Solar Arrays serve a vital function, but also make a lovely mosaic when aligned in concert with the sun.
Just a reminder to my followers -- If you haven't yet voted for the Shorty awards, I'd really appreciate your support:
. Busy day on Space Station! We installed a new telescope, and the Dextre robot practiced refueling methods.
The Pacific current mixes violently with shore waters, a liquid maelstrom off the Central American coast.
Ringarooma Bay, Tasmania. Now I can't stop saying Ringarooma Bay. I'm like a 2-year-old.
Wildlife sanctuary on the Bay of Bengal, Kakinada, India. River silt makes a rich delta.
The coral coast of (what I believe to be) Cuba. Makes me dream of scuba diving there.
While you were asleep, removed the tertiary cap from the module. Today, more wire-cutting.
I'm not precisely sure where the river is, but it is somewhere within the Amazon rainforest. Hard to tell exactly at 5 miles per second.
I'm sure this river takes itself seriously, but it makes me laugh.
Just had a very fun video meeting with , famed Cdn musician and photographer. Thanks to the team that set it up - made my day!
Just had a very fun video meeting with , famed Cdn musician and photographer. Thanks to the team that set it up - made my day!
We're using Space Station this week to test ways to refuel satellites using robots:
Thanks Brian, very kind of you to say. Tell me exactly what photos you'd like, I will do my best over the next 4 months.
Good Morning, Earth! Telescope installation day in our big Lab window. Delicate work to protect the optics and mechanisms. I'll be careful!
Tonight's finale: A pre-launch photo of the crew. Morale is important - laughing together is essential to real success.
Athens, Greece. The cradle of so much of civilization and learned thought.
Patra, at the entrance to the Gulf of Corinth, Greece. Amazing how clearly the bridge stands out against the blue.
Island of Rhodes, Greece - interesting that from space, you can see where the Colossus of Rhodes stood 2300 years ago.
Greece continues! From Sparta to Kalamata is a pretty wild drive, with a beautiful view on all sides.
Another, fuller view of Heraklion and Crete from a bit further back. From coast to coast, to Dia island and out to sea.
Heraklion and the visible palace of Knossos, on the island of Crete, Greece.
Geia sas Elláda! Clear skies over Greece today, will post photos tonight. That makes it unofficial Greece Day!
Tiny, perfect, weightless loaf of Russian black bread. Shelf life measured in years, good for spaceflight.
Russian Space Food - stew in a can. We heat the whole thing, open, and eat. Delicious!
I do my best to take photos & Tweet in the short gaps between work tasks; a wonderful motivation to get ahead of the timeline.
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: Good Mon Morning, World! Today: start installing a new telescope in the US Lab window, finish H20 sampling, and run a colloids experiment.
Tonight's finale: The pall of smoke clouds over Australia, as seen from orbit. A rare view of the bushfires' effect.
A clearer view of Vancouver on a sunny day - can clearly see the ferry terminal, airport and many boats in the Inlet.
A clearer view of Vancouver on a sunny day - can clearly see the ferry terminal, airport and many boats in the Inlet.
The first shot of Vancouver, BC, where the Fraser flows into the sea. A beautiful city.
A few from the West Coast. Here's Victoria, BC. Have tea at the Empress and take time to walk through Butchart Gardens.
Lava Carbuncle - an ancient intrusion of tough, hard rock in southwestern Africa. Quite likely also Namibia.
For 5 months in orbit I could bring 1.5 kg of personal stuff, in a shaving kit-sized bag. Regular items are provided, though.
Sandstorm on the edge of farming country in the American Northwest.
High speed, low mileage. Our running shoes, ready for the treadmill and weightlifting.
The wind has blown away the sand and left bare stone, truly bone dry. Likely Namibia in Southwestern Africa.
A river on the way to the ocean, stopped by sand and heat. Southwest coast of Africa.
Frozen crests of sand break over the arid rock, Namibian coast, Africa.
Adam, remember that you need to decide who you want to be, and then start slowly turning yourself into that person, each day.
Good Morning, Earth! Time to exercise - 1 hour lifting, 1 hour on the stationary bike (going 27,000 km/hr) - cycle from Peru to Perth!
Tonight's finale: A view that starts from a line of towering thunderstorms and heads all the way to the black of space.
Island off the horn of Africa. I bet that beach is beautiful.
A long pier and a full beach on the Yucatan, Mexico. The coastal city of Progreso just north of Merida.
Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. Unsure of the city, though. Perhaps Merida?
Merci Dalianne. C'est un plaisir incroyable d'etre ici, dans la station, en voyant la terre.
Yes, that's the island! In the Caribbean, not far from Belize City. Congratulations from orbit!
The Panama Canal - an incredible feat of engineering, short-cut between oceans.
If you're thumbing through an atlas or scanning Google Maps for that fish island, here's a hint: Capt Jack Sparrow sailed the sea.
If you're thumbing through an atlas or scanning Google Maps for that fish island, here's a hint: Capt Jack Sparrow sailed the sea.
A lonely road to drive; don't run out of gas. Saudi Arabia.
Limassol, Cyrpus - facing south to the sea
Sands of Namibia, a rippling texture of stark beauty from space.
- I took the sandstorm picture yesterday around midday. I think it may be Idaho, but at 5 mi/sec it's hard to be sure.
This is how to know when to look up and see the Space Station fly over your house:
Sandstorm in the Northwest US. You can see where they start. Not exactly sure where, though. Anybody down there know?
You're welcome - I hadn't realized I was on ! We don't get TV up here on the Space Station :) Regards from orbit.
I love it when islands are shaped like fish.
Just talked with Royal Cdn Air Cadets in Newfoundland, great Q&A session via ham radio. A real pleasure, since Cadets is where I started.
Road, River, Rock and Red Sand create a strange stick figure in Africa.
It must have been quite a day when this lava flowed out of the earth into the Saudi Arabian desert.
A clear morning in Scotland! I will try and take a picture during the day. Such a lovely, rugged, historic part of the world.
Good Morning Earth, from 5 miles per sec. I'll be talking with Air Cadets in Newfoundland today, if their snowstorm allows, via ham radio.
More volcano-spotting! Mt. Taranaki on New Zealand's North Island served as the backdrop in the movie The Last Samurai
Yes, I read your Tweets, and love the curiosity and insight. But it's late on a Friday here on Space Station - goodnight.
Tonight's finale: Space-age laser weapons! Okay... they're actually just pressure sensors for the toilet.
Space Tweet Central - inside my sleeping pod (see my bed?), with the laptop on Twitter.
Variety is the Spice - corn chip, salsa, mushroom pate and jalapeno, floating weightless.
Yes! The magnet aligns itself with the Earth's magnetic field, in all 3 dimensions. Slowly turns & dips as we orbit.
Yes! The magnet aligns itself with the Earth's magnetic field, in all 3 dimensions. Slowly turns & dips as we orbit.
Space Magnet - used to move colloid particles in a fluid. Any ideas for a weightless experiment with it?
Foot restraint in weightlessness, to hold me stable while carefully flying the huge Canadarm2 robot.
Living in zero-G turns even the most mundane activities, such as clipping your nails, into a potential problem:
Love being Weightless - bar coding medical samples for cold storage and return to Earth on SpaceX Dragon.
Getting weighed in weightlessness - the device uses acceleration to calculate my mass. I lost a kilo :)
Hi Juliette. Space is better than I dreamed it would be when I was 8 years old; beautiful, challenging, inspiring, magic.
Space Deadlift - using our resistive exercise machine to keep bones dense and muscles strong while weightless.
Getting ready to exercise - doing up my shoes while floating.
We are compiling the FAQs asked to on social media (incl the time zone one!). Up on our site soon.
Earth above, space below, in the Cupola - the displays we use for operating the Canadarm2 robot.
Spacewalks are limited by suit batt, O2, CO2 scrubber & by astronaut endurance. We plan for ~ 6.5 hrs, but have gone near 9.
Station Health - measuring our coolant water for ammonia, pH and general contamination.
Good Morning, Earth! Today in orbit: fluid physics resarch, cooling system checks, getting weighed, & a potential solar array problem. Fun!
Hi Jana - please set up Q&A at . You should have seen the pass we just had over the Grt Barrier Reef and NZ - beautiful!
Tonight's finale: Over 11 years after I walked in space to install it, I'm flying the Station-building robot Canadarm2.
Confederation Bridge, PEI, Canada, quite a drive in bad weather.
Charlottetown, PEI. The birthplace of Canada's Confederation, seen from orbit by a Canadian, 146 years later.
Wolfville, NS. Home of Acadia University.
Wolfville, NS. Home of Acadia University.
In honour of unofficial Canada day, here's a bit of Canadian folk music I recorded with my brother a few years back.
The Annapolis Valley, NS, Canada. A lush tended farming centre for centuries.
Southeastern Ontario in the sunglint, from Huron to Erie, from Sarnia to Windsor.
Since today is unofficial Canada day on Station, all of the photos for the day will be of places in the Great White North.
Sydney, Nova Scotia, on a clear winter's day - 9 Jan 13.
The crew of Space Station heard we are up for a Shorty Award for Tweeting about our work in orbit. Please support us!
Key West, Florida. A fun place to rent a bike and see for yourself.
Last night, a (false) fire alarm rang on board the space station. Here's how the crew trains for such emergencies:
Today, at 12:15 - 12:35 EST, the will be putting on a live webcast of my first news conference from orbit:
Space Plumber - annual overhaul of the urine hoses, valves and sensors. After I was done, it worked!
Glad you got up to see us fly over! The sun shines so brightly on the solar arrays.The whole crew is waving back at you, at Earth.
A poignant article written by my son before launch, detailing the mixed emotions of space launches for the families:
Last night the Fire Alarm rang onboard. We reacted as trained, & were glad to find it was false. Dust looks like smoke to fire detectors.
The next SpaceX Dragon resupply ship is due to arrive early March. It hovers close to ISS, we reach & grab it with Canadarm2.
Our CAPCOMs in Houston today are and , the 2 new Cdn astronauts. It will be fun talking to them all day!
Mission Control uplinked me a training session I did with . Fun to watch now, fom here:
Good Morning! Flying Canadarm to maintain skills for the capture of Dragon spacecraft, a materials test in the furnace, & a press conf.
Tonight's finale, the Moon at sunrise, with ethereal blue noctilucent clouds and a solar array glowing gold.
Correct! Like the bushfire photos, this too comes from the land down under.
Correct! Like the bushfire photos, this too comes from the land down under.
Another of the Australian bushfires, this one near Burrinjuck Dam. Look closely and you can see the flames from orbit.
Striking image of the bushfires in Australia. Streamers of smoke are visible all across the country.
Tonight there's a fluids experiment the requires as perfect weightlessness as possible. We're moving on our fingertips.
The Earth is a spinning kaleidoscope. Where in the world do you think this is?
Good Evening, Marlon, thanks. We just flew across Brazil, N to S. I took pictures, though the Amazon was cloudy. Patience :)
An island made for running laps. Off the coast of Indonesia.
If you're looking for more information on the orbit patterns of the ISS, you can find it here:
Here is a closer view of Qingdao (Tsingtao). Much easier to see the bridge in this photo.
This graphic explains high-beta very well! Less time spent on Earth’s night side for now.
Qingdao, a Northern Chinese city on the sea. You can just make out Jiaozhou Bay Bridge, the world's longest sea bridge.
We’ve been flying a “high-beta” orbit: pic shows our line of travel skimming beside dusk (or dawn). Lots more sun!
Astronaut's Breakfast - corn flakes, juice and coffee. Flakes in a bag with powdered milk, coffee through a straw.
Orbiting Medical Lab - how do you store medical waste inside your spaceship for months? In this heavily-zippered bag.
Weightless Medical Lab - Blood samples are then frozen and brought to ground in the Dragon spaceship.
- here's how we 'go' in space:
Good Morning Earth! This morning I'm refurbishing the Urine collection hydraulics, all hoses and valves. Space Plumber, on a house call.
Tonight's finale: video of my wristwatch, one of the first things that struck me when I got to orbit:
Our atmosphere has distinct layers; the troposphere and stratosphere are easily visible from orbit.
Our atmosphere has distinct layers; the troposphere and stratosphere are easily visible from orbit.
Can you cry in space? Your eyes make tears but they stick as a liquid ball. In fact, they sting a bit. So - space tears don't shed.
Humans need straight lines, nature doesn't. Indecisive river and orderly farmers, central Asia.
Glacier tongues in the Himalayas.
I'm pretty sure it's a friendly dragon.
Thunderstorm from above. What animal to you see?
Australia - the dryness creates colours and textures that make the Outback immediately recognizable from space.
Photographing Earth - in the Cupola with the big lens.
Australian beach - the tip of King Sound, near Derby in the Northwest.
Goose Bay, Happy Valley, Labrador. I flew CF-18s as an RCAF fighter pilot here.
Read about -80 deg C freezer in 's pic
Taking pictures of our planet from the cupola, a favourite pastime of astronauts aboard the ISS.
A crazed stained glass mosaic - the winter black and white of farms in central Asia.
Minus 80 degree freezer makes a cloud of ice fog. Used for preserving biological samples.
A chance to talk to everyone live from space on Thursday, answer questions. Need to find a clean new shirt:
- yes, I should sleep more on Station, but the view from the window is like a perpetual magnet, too wondrous to ignore.
Good Morning Earth! An astronaut science day of blood and urine samples, centrifuge & cold storage, colloid samples and ISS maintenance.
Tonight's finale: Newfoundland and Labrador, without zoom.
Even from 400 km up you can sense the searing dryness of southern Saudi Arabia.
Even from 400 km up you can sense the searing dryness of southern Saudi Arabia.
Hurghada, Egypt, a popular tourism and diving site on the Red Sea.
Sharm el Sheikh, at the tip of the Sinai on the Red Sea.
Greece, the west coast from Patra to Zacharo.
Here's a tune my brother Dave wrote that he and I recorded in quarantine two days before my Soyuz launch:
The Greek Island of Corfu. Places as beautiful as this are alluring for my return to Earth.
Vlore, Albania, with the Adriatic Sea currents vividly visible.
Hello Daniel. I had a big poster of the Moon above my bed. It helped inspire me to pursue my dreams.
This beautiful Italian peninsula jutting into the Adriatic Sea suddenly looked like a dog's head to me.
The heel of the boot of Italy. The port of Brindisi is clearly visible.
Corn rows of sand, tightly sculpted by wind, heat and time, Saudi Arabia.
The Solar Arrays are usually a brilliant gold, but at dawn or dusk they become an iridescent blue.
Taranto, in the arch of Italy's boot.
@tommybryars This video should answer your space waste question:
The Vacuum of Space - weekends we clean house, including vacuuming the air filters.
Space dust - dirt doesn't fall to the floor here, it gets pulled into the filters.
Space Station cameras are Nikon D2 and D3, with a variety of lenses out to 400. We can even take them out into the vacuum.
The Space Station runs on Universal Coordinated Time - which is the same as London, England. A compromise between Moscow & Houston.
If we predict that space junk may get riskily close to us, we fire the Space Station engines to change our orbit and miss it.
If we predict that space junk may get riskily close to us, we fire the Space Station engines to change our orbit and miss it.
Space Temperature: outside of Station in the shade is about -180 C, in the sun +115, inside a comfy 23 - shorts/T-shirt
We're studying bone loss, evaluating ways to fight it. Blood and urine samples are spun/frozen, evaluated on Earth later.
Good Morning from Space Station! Did blood draws this morning, a challenge in weightlessness - everything floats away. But successfull!
Tonight's finale: Not a picture. Just a sincere thank you to everyone who follows, retweets and appreciates what we've achieved so far.
Japanese rice fields tidily blanketed with snow.
Volcanoes look dramatic at dawn. They startled me when I spotted them through the lens.
. Davey Keon was a hero to me as I grew up, I've been a Leafs fan ever since, no matter what. Though there's been lots of what.
It's Orthodox Christmas Eve. We just celebrated with the Russian crewmembers, and all sang this together: . Memorable.
With the lockout finally ending and a 50-game NHL season about to begin, I am ready to cheer from orbit. Go Leafs!
Ham Radio - talking with students at CP Allen High in Bedford NS. Fun to hear the voices and questions!
Taking pix while wearing hardware for a cardiovascular experiment – always busy on the !
Noctilucent Cloud - rare super high altitude cloud, barely visible from Earth, seen at dawn in the mesosphere from ISS.
India, through a hole in the clouds. I'm not sure where - does anyone recognize the exact location?
Italian coast - like a diamond set in a ring.
Combustion is important to Earth's economy and environment. helps fundamental understanding of fire.
From orbit, water can be more striking than land, as it swirls in this Mediterranean port.
In space we snore much less - with no weight on sinuses and airways it makes for a quieter night. Many subtle changes up here.
In space we snore much less - with no weight on sinuses and airways it makes for a quieter night. Many subtle changes up here.
I've started posting some links to to test out usability to see about a potential future AMA from station:
Yes, we just came past Australia. Good evening from the Space Station! Now crossing the Pacific, and soon into the dawn.
On ISS we orbit Earth every 92 min, at a fast 8 km/s. But light goes 300,000 km/s, so our relative time is virtually unchanged.
ISS is a testbed for interplanetary travel. Water recycling is one of the technologies we're developing:
Space Furnace - for use in our materials science experiment racks for high temperature research.
Happy Birthday, Danny! Good morning from the International Space Station. Glad to have a Sunday on orbi - enjoy your day!
Dublin! Of course! The orientation fooled me, and I took the picture! Colour this astronaut embarrassed...
Tonight's Finale: I'm not quite sure! Ireland, Wales or England, through a gap in the cloud. Where is this port town?
It's hard to believe the colours of the Bahamas from space.
Key Largo, FL - home of the Aquarius underwater habitat; I commanded a crew of 6 for 2 weeks on the ocean floor here.
Delta Del Ebre, Spain - I love the echoing patterns that swirl into the sea.
-- it is from the crew quarters (sleep pod).
- we recycle our urine and sweat back into drinking water - just like on Earth :) I'll be refurbishing the processor this week.
In the meantime, I'll continue posting as many pictures of our beautiful planet as the weather, flight pattern and my schedule allow.
So what's next? What would you like to see more of? Something new? We're a lot of minds, so I expect we can create some great ideas.
In the midst of all this, I've kept up with some pretty important science: . (For more info, follow )
To recap for the newcomers, I've recorded music: , taken pictures: and tweeted Starfleet.
To recap for the newcomers, I've recorded music: , taken pictures: and tweeted Starfleet.
Ibiza, Spain - lovely in the Mediterranean Sea.
Cleveland, Toledo, Detroit, and the town where I was born, Sarnia Ontario.
I am not Spock either, but living and working in this spaceship comes pretty close. Life mirrors art. LLAP, .
El Ejido, Spain - you can easily tell where the people live, even from orbit.
- Danyelle, please tell your students Hello from orbit!, and to have a look for updates on what we're doing in space.
We live on a solar-powered spaceship, renewable energy means less fuel needs. Side benefit is the beauty of the arrays.
- today I saw a sunrise with flowing blue noctilucent clouds above. Very rare to see from Earth, ethereal beauty from here.
Just talked with the Cheetahs of CPA High! Ham radio Q&A with students as ISS flew from L Superior to mid-Atlantic. hosted!
Cagliari, Sardinia. Cool in January under scattered cloud. Some tremendous caves inside this island.
St Mary's County, MD - home of Patuxent River NAS, where I was a test pilot before becoming an astronaut.
For those of you joining in, here's a reminder about 's 'understanding' with :
Thanks! Not sure we could afford the payload room, though. I'm uploading what I'm recording in space here:
I'll be speaking with students at Charles P. Allen High in Bedford NS via ham radio shortly. Looking forward to it!
Chesapeake Bay from far away - you can even see the causeway.
Halifax NS, on a crystal clear day. The type of city where you can easily see why sailors would have settled there.
For more videos on our flight and Canadian space exploration efforts, be sure to check out 's channel as well:
The lighting and weather has been wrong on the passes so far. I'll keep looking, though!
A couple of new (earth-bound, for now) videos have been added to the youtube channel. I hope you like them!
Wesley, we've talked about you being on the bridge. I believe you're needed in Engineering. :)
Wesley, we've talked about you being on the bridge. I believe you're needed in Engineering. :)
This week I'm on a science diet studying bone loss - how what you eat can affect your skeleton:
Here's the "Captain's Blog" of the weekly work we're doing on the Space Station: ,
Neil & I would've tweeted from the moon if we could have but I would prefer to tweet from Mars. Maybe by 2040
One last picture for the night: Casablanca. Here's lookin' at you.
The very northern tip of Newfoundland with clouds rolling in. Narrow strait across to Labrador from here.
Baie des Chaleurs, New Brunswick, Canada. The name means 'bay of warmth', but the fingers of ice disagree.
Kiev, Ukraine - an historic major crossing place of water, rail and road.
Rocher Perce - Perce Rock - Gaspe, Quebec. A famous tourism site, looks different from up here!
With posting about our space comms, all we need is to beam in and we'd have an away team! :)
The priorities are crew health, vehicle health, work/science & then personal pursuits; I take photos & play guitar when I can!
Vibration isn't normally damped much by gravity, but the guitar itself can resonate longer up here since it's floating free.
- we exercise 2 hours/day and thus maintain bone & muscle strength. The work struggle is often with leverage - your feet fly up!
- we take it a bit easier on weekends, though tomorrow I have 7 scheduled work events & medical data gathering. Time is precious.
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: TGIF - this week did cardiac research, fluid physics experiments, sampled atmosphere, collected microbial growth & kept the labs humming.
So much of the World's beauty is simply art itself.
Weightlessness confuses our balance system; the body thinks maybe it's been poisoned, so vomiting. We take meds 'til we adapt
Weightlessness confuses our balance system; the body thinks maybe it's been poisoned, so vomiting. We take meds 'til we adapt
. The Great Wall of China is nearly impossible to see with the naked eye. The colour is too similar to that of the ground around it
These mountains near Sochi, Russia remind me somehow of corduroy pillows.
Ostrich skin of the Sahara. Change your viewing angle and Earth can quickly appear other worldly.
It looks like and are correct! The photo is of Tulsa, OK. Thanks!
Took this picture of a large US SW city, but can't seem to figure out which one. Any budding geographers out there?
Great Belt Bridge, Denmark, connecting Zealand and Fyn. Straight lines stand out against nature when viewed from space.
I'm proud of being Canadian, but after yesterday's twitter conversation am starting to question wearing this red shirt.
I'm in orbit, working onboard ISS for 5 months, until mid-May. One fortunate guy! For interviews, please contact .
We are a fast-moving bright star. Thanks for looking up!
- Good Morning! Yes, I am playing a little space guitar, before bed and after work on my weekends:
For our mission experiments in detail, follow . They keep good track of our busy ISS laboratories up here.
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: ¡Hola! Good morning from the International Space Station. A full day of work: science experiments, repair, exercise & wonder.
Tonight's finale: Montreal - home of the Canadian Space Agency (), just visible at the bottom of the photo.
Winnipeg, Manitoba: Home of the (currently idle) Jets. Portage and Main are visible if you know where to look.
Edmonton Alberta - the North Saskatchewan River looks serpentine, writhing through the capital city.
Calgary on a clear winter's day. Fewer clouds in this shot than the last - 2 Jan 13.
The last time and I met was in another dimension - 2D. (From contest - …)
Space Horizon - from a Pacific thunderstorm to infinity.
St John NB - beautiful in the sunlit snow. Taken from the International Space Station, 2 Jan 13
St John NB - beautiful in the sunlit snow. Taken from the International Space Station, 2 Jan 13
Seattle WA. Look carefully, you can see Pike Place Market.
Please tell Lauren that I decided to become an astronaut when I was 9, after watching the first 2 humans walk on the Moon.
The best part is being able to directly share the art & wonder of this new human place with everyone, worldwide.
Like a Hole Punch - confetti of farms using central irrigation in the American Southwest. Jan 2, 2013.
Yes, Standard Orbit, Captain. And we're detecting signs of life on the surface.
Chicago, 2 January 2013. I'm trying to find the time to post some more Canadian views from above - keep posted!
Mojave Desert and the lake beds of Edwards AFB where I attended test Pilot School, and where the Shuttle first landed.
Australian Wildfires - took this photo of many smoky fires on 2 Jan 13.
Those curious about our mission research in detail should follow . There is a lot of work to be done, and they keep good track.
The Golden Horseshoe snowily wrapping the end of Lake Ontario on the 2nd of January.
Los Angeles from Earth orbit, New Years Day.
Great effort by our hockey juniors. I couldn't see the game, but a medal is not the only thing they can feel pride about in this tournament.
Was that you waving? Thanks! I wave back to the whole family. Australia's space colours and textures are beautifully unmistakable
Josh - my voice is the one with the moustache :)
Playing guitar in the ISS Cupola before New Years, seeing the world. In space, right side up is a relative term.
Here's the view looking through to the US Lab from inside the Russian FGB at our Robonaut in the distance.
- we go around the world every 90 minutes, but choose to be on London time - splits the difference between Houston & Moscow.
- I won't get to watch the WJ hockey real-time, but I'll get the scores and see the highlights. Go Canada!
- Lights-out on Space Station is 21:30 to 06:00 London time, but I've been staying up a bit late looking at the World.
- Lights-out on Space Station is 21:30 to 06:00 London time, but I've been staying up a bit late looking at the World.
- the guitar is a Larrivee Parlour, small enough to fit in a Shuttle locker. It tunes the same as on Earth & is sweet to play!
- our crew is on Space Station until mid-May, a couple thousand more orbits of our World. Fascinating place to be.
Good Morning from Earth orbit! Breakfast is rehydrated Cornflakes, dried milk, bag of peaches & instant black coffee. Time to get to work.
The Pyramids at Giza, Egypt - can you see them?
- our Space Station cameras are Nikon D2s and D3s, with a variety of lenses. We even take them outside into the vacuum with us.
Polka-Dot Desert - centre-point irrigation farms in Egypt. A life necessity viewed from a stellar vantage point.
- thanks Lee. Please say Hi to my brother Phil, wife Teresa, hockey-playing boys Taylor & Andrew. They live there in Paradise.
Latakia, Syria - deceptively calm and beautiful, strife-torn on the shore on the sea. Peaceful from such a distance.
Sands of the Sahara - starkly beautiful, a harshly serene and unmistakable part of the Earth's skin. Just stunning.
Boston in the snow - taken from the International Space Station, January 2, 2013 at 10:15 AM
St John's, NF - catching some winter sun through the cloud. Taken from the International Space Station on 2 Jan 13.
Halifax NS, dressed in snow. Beautiful both on earth and from space - taken on the second day of 2013.
- I'm honoured. Thank you for helping see the World with me. The unending beauty of it is mesmerizing, especially from here.
Poti on the Black sea - you can clearly see the fishing boats and the loads of silt washing out to sea.
- I'm cheering for the Canadian Junior Hockey team from here in orbit! (and I hear Russian and US cheers here too). Go Canada!
Batumi Beach on the Black Sea. Keeping up with these photos is hard work. I hope nobody minds that I've got some more!
Two lakes, close but very different. Lake Hazar and Keban Reservoir, Turkey.
Turkish Coast near Ceyhan, on 2 Jan. Fishing boats and piers along an interesting landscape.
A view of the Suez Canal, as it opens into the Mediterranean. A great mix of nature and powerful human engineering.
A view of the Suez Canal, as it opens into the Mediterranean. A great mix of nature and powerful human engineering.
Haifa, Israel, on 2 Jan 13. Interesting how well you can see the city planning decisions when viewing from space.
Robonaut - testing human-machine combined capability. Today we brought it to life on Space Station.
- on the Space Station we recycle our urine and sweat back into drinking water. Same as on Earth, just more ... personal.
I'm very proud to have my country's flag on the wall of the Space Station, especially in such honourable company.
Testing the Air - open one of these and they suck some air in, for later analysis on the ground.
This vital equipment is used in both the US and Russian sections of the Space Station. Do you recognize what it is?
Inside my Sleep Pod - it serves as my bedroom, recording studio, and twitter zone while on the Space Station.
Space Station Toilet - it uses airflow, and solids/liquids are done separately. Note the ironic reading material.
The Russian-built parts of the Space Station are wallpapered with Velcro. Very handy when weightless.
@Honey_Bunny_ We have multiple smoke alarms in every module. Our problem is that we can't leave the building - so masks and tox sensors.
tweet.retweet_count: 1 time " > 1 Retweet

tweet.tweet_content: If you smell smoke, grab one of these and turn it on. They measure toxic gas levels, so we know when to take off masks.
The glove box protects us from dangerous experiments. Important in a closed environment like a Space Station.
- this is my 3rd space voyage. I helped build Mir Space Station in '95, and to build Canadarm2 in '01.
- the location on Canada's Prairie is the wide Qu'Appelle Valley, near Lumsden and Craven, SK.
- takes about 4 hrs to get fully dressed to go outside for a spacewalk in the big white spacesuit. It's a 1-person spaceship.
- takes about 4 hrs to get fully dressed to go outside for a spacewalk in the big white spacesuit. It's a 1-person spaceship.
- one of the fun parts of weightlessness is that you can put your pants on 2 legs at a time :) Just float into them!
- onboard the International Space Station we go around the Earth 16 times per day; that's 16 sunrises & sunsets, each one lovely
- inside our space helmets we have a foam pad to push our nose into to clear our ears. I also use it to scratch my nose :)
Thanks Heidi Jane! Music is even more important to me while away from Earth. Good Morning from the Space Station!
Andros Island, a lesser populated island with some great diving. At the bottom center you can see the island's runway.
The beauty of the Bahamas is surreal; every blue that exists. Taken on New Year's Day, 2013 from the Space Station.
After working hard on Station and sharing the experience as much as possible, it is nice to take a moment to relax.
- the beauty of Twitter and SoundCloud is everybody gets a backstage pass :) And this is one amazing stage.
Thanks Jennifer. You should see Canada the way I can see it from here. We arc up and across, coast-to-coast in 10 minutes!
Calgary emerging from the snow on New Year's Eve, with clouds beginning to roll in overhead.
Sackville NB, home of University - on the last day of 2012.
Mt. Vesuvius, Italy, on New Year's Day, 2013. Looks a little like a remainder from earth's difficult puberty years. :)
For everyone who asked, the Space Station runs on Universal Coordinated Time, or Greenwich - the same time zone as London, England.
For everyone who asked, the Space Station runs on Universal Coordinated Time, or Greenwich - the same time zone as London, England.
Space Experiment - close-up of colloid particles responding to magnetic field, making a fluid behave like a solid.
Ultrasound Lab - the rig we used to measure how Tom's heart is changing and adapting without gravity, like rapid aging.
Mad Space Scientist - researching colloid behavior in the microgravity glovebox with a sensor bolted to my head.
- thank you, David. Yes, after looking all day, we saw fireworks over S America! Hard with orbital mechanics vs midnight :)
Happy 2013 from orbit! Let's use Twitter to communicate like never before, see the year and the world through each others' eyes.
As the clock strikes midnight Station time, we'll be floating over the Indian Ocean. From our crew of 6 to the whole world - Happy New Year!
Quebec City - La Ville de Quebec, le 31 Dec 12 a midi, de la station spatial internationale.
Tadoussac, Quebec - a great place for whale watching. Photo taken at Noon on 31 Dec 12.
Kitchener-Waterloo in the snow, taken from the Space Station on the last day of 2012.
Cambridge Ontario in the snow, on the last day of 2012.
PEI on the last day of 2012, as seen from a window of the Space Station. (11:00 AM, 31 Dec)
The Alps are beautiful, even from orbit. Taken on the last day of 2012 from the International Space Station.
Like a pointed toe into icy water - Long Point, Lake Winnipeg, from orbit. (30 Dec 12)
The Space Station followed this valley across the Prairie - 30 Dec 12. Recognize where it is?
The Rockies are beautiful, and very much so from orbit - What an amazing view! (photo taken 30 Dec 12)
Earth, Moon and Soyuz: Kevin Ford took this picture as we approached Station last week. Science fiction into fact.
- I waved :) It's New Years, so we're waving at the whole world, and looking hard for fireworks as the clocks sequence through 12:00
Soyuz in the Desert - coming up to dock with the station with a view of the Sahara below.
just spent an hour imaging Tom's heart with ultrasound with an expert on Earth guiding - learning how hearts age, adapt and stay healthy
For more station sounds, I've created a set on of various noises recorded throughout the average day:
For those of you wondering how I could sleep with all the noise, here's the volume of my dampened sleep station:
This has a human tissue simulator in it, and measures cosmic radiation dose and direction. Understanding the universe.
Good Morning Earth! Today is my Fitness Exam, cardiac ultrasound research, experiments with colloids, & Circadian Rhythm expt. Fun on ISS!
Like a torpedo tube, this airlock in the Japanese Lab allows us to put experiments out into the vacuum of space.
Toehold in Space - when operating robot hand controllers while weightless, it's good to have your feet stable.
I'm heading to the Cupola right now for a pass across the whole of Canada. Hoping for breaks in the cloud. Wish me and my camera luck!
Festooned with antennae, our Soyuz, just a minute before docking with the Space Station. Just beautiful!
Barrie, ON in snow - how it looked from ISS, today, 30 Dec at 12:40.
Toronto in snow - how it looked from the ISS today, 30 Dec at 12:35 local.
Montreal South Shore, in snow (and a trace of cloud) - how it looked today from ISS, 30 Dec at 12:40.
Ottawa in Snow - how it looked today from ISS - 30 Dec at 12:40
Ottawa in Snow - how it looked today from ISS - 30 Dec at 12:40
Kingston, ON in snow - how it looked from ISS today, 30 Dec at 12:40.
- our speed to orbit earth is 8 km/s, 5 mi/sec. To leave Earth we'd need to go 41% faster, which would take a lot of fuel.
- math in public: 16 orbits/day times 365 days = 5,840 days (& nights) per Earth year!
Open the window cover and you suddenly see the harshly-lit Station against the velvet blackness of forever.
- viewing Earth is THE favourite astronaut hobby. I think the coolest things are lightning, the Bahamas, volcanoes and aurorae.
Ultimate Leg Press Machine - from Europe, called MARES, we're going to try and put this together this week.
Space Laboratory - looking down the length of the Japanese Lab, called 'Kibo' (meaning 'hope').
- on Space Station we don't do laundry; it's too water-intensive. We wear our clothes until dirty, then throw them away.
Like on any ship at sea, stowage space is tight. We fill unused areas with bags - these mostly have clothes and towels.
- What motivates me, at my core, is the desire to use the very limits of my ability to accomplish things I believe in.
Space Medical Emergency - our Crew Restraint platform with straps to hold the patient in place. Practiced it yesterday.
- I get nervous when I'm unprepared, so I've been training for this for the past 20 years (& preparing since I was 9)
- I get nervous when I'm unprepared, so I've been training for this for the past 20 years (& preparing since I was 9)
- 2 Soyuz & 2 Progress are docked. In Feb we swap a Progress, in March a Dragon & swap a Soyuz, April a Cygnus, & May an ATV.
Earth is hit by ~100 tons of meteorites/day. Progress & almost all rocks burn up completely, becoming the dust seen in a sunbeam
Space Dumpster - the Progress resupply ship is slowly filling with trash for eventual jettison and burn-up on re-entry.
- you've been photoshopped onto the Space Station treadmill, so it's official. Now it's up to you!
- on ISS we're running ~130 different experiments, from Earth climate to human physiology to collecting high-energy particles.
- Please tell your daughter that Christmas and Santa have magic about them, and that he found us, even here :)
Space Oven - our suitcase-sized food warmer. Tuck a pouch under the strap, Velcro shut, wait 10 minutes - hot food!
- Skier. I used to race downhill & teach skiing in Ontario. But there's no finer hill than Sunshine on a sunny day!
- yes, mistype, sorry, D2s and D3s. Film spoils quickly up here with the radiation.
- I agree, Brian, the beauty washes around us unstoppably up here. I've been playing '39 on the space guitar - a favorite tune!
- yes, I sure have, they are singng in my headphones right now, in fact :)
- nous avons 4 gyroscopes enormes pour controler l'orientation de l'ISS avec electricite, & propulsion si necessaire
- yes, we have iPads onboard. In fact, I used GarageBand to record Jewel in the Night with the iPad's built-in mic.
Space Printer: we try to stay wireless, but some things are better printed. We keep our spare paper in the Ziploc bag.
Quick Getaway - these locking clamps help hold our Soyuz to ISS, but can be swiftly released for rapid evacuation.
Quick Getaway - these locking clamps help hold our Soyuz to ISS, but can be swiftly released for rapid evacuation.
Floating free, testing the human neurovestibular system as it adapts without gravity. Insight into how our bodies work.
Lunch in a Pouch - this is Fiesta Chicken. Very tasty. You can see my long spoon velcroed to the table.
- we're working on it, emm :) But for now 28,000 kph is the best we can do.
- we're going 8 kilometres per second, but our internet is pretty slow. A space irony :)
We exercise for two hours a day to fight bone & muscle loss. The view while bench pressing is particularly distracting.
- we use primarily Nikon F2s and F3s, with a variety of lenses. We even take them out on spacewalks, into the hard vacuum.
- the high-res versions of all the photos I Tweet are at the NASA and/or CSA websites. ,
Docked to the mother ship - our Soyuz and an unmanned Progress resupply ship. Great view from the Cupola windows
- I'd love to get a copy to watch up here on the Space Station!
It strikes me as funny when I log-in to record my exercise on the treadmill. Guest?
It strikes me as funny when I log-in to record my exercise on the treadmill. Guest?
Brain Waves - today's science experiment looked at neurovestibular changes without gravity.
- I'm Tweeting from a regular laptop; the real magic is how my Tweet gets from here all the way to you :) Amazing NASA network.
: in weightlessness you don't need a guitar strap, but when you set it down it floats away! The white patches are Velcro :)
- Daniel, there's no need for extra stimulation at 8 km/sec and 400 km up. I've never been higher in my life :)
@nachofras - we have an emergency medical kit onboard, are all trained as EMTs, Tom is a doctor, and I trained in Emerg in a hospital.
