tweet.tweet_content: - when I turn upside-down and move across the ceiling and walls, I feel free, like Spiderman. Except - this is REAL!
- yes, I'm intending to record an entire CD's-worth of original music while here. It's a very inspiring place. I'm writing daily
- the guitar here needs tuning often depending on the humidity of where it's stored, but my GarageBand tuner makes it easy :)
- the guitar here needs tuning often depending on the humidity of where it's stored, but my GarageBand tuner makes it easy :)
Wiring up the condensate transfer pump. Without gravity, cables and hoses are like live snakes.
After running on the treadmill, held down by bungees, I almost forgot I was weightless. It was like a gift to unhook and ... fly.
- I'm drinking Kona Black coffee from a bag through a straw as I type this :)
- we live and work on Greenwich time - same as the folks in London, England. A compromise between Houston & Moscow.
Good morning from Boxing Day on the International Space Station! We get up at 06:00: 6 men, 2 bathrooms, short commute to work.
I was asked by many to record the ambient noise of the space station. Here is what the US lab of the ISS sounds like:

A week ago I was on earth looking at the stars. Today I am looking down thinking what a beautiful world we have.
Happy holidays to you all.
Running Weightless - my first-ever session on the T2 treadmill. I felt like a newborn calf, clumsy and awkward.
Music on High - playing Christmas carols while floating over the eastern Mediterranean. Miraculous.
Our stockings are hung by the Node 3 hatch with care, in hope that St Nicklaus has a big red spacesuit.
Inside the Space Station - closet space is limited. Some modules are pretty full.
I recorded my first song on station yesterday. Here is the non-youtube version:
Sampling history: Here's some of the first original music written for and performed on the international space station:
Our tree is up – on the ceiling! The beauty of a weightless Christmas.
Happiness Is ... arriving at a Space Station and finding your name on a locker :)
Having a closet with no gravity is a challenge - hard to keep track of where everything is!
Having a closet with no gravity is a challenge - hard to keep track of where everything is!
Mission Patches - a wall of history in the Space Station Node 1, including my last time here, 11 years ago.
Look what I found on Space Station! It's now in my sleeping quarters, nice & quiet for recording.
Food on Space Station - a pantry full of goodness, ready to rehydrate and eat.
Fathead Astronaut - being weightless means there’s no gravity to push your blood to your feet, so your head swells up.
This brave little ship carried us from Earth to orbit, now safely nestled into Station. Ready when we need her to fly.
From Chris' Son - The next tradition is the blessing of the crew by Orthodox priests. The crew ended up dripping wet.
We celebrated launch&docking of with these cool handmade cookies that a guest brought to Moscow.
From Chris' Son: The cosmonauts have a stunning number of superstitions and traditions. Here's the signing of the door:
Space Station Bedroom - sleeping bag on right, laptop on left, moving my luggage in. A very small dorm room.
Man What A Ride! After a roaring, hammering slingshot ride on the rocket & 2 days maneuvering, we are safely docked! ISS is huge!
Soyuz Food - simple dried and canned food, came in a very cute bag. I like the little rocketship.
Space Station! Floating free, buoyed up even more by my smile :)
A special thanks to for taking care of the family during the launch. You've done a superb job, and we're extremely grateful.
Hatch opened, crew inside. Welcome to the ISS, dad.
Jettisoning the boosters, as seen from the ground. You can see them as four steady points of light around the Soyuz.
Yury Romanenko has spent over 430 days in space. Surprisingly, he's incredibly down to earth.
Crewmate Roman's father Yury was also a Cosmonaut and has twice been designated as a Hero of the Soviet Union:
The shadow of the cloud the launch created was very impressive in the otherwise perfectly clear sky of Kazakhstan.
We have liftoff!
We have liftoff!
The family is back from Baikonur, waiting patiently in Moscow for tomorrow's docking. We are all looking forward to the tweets from space!
There is nothing I have experienced in my life that even comes close to a space launch by a family member. Our language needs more words.
Evan, Chris' son, will be tweeting while Chris is in the Soyuz, but once he reaches the ISS he will be able to access internet again
A few hours ago, a Soyuz rocket launched to space with three men on board. Those who witnessed it will never forget:
The reality of being an astronaut's son:
RT : A very human essay by Evan Hadfield (Chris Hadfield's son) via -
Watching & blast to orbit with family was incredible! You feel rocket's power. Can't wait to try it someday!
The Soyuz launch was an incredibly emotional experience. Godspeed, Dad. Your achievement has literally brought us all to tears.
So everyone can see launch photos and other info while I'm waiting to dock with the ISS, my son will be posting here for the next few days.
A Little Launch Music - same as 11 years ago, I played just before heading to space. Day to Day, by Stan Rogers.
Just took my last hot shower for 5 months. I lingered ...
- my answer:

tweet.tweet_content: - merci, Marc! Sun's rising here in Baikonur, the clear cold morning of launch day. Crew just had breakfast, we're excited!
Making Music in Quarantine - brother Dave's blog of our time together:
One last kiss before I go - love under glass with my wife. It's launch morning, I slept well, feel great. 10 hrs until!
Excited to attend 's launch viewing event of a Russian Soyuz Vehicle with aboard.
The hi res of the map is now in the "Launch" section of our Soyuz Experience:
MT : Cdn Astronaut Training in (and in Russian) on CBC The National HD version
Tomorrow we light 's rocket & launch him to station! You can watch it here at 7:12am 19 Dec.
Haircut for Space Travel - Tatiana got cleared to come into Quarantine. Next barber will be Tom with a vacuum cleaner.
My son and daughter-in-law got me a great Christmas present. The whole crew loves it!
Where to watch Launch tomorrow? Will be hosted by 3 Cdn astronauts (David, Bob & CSA President Steve MacLean)
- please tell your students: not only is spaceflight a wonderful experience, but you DO get ~5 cm taller! (until gravity again)

tweet.tweet_content: Feel what Launch is like - a couple videos worth watching:
Quarantine Guitar - got medical clearance to play some songs with brother Dave, just 24 hrs 'til launch. Very special.
Gagarin flew in a spaceship called Vostok (East), & during descent ejected, to land under parachute. That was Plan A.
Prime/backup crew press conference behind quarantine glass.'Excited about challenges, science & perspective'
My brother and I wrote what it feels like to be here, now:
Our rocket rode to the launch pad on a rail. Fill 'er up, please, we have a long trip planned.
My Soyuz Checklists - from L to R: Launch/Entry, Malfunctions, Orbital Flight. Colour-coded for easy spaceflight.
Must watch: Tonight on - Bob McDonald's documentary on & his historic space launch on Wednesday
How cold was it at rocket roll-out this morning? My son took this portrait of his wife.
This morning they rolled out the rocket for launch. What a beautiful and moving start to the day.
- we need to make the most of each day of this life, to celebrate wonder, endure tragedy, and honour & care for each other.
Crew at Breakfast - with our new Expedition shirts shining. Roman is going to be a hoot to fly with :)
Soyuz Rescue - 8 planes, 13 helicopters and a ship wait along our launch track, from here to Japan, just in case.
My kids brought me a Yule Tree that plugs into a USB port. Perfect for the Christmas traveler who has to pack light.
Up early, can hear the wind blowing. It's 30 below as they roll the rocket on its carrier train to the launch pad. Stay warm, launch guests!
Just watched the Station fly over, with my family, after celebrating Christmas together in Quarantine (not too close!). Very special.
Soyuz Docking Sim on a Laptop - what we train with in Quarantine; left joystick is for moving, right for turning.
It takes these 32 engines to get these 3 humans safely above the air. And that's just the start.
- we have a box of Christmas decoration on the Space Station, just like in many basements and garages. Including a small tree :)
Early Christmas - prime & backup crews at the Cosmodrome museum. It's beginning to look a lot like ... spaceflight!
Four days before launch, gives us an inside look at City’s Centrifuge:
- thanks, Jeremy, for taking care of my family during launch and while I'm away from Earth. I owe you.
What are 10 Songs you'd Take to Space with you? Here's my list, plus Ed Robertson's and Bob McDonald's:
How Astronauts Relax in Quarantine - for the real Russian billiards players, how's my technique?
Maybe today I won't be running outside...
Spinning Chair - Luca Parmitano, my immensely talented back-up, on the vestibular trainer. Smiling at the joyride.
Spinning Chair - Luca Parmitano, my immensely talented back-up, on the vestibular trainer. Smiling at the joyride.
Quirky Space Tour Guide:
Includes , and Romanenko. Launch Dec. 19 MT : Exp34 crew poses for pictures
Good and Bad Magic of Spaceflight - insightful article by
This Russian phone is for calling the Fire Department. Or 1957, I'm not sure which :)
At the edge of the desert here in quarantine. Looks warm, but is 15 below with a stiff wind. The river is freezing up.
Hatch to Another World - what it looks like to climb into a Soyuz spaceship. We then crawl down into our seats.
In front of the tree Yuri Gagarin planted when I was 2, here in Quarantine at the Baikonur Cosmodrome. Cool!
Astronaut Greatest Hits: a good summary of Q & As from the Ask Me Anything I did last night.

To those with questions, my reddit AMA has begun:
I'm looking forward to answering as many as possible!
Spaceflight and the secret to aging. Perhaps a weightless fountain of youth. Interesting Cdn research:
1 week to go - took this at 18:12 on 12/12/12, so this is how the sky will look at launch. Our engines will be bright!
Spaceship Cover-Up. Soyuz slides into its launch shroud, protects us from the weather, gets jettisoned during ascent.
Pressure Suit - I trust my life to this bubble of plexiglass, hand-sewn suit & the craftspeople who put it together.
There is an unbelievable thrill in getting into your own spaceship. This is the same hatch we'll use on the launch pad.
Space Medical Experiments - what we do, and what is done to us:
Flag raising ceremony In Baikonur. All other crewmembers had their own Country, so I raised Kazakhstan's flag.
Aliens Exist! At least on this Christmas tree :) Good morning to all, from Kazakhstan, 1 week to launch.
Nice video from : boldly go where no Canadian has gone before
Nice video from : boldly go where no Canadian has gone before
Don't miss my upcoming pre-flight AMA on Reddit, this Thursday Dec. 13th at 11:00 a.m. EST (22:00 Kazakh time). Straight from quarantine!
Spaceship Cover - they're sliding this aero shroud over our Soyuz; protects us as we ram up through the atmosphere.
Alicia scheduled every day of our lives & training for the past 2.5+ yrs, world-wide. We thank & honour you, Duchess!
Canadian astronaut prepares for historic mission: Bob McDonald explains - CBC TV video
- quarantine food is great! Very careful with our health, but also delicious. Today we had Kazakh manti.
4 Flags over Kazakhstan - I was proud to raise the Maple Leaf, now flying above our Quarantine here in Baikonur.
New Shirts - gifts for my Rendezvous and Life Support instructors as we grill shashlik here in Quarantine.
- no shoes: our Sokhol pressure suits have built-in feet, like a toddler's pajamas :)

tweet.tweet_content: Dressed for Success - note the grey soft leather boots. We only wear them as far as the launch pad; very low mileage.
- yes, excited, disbelieving, thrilled, deliberately subdued, happily competent, and ... ready.
- it was chosen by Roman's 9-yr-old daughter Anastasia, for a character named Klyopa on a Russian TV show called ABCD-E :)
This small clown doll will hang in our Soyuz by a string. When it starts floating weightless, we are safely in orbit :)
Enemas and Barf Bags - the less glamorous side of spaceflight :) From today's medical briefings in quarantine.
Space Accidents - 1-page summary from X-15 to Vostok to ISS. Worth understanding.
Quarantine Run - nice day in Kazakhstan, so Tom and I ran along the line of trees honouring all flown cosmonauts.
Cosmonaut Breakfast in Quarantine: omelet, bacon, mustard, red caviar.
Cosmonaut Breakfast in Quarantine: omelet, bacon, mustard, red caviar.
Inside the Spaceship - Tom, Roman & I in our Soyuz during Fitcheck. It's small, efficient & very familiar.
Survive the fire - this Soyuz capsule will protect us as we re-enter the Earth's atmosphere in May - a human meteorite
Astronaut Doing Cartwheels - nice article :
3 men in a Soyuz. Few things better than being inside your own spaceship for the 1st time! That new spaceship smell :)
Standing between Velentina Tereshkova (1st woman in space) & Alexei Leonov (1st space walker). I am honoured.
Glass-Nosed Airplane flew us to Baikonur. I crawled into the nose and visited with the navigator. He had a GPS iPad.
When you board the bus to go to space, this is what it looks like. Star City, this morning.
Welcome to Kazakhstan! I wasn't expecting gold pom-poms, but I like them :)
Our crew, Russian transport plane in background, soon to be headed south-east together to Kazakhstan.
First vehicle on the road to space. A Police escort doesn't really help during Russian rush hour :)
Gagarin Goodbye - Yuri and I wave farewell to Star City. Off to Baikonur!
Nice article in Canadian papers today:
One last look at the Star City church before we go. And its snowblower.
Star City Snowman - you can tell you're North when the shadows are this long at noon. We leave for Baikonur tomorrow!
Young Astronauts - Jacob & Jacob did an excellent school project, and are supporting our launch, mustachioed!
Yo-Yo Ma and the Flat Astronaut. Download yours and take me around the world!
I just did several Skype interviews from my room in Star City with Canadian and NASA media. Here's one:
I just did several Skype interviews from my room in Star City with Canadian and NASA media. Here's one:
Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield prepares to take charge of ISS. CBC TV video:
How do you give CPR without gravity to hold you down? Like this!
Russian Soyuz patch that our crew wears on our left shoulder. I like its bold simplicity - like the rocket!
It's going to be cold at launch on the 19th - it will look something like this.
- our launch is 19 Dec at 18:12 Kazakh time, so 08:12 AM in St. John, NB. Watch live online at .
Bobblehead Astronauts - each of us now has the complete set. Not much good in weightlessness, but fun on Earth :)
Chris Hadfield Public School - well done, Hawks! Good luck at the regional playoffs!
4 Google 4 space. I want to ride on this galaxy train! Designed by 11 grader. Check out today ONLY.
Cosmonaut Tree Ornament - it's beginning to look a lot like spaceflight :)
Red Square, Moscow - the big 'ГУМ' department store has a skating rink out front, Bing Crosby carols playing
Soyuz Rocket motors, close-up. Glad to see all of them worked from French Guiana yesterday!
Our Sun, in perspective: 386 billion billion megawatts of power. My spaceship seems suddenly even littler.
Soyuz Rocket: external boosters, lower and upper stages, our capsule nestled inside, on top. This IS rocket science.
Soyuz Spaceship: engines/fuel underneath, living quarters on top, Entry capsule in the middle. Simple, elegant, safe.
Beautiful NASA JSC campus!
Russian Paparazzi - how the Press Conference looked through our eyes.
Russian Paparazzi - how the Press Conference looked through our eyes.
Passed our exams! Paying respects to Gagarin at the Kremlin wall. One of many great Russian space flight traditions.
Red Square video: laying flowers at the Kremlin wall, honouring Yuri Gagarin & others, on a cold Moscow day
Signing chosen envelope of sim malfunctions: O2 control, VHF txmtr, RNDZ radar, fuel supply press, Entry control
laying flowers on Gagarin's grave on Red Square.
and exp 35 crew on Red square in Moscow. Old Russian space tradition
And here's a version that my very talented son Evan made :)
Russian crew poster. Happy to be cast as Tommy Lee Jones :)
signing guest book in the office of Yuri in Star City
It's worth flying in space just to inspire someone to make these cookies.
Our very last sim went great - now qualified for spaceflight, a very good feeling :) Tomorrow, ceremony on Red Square
The Final Sim - the biggie, 8 hours in the Soyuz where they throw everything at us. We're ready!
Russian Simulator Reflection - the ceiling in the Star City Space Station sim hall. You can see my camera flash.
Space Buff: Lifting Weights in Weightlessness - nice article in the Wall Street Journal by author :
Would you leave Earth for a year? These two men are going to:
What I'm thinking at this point, pre-launch - video: , transcript:
Snow in Star City as we start final exam week - reviews all day today, Station Tuesday, Soyuz Wednesday. Wish us luck!
- all water on Earth is recycled sewage, if you think about it. Dinosaurs were big, and were here for a long, long time :)

tweet.tweet_content: Great link via bullet would travel forever if shot in space
The World is Beautiful. An interview with -
Good guesses! It's for 'weighing' us in 0G; we grab on tight, release a latch, & see how fast it springs up & down
Saturday Quiz - what is the white shovel-shaped thing by Tom's feet, here in the Russian part of Space Station?
Less than one month from flight. Will have "finals" all week. Final suit fit check shown here. Still feels great!
Russian TV video of our cockpit fire - and the crew handover on orbit.
- there is no such thing as a small fire in a spacecraft :)
Fire in the Soyuz sim - you can see how thick the smoke gets, makes it very realistic, excellent training!
- the key to not being nervous IS to talk of such things, in deep detail, until we understand every risk & action. It's calming
What if the rocket blows up on the pad? Slide down the escape pole to the underground bunker!
Sarnia lit up - the town where I was born is going to turn the lights on for me, to see and photograph from orbit.
As an astronaut you have to train to wear many types of headgear. Our instructor got the best hat.
This is a thoughtful gesture from NASA. I hope to hear from you while we orbit during the Holidays!
Like your big sister showing you around - Suni's video tour of Station just hours before she came home.
Nice photo from today - after 4 long, hot hours in the Soyuz sim. We made it back to Earth :)
Just passed the hardest of all Soyuz final exams, manual docking. It feels great! Two exams left.
Cool Astronaut Glasses - we can adjust the prescription with the little knob on the top. And repel suitors.
Cool Astronaut Glasses - we can adjust the prescription with the little knob on the top. And repel suitors.
TV Special on our upcoming spaceflight - the visuals and people tell the story, even if you don't speak French.
Today is Launch minus 30 days to 's mission. Get ready by learning a bit about it:
Crew who Fell to Earth. Suni/Yuri/Aki safely back - can see where the parachute dragged the Soyuz through the snow.
Time to Land - Aki & Suni in their Soyuz underwear, landing 1 hr before the Kazakh dawn. Just talked to them by phone!
Video from Kazakhstan - it will be colder when we're there for launch next month (Dec19) as Prime Crew!
Testing, testing, 1 2 3...
Testing, testing, 1 2 3...
Back to Earth - they land 1 hr before dawn in rural Kazakhstan. “: Preparing for our return tomorrow ”
Time Machine - Hubble & Spitzer telescopes show us the very edges of what is out there.
Seeing in Space - weightlessness affects our vision. Aki & Suni ultrasound his eyeball to help understand why
@Honey_Bunny_ - that Soyuz door doesn't exist in the real vehicle. We enter through the top.

tweet.tweet_content: Thanks for following, Beth Nielsen Chapman. I love your voice and music! All my best from Star City, Russia.
Passed the Exam - crewmate climbing out of the Soyuz sim after we aced our Manual Rendezvous test
Where will the Soyuz land? Crew's getting ready, touchdown Sunday 7:54 PM Houston time.
Space Spanx - the g-suits that Suni & Aki wear under their pressure suits (back to Earth via Soyuz this weekend)
Flying Canadarm for the very 1st time, on the aft flight deck of Atlantis in the immense blackness of space
Wallace&Gromit got nothing on us! When I saw this countermeasure system, I couldn't think of anything else.
Google's Doodle today shows the Canadarm and a space walker - nice! “@scottmahoney94@CanadianSpace ”
Rocketship explained very simply :) “: Up Goer Five! via ”
What to pack for Spaceflight? When I left Houston this was my luggage. In the Soyuz I can only bring 1.5 kg/3.3 lbs!
Nov 12, 1995: launches aboard Atlantis for STS-74. He will be the 1st & only Canadian to board Mir
Russian Art - on the electric commuter train, showing reserved seats. The top one is very ... Impressionistic.
Remembrance Day - Chris Hadfield 820 Squadron Royal Cdn Air Cadets honour our veterans:
Spent a while in my back yard last night enjoying the sights, smells and quiet. Last time before heading to Russia today for launch prep.
Learn about the exams, quals & traditions will go thru in the next few weeks in The Soyuz Experience:
world's largest centrifuge, in Star City, where I qualified to manually fly the Soyuz home through the atmosphere
As his launch approaches, shares his reflections on how a person can live their dreams:
11 Nov is Remembrance Day. It's important to me. My medical techs are proud to wear poppies too
Typical Astronaut Day: they did heart ultrasounds, blood vessel imaging, panoptic eye, froze fish & fixed the toilet!
That looks just like me - merci Eva! (drawn by Eva in Grade 2 )
That looks just like me - merci Eva! (drawn by Eva in Grade 2 )
Backup Astronaut - just in case, Luca is trained to fly in my place; his planned launch is in May. He plays guitar too!
How is our climate changing? Take a look at some of the Key Indicators here:
How to Catch an Astronaut - I cleverly avoided this trap by using a different entrance to our training building.
This spaceship cockpit dares me to start throwing switches! Nice Canadarm :)
a spaceship just before it runs into you - from last week's Progress docking, -Suni's photo
Whistling, of all things... trip into vacuum for & myself! On the blog.
Last week in US B4 final exams in Russia & launch! Great photo taken during last week's EVA - can u find the crew?
'Unity Day' today, Russian holiday. I'm studying for my final 7 exams to qualify for spaceflight
Get a message from NASA - to know when to look up and see the Space Station fly over you!
Movember has raised $300 million for health research. The CSA, my moustache & I are glad to be a part of that!
Here's how it looks today in Star City, Russia; 3 babushkas on a November walk.
Awoken by Explosion - rattled windows, roared, lit the sky like sunrise, 5 km from Star City:
With the winners of the Young Cosmonauts competition, today here in Star City. Bright, nice young people.

at for proficiency training (and Payload) as cmdr

Canadian astronaut Chris Hadfield training at VRLab.

studies hardware we may have to replace EVA, suspended to react like its in 0-g. Last week of US trng!

Spacewalk Glove Damage from last week's work outside. Just the rubber pad, but something to beware in a pressure suit!
